channel.title: MyRightCareer
channel.description: Helping you find your Right Career

item.title: Prerequisites
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Welcome to the MyRightCareer Program

Click on the link above to see a video where Don provides an approximately 5 minute Overview of the MyRightCareer Program, the

Prerequisites Assignment and the Web site. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page. Note: If you are using a Mac you will need to install Flip4Mac, the official Windows Media Player on the Mac, so you can play Windows Media files (.wma and .wmv) and view Windows Media content using a Web browser. You only need the Free player. Click Flip4Mac.

Web site Navigation

We designed the system with two methods of navigation to make it easy for you. They will allow you to do things like: moving from one Assignment to another, moving from one Exercise to another, moving from one Step to the next Step (within an Exercise), moving from Short Instructions to Full Instructions (and back to Short Instructions), accessing resources like Example pages and Template pages.Top Down Navigation Top Down Navigation The Assignments, that are listed across the top of the Web page, have Drop Down menu's. If you hold your cursor over any of them they will expand to show you everything under that Assignment. You can use the Top Down Navigation to get to anything in the system at any time.
  • Under each Assignment it will show all the Exercises
  • Under each Exercise it will show all the pages, e.g. Short Instructions, All the Full Instruction Steps (1, 2, ...), Examples and Templates.
Sub-Navigation Menu The Sub-Navigation menu is located in the upper right portion of every page. It displays the Web pages at the level of your current page. Thus to the right you now see all the Exercises in the Pre-Requisites Assignment (e.g. Steps 1 to 7). This allows you to go from one Exercise to the next in this example. Each time you click on a new Exercise, e.g. "2-Program Approach", that page will be displayed and that heading will have a gray box around it. When you are finished with "2-Program Approach" you only need to select the next Exercise you want to complete from the Sub-Navigation Menu.

Prerequisites

Below are the steps in the Prerequisites Assignment. Almost all of them are the same whether you are the student completing the MyRightCareer Program or an adult helping them as an Adviser or Career Advisory Board Member. The only one that is different is the description of the Advisor & Career Advisory Board Member - in this case there is a unique description for the Student and another description for the Adult who will playing one of these roles.
  • 1 - Review the Intern Guidance (Optional)
As an Intern you will be using the MyRightCareer system differently depending on the type of Internship you are completing. Visit the Intern Guidance page, find your Internship and read the Guidance before proceeding. Click on the Intern Guidance link in the Sub Navigation panel on the right to find out more. If you are not completing an Internship you do not need to read this page.
  • 2 - Complete the Right Career Concept Overview
The Right Career concept will drive your decisions for your first job and for your jobs for the rest of your career. You will forever be trying to find something that leverages your natural talents & personality so you can Be Your Best, something that allows you to find Meaning & Passion and something that will fuel your economic engine (money to support your life style). You will also learn about a concept called the “Whole Person”, which involves dealing with more than just your career. Both the student and the Facilitator need to understand the Right Career concept because it is the foundation for this Program. This will take less than 10 minutes. Click on the Right Career Concept Overview link in the Sub Navigation panel on the right to find out more.
  • 3 - Understand the different Program Approaches
A good way to start is to envision the MyRightCareer Program as a college course. The recommended order for completing the Assignments is their position across the top of the Web page. But you don’t have to do the Assignments in the recommended order, instead you can complete the ones that you feel will provide the most insights. Click on the Program Approach link in the Sub Navigation panel on the right to find out more.
  • 4 - Understand the Program Content
The MyRightCareer Program has three main types of work: Prerequisites Assignment, Insights Assignments (six) and the Capstone Project. Click on the Program Content link in the Sub Navigation panel on the right to find out more.
  • 5 - Review the Benefits
There are two types of benefits from taking the MyRightCareer Program. 1) Immediate - This is what you get once you take that first step on your Right Career path. It is the benefit of being in your Right Career. 2) Long Term - This is how the Program will help you as you move forward in your life. In today's world this is probably not the only time you will make a career decision. You are predicted to have five to eight careers in your professional life. Click on the Benefits link in the Sub Navigation panel on the right to find out more.
  • 6 - Program User - Adviser and Career Advisory Board Member
These two roles provide the MyRightCareer Program User with very important outside input. To find out more about the those roles click on the Program User - Adviser and Career Advisory Board link in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.
  • 7 - Mentor - Adviser and Career Advisory Board Member
This is written for the people who are going to be Career Mentors to the people who are using the MyRightCareer System. By assuming one of these two roles you will be providing the Program User an invaluable service, bringing real life experience to the Right Career identification process. To find out more about the those roles click on the Mentor - Adviser and Career Advisory Board link in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.
  • 8 - Provide Feedback
In this step you will be asked to take a survey and provide your feedback on the Prerequisites Assignment. Click on the Prerequisites Feedback link in the Sub Navigation panel on the right to provide your Feedback.

Summary

When you have completed all the Prerequisites steps you are ready to begin the first of the six Insights Assignments that provide the insights you will use during the last Assignment, your Capstone Project. From the Assignment Menu across the top of the screen select the End Assignment.

item.title: Old Accomplishments
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

You need to: 1) Create a list of accomplishments, 2) Create a list of 3 to 10 major accomplishments you really enjoyed doing, 3) Create a list of 2 to 3 accomplishments you did not enjoy doing, 4) Document the insights you gained from the exercise (both enjoyed doing and didn't enjoy doing), 5) Provide feedback, 6) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 7) Become an Example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. Steps 1 through 4 will probably take you about 2 hours. I like to think of it as we all have two resumes – one for others (e.g. to get into grad school, to find a job or just to impress people) and one for ourselves (this is what we are developing in this exercise).

Resume for Others

You put Accomplishments on this resume that you know other people will find impressive. It doesn’t matter if you enjoyed doing them or not. You are looking for all the things that will sell you to others. You are looking for the things that are “hot” at this moment in time. You are creating a special resume for that target company.

Resume for Yourself

This is the resume I am asking you to create. It will help you understand what is the Right Career for you to pursue. Enjoy Doing: It contains Accomplishments you really enjoyed doing. They must be Accomplishments that both you and others will recognize as true accomplishments. I am making it hard because I am asking you to create a short list of Accomplishments – only 3 to 5. But think of that as your short Bio in a normal resume. If you look at the examples I provided you will see several of them are clearly not ones that end up on the “Resume for Others”: Dave (Getting to take Dad flying) and Melissa (Marathoner). Yet you can learn things from these Accomplishments that will help you in many different ways. Don't Enjoy Doing: It also contains Accomplishments you did not really enjoy doing, but you did them anyway.

  • Instructions

    • Now you get to apply these ideas to your life.

    Resources to help you

    Click on Resources to access the Accomplishments Resources page which contains examples of other people's Accomplishments.

    1) Create a List of the Major Accomplishments (You really liked doing)

    Create a list of 3 to 10 major accomplishments you really enjoyed doing. The accomplishments have to be significant accomplishments. They also have to be ones you really enjoyed doing, not just ones you put on your resume because you know they will impress the reader. Think of this as your personal resume – it is written for you, not other people. IT IS VERY IMPORTANT THEY ARE ACCOMPLISHMENTS YOU REALLY ENJOYED DOING. One of the best ways to arrive at the Top 3 to 10 is to start with a longer list and narrow it down. Here is an example:
  • Click on Jenna's All Accomplishments List and you will see a document listing all of Jenna's accomplishments from middle school through the middle of her sophomore year in college. Her Top Accomplishments (she really enjoyed doing) are highlighted in bold blue.
    If you listed all of your accomplishments you still need to create a single list of your Top 3 to 10 Accomplishments your really enjoyed doing. Here is an example:
  • Click on Jenna's Top Accomplishments List and you will see a document listing only Jenna's Top Accomplishments (she really enjoyed doing) from middle school through the middle of her sophomore year in college.

    2) Document Insights Gained from the exercise

    What did you learn by looking at your entire list of accomplishments? What did you learn by then selecting only the 3 to 10 you really enjoyed doing?

  • Summary

    • We would all like to be doing things we really like to do and we do well. This exercise should have helped you gained some insights.

item.title: Fuel Your Economic Engine
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Your assignment involves these steps: 1) Estimate your Age 30 Budget, 2) Estimate your Age 22 Budget, 3) Optional Exercise – Age 22 Non Professional Job, 4) Optional Exercise - Financials of Buying a House, 5) Optional Exercise - Financials of Raising a Family, 6) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights, 7) Provide feedback, 8) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 9) Become an Example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. The Basic Assignment (Steps 1 & 2) will take you about 2 hours, with another hour for the Insights/etc. Each of the Optional Exercises will add another hour. If you did all of the exercises this Assignment would take around 6 hours to complete.
If you click on Economic Engine Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the exercises in this Assignment. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Adviser/Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page.
There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically listening to an approximately 6 minute video and using examples to do your work.

click on Full Instructions

If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the approximately 6 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

item.title: Capstone
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

This Assignment has three exercises:

Identify your Right Career

In this Exercise will use the information you have been collecting in your MyRightCareer Insights documents (Be your Best, Meaning/Passion, Fuel your Economic Engine and Whole Person) to identify your Right Career (s). This should take you about 2 to 3 hours to complete.

Build a Sales Story

In this Exercise you will use that same information you used to identify your Right Career to build a Sales Story for why your are the Right person for your Right Career. This should take about 2 hours to complete.

Build a Follow-on Plan

In this Exercise you will build a Follow-on Plan. The length of the plan will depend on your situation, e.g. Casey's is a 2 year plan, while Edward's is only a 1 year plan. This should take about 2 hours to complete.
The total time to complete this Assignment is 6 to 7 hours.
There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically reading a couple of sentences of instructions and using examples to do your work.

click on Full Instructions

If you would like more help then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

item.title: Old Personality & Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Not Conformed to New Delivery Approach

This assignment has three exercises. You get to those exercises by clicking on the links in the Sub Navigation section on the right.

  • Personality

    In this exercise you will take your Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator to produce a "Do What You Are" assessment. This will help you understand your personality and the occupations most suited to that personality.

  • Strong Interest Inventory

    The Strong Interest Inventory has been around for over 70 years and helps you see what types of careers and occupations might interest you.

  • Strong/Myers-Briggs Career Report

    Your combined results on the Strong and MBTI tools are based on two simple assumptions— 1) that you are most likely to be satisfied and productive if you are working at something that interests you (the Strong Interest Inventory) and 2) if that something also fits your personality (your Myers-Briggs Type).

item.title: Step 1 - Strong Interest Inventory
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Keep in mind that the Strong Inventory measures interests, not skills or abilities. The report is summarizing what you said in the assessment - so this is what you said interests you. I have found people often think these interests were created by the system, they were not, they are yours. The results can help guide you toward rewarding careers, work activities, education programs, and leisure activities—all based on your interests. The Strong Interest Inventory and Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report (with Strong Profile) is two reports. The first section (pages 1 to 9) deals with the Strong Interest Inventory and is the subject of this exercise step. Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Report (pages 1 - 9)

Assignment

Take a look at the following areas:

Review your General Occupational Themes

The charts display your General Occupational Themes results in descending order, from your highest to least level of interest. Referring to the Theme Descriptions provided, determine how well your results fit for you. Do your highest Themes ring true? Look at your next highest level of interest and ask yourself the same question. The General Occupational Themes (GOTs) measure six broad interest patterns that can be used to describe your work personality: Enterprising, Conventional, Social, Artistic, Investigative and Athletic. These are also referred to as Holland Codes and are used on other systems, e.g the O*NET System referred to below. Most people’s interests are reflected by three Themes (e.g. Edward's are Enterprising, Conventional and Social), combined to form a cluster of interests. Work activities, potential skills, and values can also be classified into these six Themes. This provides a direct link between your interests and the career and education possibilities likely to be most meaningful to you. Your standard scores are based on the average scores of a combined group of working adults. However, because research shows that men and women tend to respond differently in these areas, your interest levels (Very Little, Little, Moderate, High, Very High) were determined by comparing your scores against the average scores for your gender.

Make use of O*NET

O*NET MyNextMove: Click on MyNextMove to start the use of the system. You have three options to search for careers: 1) Search Careers with Keywords, 2) Browse Industries and 3) Tell the System What you Like to Do (Interests). If you click on the third one the O*NET Interest Profiler can help you find out how your interests relate to the world of work. You can take their short Interest Assessment or use your GOT scores (General Occupational Themes) from the Strong Interest Inventory report discussed above. For consistency we recommend using your Strong Interest Inventory GOT scores. Because MyNextMove uses a different scale you need to multiple your Strong Interest Inventory GOT scores by 50% before putting them in the system. Then you will see a little menu button on the left of the page "Taken the Interest Profiler before?". Click it and enter your GOT scores X 50%. Edward's O*NET Interest Scores (GOT Score x 50%) You can then choose the Job Zone of interest (1 = Little of no Preparation, up to 5 = Extensive Preparation Need). Edward selected Zone 5 and the system provided Edward's Career List. After some more use of the system Edward identified three careers of interest. He is trying to decide if he should: 1) Engineering - go out to work in engineering after his graduation, 2) Law - go to Law School or 3) Business - go to an MBA Program. Below are careers in Law and Business (he already understands an engineering career): Chief Executives Financial - Treasurers and Controllers Lawyers If you think your Strong Interest Inventory Assessment may not represent your true interests you can take the O*NET Interest Profiler and get a new set of scores. Or you can do it just to see if the Interest Areas change when you take a different type of Interest Assessment.
O*NET Overview: You can access the O*Net Web site to perform your own searches. My Next Move referenced above is one of the capabilities offered on the O*NET Web site. The O*NET program is the nation's primary source of occupational information. Central to the project is the O*NET database, containing information on hundreds of standardized and occupation-specific descriptors. The database, which is available to the public at no cost, is continually updated by surveying a broad range of workers from each occupation. Information from this database forms the heart of O*NET OnLine, an interactive application for exploring and searching occupations. The database also provides the basis for their Career Exploration Tools, a set of valuable assessment instruments for workers and students looking to find or change careers. O*NET Content Model: Every occupation requires a different mix of knowledge, skills, and abilities, and is performed using a variety of activities and tasks. These distinguishing characteristics of an occupation are described by the O*NET Content Model. Explore the interactive Content Model to see the range of occupational descriptors in the O*NET database. which defines the key features of an occupation as a standardized, measurable set of variables called "descriptors". This hierarchical model starts with six domains, describing the day-to-day aspects of the job and the qualifications and interests of the typical worker. Click on O*NET Content Model to see more detail. O*NET Taxonomy: While the Content Model defines the information structure for a single occupation, the O*NET-SOC taxonomy defines the set of occupations across the world of work. Based on the Standard Occupational Classification (SOC), the O*NET-SOC taxonomy currently includes 974 occupations which currently have, or are scheduled to have, data collected from job incumbents or occupation experts. To keep up with the changing occupational landscape, the taxonomy is periodically revised; the last revision was in 2010. Click on O*NET Taxonomy to see more detail.

Review your Basic Interest Scales

The Basic Interest Scales represent specific interest areas that often point to work activities, projects, course work, and leisure activities that are personally motivating and rewarding. As with the General Occupational Themes, your interest levels (Very Little, Little, Moderate, High, Very High) were determined by comparing your scores against the average scores for your gender. As you review your results, note your top interest areas and your areas of least interest, and think about how they relate to your work, educational, and leisure activities. Take time to consider any top interest areas that are not currently part of your work or lifestyle and think about how you might be able to incorporate them into your plans. Also look at the Areas of Least Interest that came from your assessment. Sometimes it is just as important to know what doesn't interest you as it is what interests you.

Review your Occupational Scales

Your score on an Occupational Scale shows how similar your interests are to those of people of your gender who have been working in, and are satisfied with, that occupation. The higher your score, the more likes and dislikes you share with those individuals. The Theme Codes associated with each occupation indicate the General Occupational Themes most commonly found among people employed in that occupation. The 10 occupations most closely aligned with your interests are listed in the summary chart. As you read through your Occupational Scales results, note the names of those occupations for which you scored “Similar.” Those are the occupations you might want to explore first. Keep in mind that the occupations listed in your Profile results are just some of the many occupations linked to your interests that you might want to consider. They do not indicate those you “should” pursue. The only one of the Top Ten Occupations that Casey really liked was Advertising Account Manager. She did a search for that occupation at the O*NET Web site and this is what she found Casey's O*Net Advertising Account Manager search result. The result with the highest score was "Advertising and Promotions Managers". There were others she could explore as well.

Review your Professional Styles Scales

Your scores on the Personal Style Scales were determined by comparing your responses to those of a combined group of working men and women. The Personal Style Scales describe different ways of approaching people, learning, leading, making decisions, and participating in teams. Personal Style Scales help you think about your preferences for factors that can be important in your career, enabling you to more effectively narrow your choices and examine your opportunities. Each scale includes descriptions at both ends of the continuum, with scores indicating your preference for one style versus the other.

Document any insights you have gained from this exercise

Casey documented her insights in a separate document, organized by the four areas above:Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Insights.

Summary

You will have learned a lot of things about yourself, your interests and potential occupations. Your interests can give you a clue as to what you might be "Best At" (i.e. what is natural for you), what has Meaning for you and an idea of what might be your Right Career.

item.title: Old Strong & Myers-Briggs Career Report
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

From past experience it works best if you print these pages and then work from the hard copy as you do your assessments and the exercises. It will not only allow you to look at the instructions it will provide a checklist on the assignment.

Strong & Myers-Briggs Exercise

You have already taken these assessments and received the Strong Interest Inventory and Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report (with Strong Profile) Report. The last part of this report is titled Strong and MBTI Career Report in the upper left corner. It has 13 pages. Your combined results on the Strong and MBTI tools are based on the same assumption—that you are most likely to be satisfied and productive if you are working at something you enjoy in an environment you find compatible. · The Strong Interest Inventory matches your interests with six types of work environments. · The MBTI assessment describes your personality type and matches it with types of work.
Take a look at the following areas:
  • Combined Strong Themes and MBTI Preference: Review what happens when you take your strongest General Occupation Theme (e.g. Enterprising) and combine that with your MBTI (e.g. INTJ). For Don ENTERPRISING + INTJ = The Theoretical Persuaders.
  • Combined Personal Style & MBTI Preferences: Review the results on the five Strong inventory scales that describe your personal style of working and learning, combined with the impact of your MBTI preferences (e.g. INTJ).
  • Career Fields suggested by your combined results: Explore the career fields that reflect both General Occupational Theme (e.g. Enterprising) work environments suggested by your Strong results and O*NET™ job families that attract your MBTI type (e.g. INTJ).
  • Occupations suggested by your combined results: Review the occupations that were suggested by both your Strong and MBTI results, thus making it likely that you may find these occupations satisfying and enjoyable. Keep in mind that: 1) Your interests are similar to those of people working in these occupations who like their work and 2) these occupations tend to attract people with your MBTI preferences who are satisfied with their job
  • Good Match to Start Your Career: The Strong Interest Inventory and Meyers-Briggs assessment can guide you to a career direction that is interesting and fulfilling. Be sure to consider entry positions that are a good fit for your Strong Theme and MBTI preferences. Look at the questions in the two boxes for some guidance on your first job.

  • Summary

    • When you are finished with this you will have insights that combine your interests and your personality with a focus on your personal style of working & learning and suggestions of career and occupations.These reports will help you understand how you can "Be Your Best" and give you some insights into what has "Meaning & Passion" for you.

item.title: Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

In this exercise you need to: 1) Use the O*NET System to select your Skills, 2) Assess the Occupations suggested by those Skills, 3) Explore one or two of the Occupations in more depth, 4) Create an Insights document, 5) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights documents, 6) Provide Feedback, 7) Discuss the exercise with your Advisor/Facilitator, and 8) Become an example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total the first five steps will probably take you about 2 to 3 hours.
If you click on Skills Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Adviser. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page.
There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically listening to an approximately 6 minute video and using examples to do your work.

click on Full Instructions

If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the approximately 6 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

Summary

Working in an Occupation that heavily uses the Skills you enjoy using will make you more successful and will make you much happier.

item.title: Drivers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

You need to: 1) Identify your Top 10 Drivers (besides money) and 2) Document the insights you have gained from identifying these Drivers, 3) Update your MyRightCareer Insights documents, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 6) Become an Example. It should take you about 2 hours to complete this exercise. If you click on Drivers Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for this Exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page.

Driver Concept and Defitions

This exercise is borrowed from the book “Don’t Retire, Rewire” by Jeri Sedlar and Rick Miners. You should not let the word Retire turn you off because it has nothing to do with the issue of Drivers. These two people have run an Executive Recruiting business for a long time and this concept came from working with people who were looking for new jobs and careers. They say their candidates were brutally honest about what they wanted, besides money, in their careers. This motivated them to look deeper into the subject of drivers because they found them to be the key to job satisfaction. In their research they asked what pre-retires and retires got out of their work, besides money. They came up with a list of 85 drivers. They then culled it down to the 30 drivers pre-retires and retires most commonly told them were the reasons why they worked.
Top 30 Drivers List and Definitions
Your drivers give you another aid for identifying your Right Opportunity by showing you where your emotional payoff, satisfaction and fulfillment have come from in your life. They don’t tell you the specific activities, jobs, organizations or industries – but now you can see if those will fulfill your drivers.

Summary

There are a lot of mechanics in this exercise. As was discussed in the Skills exercise you should keep the Spirit of the exercise in mind as well as the Letter of the Exercise (e.g. the table mechanics). The Spirit is to find Drivers and some insights from those Drivers, no matter how you do it.

Instructions

To begin click on Drivers Instructions

item.title: Templates-Begin at End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

On this page are templates you can use for all of the sub-exercises. At the bottom of the page is the Begin at the End Checklist which allows you to keep track of the status of the sub-exercises in the Exercise.

Examples as Templates

You can use the examples from the Examples Page as your templates. Below are those same examples, but now you can download them in their native file format, e.g. Word. Just take their structure and remove their information. For example if you use Casey's End Result file it will already have many of the headings you will probably want to use, e.g. Live: We rent an apartment in NYC in the East Village. My husband and I are considering a move to the suburbs or a move to California since we do not want to raise a family in the city. You can then erase the text she put next to the heading Live and put in your own text. You can also add your own headings.

End Result

If you click on Casey's End Result you will get a Word file of Casey's End Result description.

Work Backwards

If you click on Casey's Work Backwards you will get a Word file of how Casey worked backwards from her age 30 career idea to age 22, her graduation from college. If you click on Elizabeth's Work Backwards you will get an Excel file of how Elizabeth worked backwards from age 35 to her current age (25). She address both her Personal Life and her Career. This is a very professional document and you may want to use her format. You can change the end year to Age 30.

Structural Tension

If you click on Casey's Structural Tension you will get a Word file of how Casey created a Structural Tension diagram between her Current Reality (summer between her Sophomore & Junior year) and her Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22 = graduation from college). It shows her objectives for those two years.

Blank Templates

In some cases it can be easier to start with a blank file that has some formatting.

End Result

If you click on End Result Word Template you will get a Word file that has a list of variables you can use to describe your life at Age 30. The list is very similar to the ones in Casey's End Result file.
    MyRightCareer Insights There are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise.
    If you click on the links below you will get a Word document for each of the five files you need to have and you can use those as your template. Each file has the names of the exercises (e.g. Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments) as headings for paragraphs. As you complete each exercise you can place your insights under these headings. Remember once you create each one of these files you will continue to use it for the entire Program. After each exercise you will add more insights to the section of the file with the name of the Exercise you just completed. For example, you should not have two files named YourName-Be Your Best Insights. For every Exercise you will be recording your Insights related to "Be Your Best" in that file. As you can see by Casey and Edward's examples you end up with a multiple page "Be Your Best" file. You should replace the name "Template" with your name.
    Template-Be Your Best Insights Template-Meaning & Passion Insights Template-Economic Engine Insights Template-Right Career Insights Template-Whole Person Insights

    Checklist

    If you click on Begin at the End Checklist Template you will be able to down the Excel file that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the Begin at the End Exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist.

    File Naming

    You should save any file you down load on your computer. Then create another copy with your name appended on the front of that file. You can then fill in your own information in that new file. If you someway screw up that file you can download the template again and not overwrite the one with your data. This way you may be able to copy some of your data from your partly damaged file to the new template.

item.title: Career Advisory Board-Pgm User
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

As a Career Advisory Board Member their main role is reviewing output at three different points in the Program: 1st review will be after first three Insights Assignments, 2nd review will be after final three Insights Assignments and the Final Review will be after the Capstone project. Thus they will only be reviewing your work twice during the program, so they are a lot less involved than an Adviser.

What is their Role?

The Career Advisory Board probably never meets as a group. Instead the MyRightCareer Program User will meet with them individually. Most of those meetings will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email.

Review Program User Progress Three Times

Their main role is reviewing output at three different points in the Program. At which time they will be reviewing your work and having a dialogue with you.
  • Career Advisory Board Meeting #1 will be after you finish the first three Insights Assignments: Begin at the End, Look at Self (Personality and Interests) and Look at the Past (Autobiography and Accomplishments).
  • Career Advisory Board Meeting #2 will be after you finish the final three Insights Assignments: Strengths (Talents/Strengths and Skills), Meaning (Stories, Drivers, How you will Measure Your Life) and Economic Engine (Age 30 & Age 22).
  • Career Advisory Board Meeting #3 - Final Review will be after your Capstone project. You will have identified your Right Career (s), validated it is really right for you, developed your Sales Story for that Right Career (s) and created a Follow-on Plan.

Provide Feedback to Don:

  • The Board Member can provide the feedback in two areas: 1) User issues they observe, e.g. they are taking a lot longer than my guidelines, on this exercise they had trouble with XYZ or this exercise was really powerful; 2) Adviser issues, e.g. if you provided me a tool for ABC it would make my job easier.
  • The Board Member can provide the feedback in two different ways: 1) via the Feedback page – there is a Feedback page on every Exercise that contains an on-line Survey, 2) Other – feel free to use whatever is easiest for you, e.g. email, phone.

Time Required

There are three Career Advisory Board Meetings and the total time estimate is about 12 hours. Below is the logic for this estimate. The first two Career Advisory Board Meeting will each be reviewing three Assignments. It is estimated they will spend about 4 hours per Meeting. For every Meeting they will have two types of reviews:
  • Prior to the Career Advisory Board Meeting (3 hour): Review the exercise output you send them. They will probably spend about 1/2 hour per exercise and most Assignments have two exercises, so they will be reviewing six exercises which will take an estimated 3 hours.
  • During the Career Advisory Board Meeting (1 hour): This is most likely a phone call session with just you (not a meeting with the entire Board) and it could last from 1/2 hour to 1 1/2 hours.
The last Career Advisory Board Meeting occurs after the Capstone Assignment (identified their Right Career, developed their Sales Story and built a Follow-on Plan). They will have less to review before the Meeting, but may have a longer meeting.

Who are Good Candidates?

They should be people who you trust to give you career advice and are willing to help you identify your Right Career. They should also be people who are willing to invest some time in helping you identify your Right Career. Normally it will have three members. Examples of people who could be Board members are: Family: your parents, other family members (e.g. an older sibling, an aunt/uncle, a grandparent and in-law) Friends: parent of a close friend, a close friend Network: your high school adviser, your college adviser, a Professor, a coach (e.g. soccer coach, drama coach), an experienced adult (e.g. an executive), someone from an internship, a professional career coach. You will need to convince them you are serious about identifying your Right Career since you are asking them for a significant commitment of their time and attention.

Career Advisory Board Member Support

There will be information that will help the Career Advisory Board Member in two broad ways.

General Information:

There is general information such as this page. There are also scheduling and tracking resources. If you click on Program Schedule Template - pdf you will get the pdf version of a simple Excel scheduling tool. It has a sample that uses movable red boxes to represent the schedule. They may send you their schedule using this tool. At the minimum they will inform you of each Career Advisory Board review sufficiently ahead of time to make a mutually acceptable schedule.

Exercise Specific Information:

There are specific resources for each Career Advisory Board review, e.g.
  • Experienced Adult Examples On the Adviser Guidance page there will be an Experienced Adult example so they can see an example more like themselves. In the Examples page there are other Experienced Adult examples.
  • Assignment Output. You will provide them with the key outputs for every exercise in the three Assignments they completed prior to the upcoming Career Advisory Board Review. For example, the 1st review will be after they finish the first three Insights Assignments: Begin at the End, Look at Self (Personality and Interests) and Look at the Past (Autobiography and Accomplishments).Click on Board Member Guidance - Review #1. This is the Board Member Guidance page for the 1st Career Advisory Board Meeting and it will open in a new tab.
  • Adviser Guidance on each exercise It will include an Introduction to the Exercise and the Steps they should be taking with you. It is in the list of Steps for the Exercise and they can also click on any of those Steps to get a full set of Instructions. They can also click on the Short Instructions page for a single page with a few sentences, examples and templates for each Step.There is an Adviser Guidance page for every Exercise that will be reviewed in Career Advisory Board Meeting #1: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography and Accomplishments. Below is the one for Begin at the End exercise.Click on Adviser Guidance - Begin at the End and it will open in a new Tab. Once you have reviewed it you can close the Tab.

Future Career Advisory Board Support

Tools will be improved over time with feedback from the Career Advisory Board community. Some of the members may even contribute or suggest tools they have found useful.

How Can a Board Member Use this?

Your Mentor can use the MyRightCareer System just as you will be using it. They can complete the Pre-Requisite Assignment, the six Insights Assignments and finally the Capstone Assignment. Since the system is self-paced they can work on these Assignments (and exercises within each Assignment) at their own pace. The bulk of the work is completing the six Insights Assignments which contain 15 Exercises. Each Exercise takes about 2.5 hours to complete. Each Exercise has multiple Steps and no Step is longer than 1 hour so they can work on this in 1 hour or shorter increments. To use the system they can click on the Experienced Adult step at the end of each page. On that page is  guidance on how they can use this Exercise to identify their own Right Career, as well as an example of someone more like them. In the Examples page there are other examples of Experienced Adults. It will not be hard for them to dialogue with you when they have just finished applying the process to their life.

item.title: 2 - Right Career Concept Overview
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the Right Career Concept Overview. The objective is to provide an overview of the Right Career and Whole Person concepts. • Create meaning and passion • Be your best • Fuel your “economic engine” . . . . .

Introduction

To launch the video click on the paragraph heading below. This will launch Windows Media Player and a presentation by Don will begin on that topic. When the presentation finishes you can close Windows Media Player and then the Tab and you will return to this page.
Note: In case you got to this page without watching the Program Overview video and if you are using a Mac you will need to install Flip4Mac, the official Windows Media Player on the Mac, so you can play Windows Media files (.wma and .wmv) and view Windows Media content using a Web browser. You only need the Free player. Click Flip4Mac.

Right Career Concepts

This module summaries the Right Career and Whole Person concepts.

Examples

WHAT you choose as a Right Career will depend heavily on WHEN you make that decision. Below are some examples:

Casey (Sophomore)

She is making her first Right Career decision during the Spring semester of her Sophomore year at a small liberal arts college. At that time she had no Internships and only two years of college. Casey had little career information to base her decision. But her advantage is an early decision will give her time to have Internships between her sophomore/junior years and between her junior/senior years that are a good fit with her Right Career. These might validate the decision she made in the spring semester of her Sophomore year or they may cause her to rethink that decision. Both outcomes are good. She also has a chance to tailor her courses, projects and other campus actives for her Junior and Senior year to her Right Career.

Edward (Junior)

He is making his first Right Career decision during the Spring semester of his junior year at a small engineering school. Between his Sophomore and Junior year he had an engineering Internship and he is signed up for another engineering Internship for the upcoming summer between his Junior and Senior year. He also has almost completed three years of college. Edward has a lot more career information on which to base his decision - first he is in a career based major (engineering) and second he will soon have two career based Internships. He is looking at three alternatives: 1) work as an engineer for a few years and then go to graduate school, 2) get an MBA right after undergraduate engineering school and 3) get a law degree right after undergraduate engineering school.

Edward (end of MBA Program)

During the Spring semester of his Junior year Edward decided to pursue his MBA. In the final semester of his MBA program he has a lot more career information than he did in the spring semester of his junior year - he completed the engineering Internship between his junior and senior year, he completed another engineering internship between undergraduate school and the MBA program, he paid for graduate school by working half time in a NASA joint venture and of course he has almost completed his MBA. He has also decided to get married during the summer after graduate school, something he did not predict in his previous Age 30 Vision (he thought he would not marry until Age 28, not Age 24). It is not a lot more work to leverage the MyRight Career process, the personal information he collected and the insights he discovered to identify his 2nd Right Career.

Elizabeth (Two Years Out of College)

She is making her Right Career decision a couple of years after graduating from college. She has been working at various jobs - one full time for about a year, some part-time and a business she started. She has a lot of career information on which to base her decision, as well as her college education. One important piece of information she has is she knows some things she doesn't want to do.

item.title: Adviser-Pgm User
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

The Adviser is more involved than they would be if they were a member of your Career Advisory Board. As an Adviser they work you on every Assignment, reviewing output from every Exercise in that Assignment. You will typically meet with them seven times, once for each of the six Insights Assignments and then once after the Capstone Assignment. On-going Mentoring is a very good idea with your Adviser. They will know you well by end of the Program, including your Follow-on Plan. You will need assistance in implementing your Follow-on Plan and they can be a valuable ally.

What does an Adviser Do?

As the Adviser they have three roles.

Collaboratively Manage the Process:

  • Together you decide on the approach you should take: College Course or Cafeteria. If you use the College Course approach you will be completing all six Insight Assignments in the order they appear at the top of the screen. If you choose the Cafeteria Approach you will select which of the six Assignments the two of you feel would be most helpful in defining your right career. There is guidance in the PreRequisites Assignment, Course Approach module, for doing this. You could start by doing only three Assignments and see if you can identify your right career. If after those three Assignments you don't feel ready to identify your right career you could then add one or two other Assignments you both think would add some more insights.
  • Together you set up the initial schedule. This is entirely a self-paced Program. The two of you should create a schedule that takes into account your academic, extracurricular (e.g. sports) and personal realities. It has to also factor the Adviser/Facilitator's own schedule into the equation. There is an Excel spreadsheet with a suggested schedule you two can customize.
  • There is a Checklist you will be given for each exercise that can be used by both of you to manage the progress.

Help with the Program Content:

  • Most of their involvement comes after you complete an Assignment and send them the completed exercises. The most important output are the MyRightCareer Insights files. There is one file for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram: Be Your Best, Meaning & Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career (s) and Whole Person. After each exercise you will add your insights for that exercise to each of the files. The Adviser should be reviewing those files.
  • Most of those reviews will take place over the phone and much of the content will be shared via email.

Provide Feedback to Don:

  • The Adviser can provide the feedback in two areas: 1) User issues they observe, e.g. they are taking a lot longer than my guidelines, on this exercise they had trouble with XYZ or this exercise was really powerful; 2) Adviser issues, e.g. if you provided me a tool for ABC it would make my job easier.
  • The Adviser can provide the feedback in two different ways: 1) via the Feedback page – there is a Feedback page on every Exercise that contains an on-line Survey, 2) Other – feel free to use whatever is easiest for you, e.g. email, phone.

Time Required

Program User

If you complete everything there are six Insight Assignments (which contain 15 Exercises) so the total time estimate for those Exercises (using 2.5 hours/Assignment) is about 38 hours. After completing the Insight Assignments you will then complete the Capstone Assignment, where you identify your Right Career, create a Sales Story and build a Follow-on Plan. The time for the Capstone Assignment is about 10 to 15  hours. All of this work would most likely be spread over a 12 week period, but since the Program is entirely self-paced you and your advisee can work out a mutually acceptable schedule.

Adviser

Your Adviser will review your exercise output after you complete each of the six Insight Assignments. For every Assignment they will have two types of reviews.
  • Prior to the Insight Assignment Review Session (1 hour): Review the Assignment output you send them - it could last from 1/2 hour to 1 1/2 hours.
  • During the Insight Assignment Session (1 hour): This is most likely a phone call session - it could last from 1/2 hour to 1 1/2 hours.

Who are Good Candidates?

They should be people who you trust to give you career advice and are willing to help you identify your Right Career. They should also be people who are willing to invest some time in helping you identify your Right Career. Examples of people who could be Advisers are: Alumni: your career office can probably arrange for an Alumni of the school to help you. Family: your parents, other family members (e.g. an older sibling, an aunt/uncle, a grandparent and in-law) Friends: parent of a close friend, a close friend Network: your high school adviser, your college adviser, a Professor, a coach (e.g. soccer coach, drama coach), an experienced adult (e.g. an executive), someone from an internship, a professional career coach. You will need to convince them you are serious about identifying your Right Career since you are asking them for a significant commitment of their time and attention.

What Support are Advisers Provided?

There will be information that will help the Adviser in two broad ways.

General Information:

There is general information such as this page. There are also scheduling and tracking resources. If you click on Program Schedule Template - pdf you will get the pdf version of a simple Excel scheduling tool. It has a sample that uses movable red boxes to represent the schedule. If you click on Program Schedule Template - Excel you will get the Excel version. It is the sample schedule, except in Excel so you can create your own schedule. If you change the start date all the other dates will change by 7 days. You can move the red boxes around - there are one week, two week and three week boxes.

Exercise Specific Information:

There are specific resources for each exercise, e.g.
  • Experienced Adult Examples On the Adviser Guidance page there will be an Experienced Adult example so they can see an example more like themselves. In the Examples page there are other Experienced Adult examples.
  • Adviser Guidance on each exercise It will include an Introduction to the Exercise and the Steps the Adviser should be taking with the Program User. It is in the list of Steps for the Exercise and you can also click on any of those Steps to get a full set of Instructions. You can also click on the Short Instructions page for a single page with a few sentences, examples and templates for each Step. Click on Adviser Guidance - Begin at the End. and it will open in a new Tab. Once you have reviewed it you can close the Tab.
  • Exercise Checklist (used by both the Program User and Adviser). To see an example of a Checklist click on Begin at the End Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the Begin at the End Exercise. Each of you will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page in the Begin at the End exercise Assignment

Future Adviser Support

Tools will be improved over time with feedback from the Adviser community. Some of the members may even contribute or suggest tools they have found useful.

How Can an Adviser Use this?

Your Mentor can use the MyRightCareer System just as you will be using it. They can complete the Pre-Requisite Assignment, the six Insights Assignments and finally the Capstone Assignment. Since the system is self-paced they can work on these Assignments (and exercises within each Assignment) at their own pace. The bulk of the work is completing the six Insights Assignments which contain 15 Exercises. Each Exercise takes about 2.5 hours to complete. Each Exercise has multiple Steps and no Step is longer than 1 hour so they can work on this in 1 hour or shorter increments. To use the system they can click on the Experienced Adult step at the end of each page. On that page is  guidance on how they can use this Exercise to identify their own Right Career, as well as an example of someone more like them. In the Examples page there are other examples of Experienced Adults. It will not be hard for them to dialogue with you when they have just finished applying the process to their life.

item.title: Old Examples - Acc
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
There are two groups of examples that will help you with this assignment.

  • College Examples

    One of these (Jenna) is from one of the early users of the Program. The other is Don's, acting as if he had used the Program when he was a Junior in College.
  • Click on Jenna's All Accomplishments List and you will see a document listing all of Jenna's accomplishments from middle school through the middle of her sophomore year in college. Her Top Accomplishments are highlighted in bold blue.
  • Click on Jenna's Top Accomplishments List and you will see a document listing only Jenna's Top Accomplishments from middle school through the middle of her sophomore year in college.
    • Click on Don's All Accomplishments List and you will see a document in which Don listed all of his accomplishments starting with junior high school through his junior year in college. He then used that list to identify his Top 8 (highlighted in bold blue).
    • Click on Don's Top Accomplishments List and you will see a document in which he listed only his Top Accomplishments from junior high school through his junior year in college.

      Plan B Examples (30's/40's/50's)

      These are from the Plan B Program that is focused on people in their 30's, 40's and 50's who are looking for something other than their current career. They are also trying to identify their Right Opportunity and these are very helpful examples.
    • Dave's Example It has a list of Major Accomplishments, his Top 7 Accomplishments (highlighted on his Major Accomplishments list) and three stories (including insights). The stories he chose to write are an indication of which of the 7 accomplishments meant the most to him. Note: this is a multiple page document.
    • Melissa’s Example It has a list of Major Accomplishments, her Top 8 Accomplishments and four stories (including insights). The 4 stories she chose to write are an indication of which of the 8 accomplishments meant the most to her. Note: this is also a multiple page document.

item.title: Look at Past
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This Assignment has two exercises.

  • Autobiography

    To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. In this exercise you need to: 1) write an autobiography & provide insights, 2) document the transitions & provide insights, 3) add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 4) discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 5) provide feedback.

  • Accomplishments

    To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. In this exercise you need to: 1) Create a list of 3 to 10 major accomplishments you really enjoyed doing and 2) add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 3) discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 4) provide feedback.

item.title: Autobiography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

In this exercise you need to: 1) Write your autobiography & provide insights, 2) Document your transitions & provide insights, 3) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 6) Become an example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total the first three steps will probably take you about 2 to 3 hours. Note: If you are an experienced adult, instead of a student, visit the "Experienced Adult" page before beginning this exercise. You can think of your Autobiography as your Facebook Timeline, but in words rather than pictures. You can create both the words and the photos to make it a richer Autobiography If you click on Autobiography Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the Autobiography Exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page. There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically listening to a 5 minute video and using examples to do your work.

click on Full Instructions

If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the same 5 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

item.title: Templates-Autobiography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

On this page are two templates you can use. At the top is a template for the Autobiography document. At the bottom of the page is the Autobiography Checklist which allows you to keep track of the status of the sub-exercises in the Exercise.

Template

Autobiography: Autobiography Template This is a Word document with the outline for an autobiography. If you look at the Don or Casey examples you will see they basically used this same outline.
Autobiography Insights: There is no template for this. If you create a separate Insights document consider using your Autobiography structure as the organizing mechanism for your insights. Both Casey and Don used that approach. You can also put your insights as the end of your Autobiography
Transitions: There is no template for this. In the instructions you were given guidance on how you can take your Autobiography document and turn it into a Transitions document. You make a copy of your Autobiography and name it XYZ-Transitions.doc. Now go through the document highlighting all of the items in red you feel have been a transition for you. If you believe there have been other Transitions you have not captured with this approach write them at the end of the document. To identify the major Transitions you take the items you believe to be major and make them Bold.
Transitions Insights: There is no template for this. If you want to create a separate Insight document consider using the above Transitions document as the organizing mechanism. Don used this approach. Casey put her Transition insights at the end of her Transitions document.

Checklist

If you click on Autobiography Checklist Template you will be able to download the Excel file that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the Autobiography. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Adviser/Facilitator. Both of you can get the file from this Templates page.

File Naming

You should save any file you down load on your computer. Then create another copy with your name appended on the front of that file. You can then fill in your own information in that new file. If you someway screw up that file you can download the template again and not overwrite the one with your data. This way you may be able to copy some of your data from your partly damaged file to the new template.

item.title: Stories
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

You need to: 1) Write stories about two of your Major Accomplishments you enjoyed doing, 2) Write a story about an accomplishment you did not enjoy doing, 3) Document your Insights for each story, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 6) Become an Example. Each story will take about an hour to write, with another 15 minutes to add your insights. The exercise should take about 4 hours.
If you click on Stories Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for this Exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page.

Summary

I recommend at some time in the future you write a story for all of the 3 to 10 Major Accomplishments you really enjoyed doing. By writing a story for each of them you will gain a deeper understanding than you will by just listing them. But it usually takes about 60 minutes to write a story & its insights, so you are going to have to invest more time. The value of these stories is huge. Because at age 30 wouldn’t you like all the Major Accomplishments that have occurred over that last 10 years to be like the ones you have just written. I think we would all like to repeat the experiences where we accomplish things and we really enjoy doing it. One way to do that is document what those accomplishments have been and then analyze them – the more accomplishments you have to analyze the better your conclusions will be. These stories of accomplishments you really enjoyed doing are a great way to discover "What has Meaning & Passion" for you.

Instructions

To begin click on

Stories Instructions

item.title: Examples-Stories
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Below are examples from this Exercise: College Students, Recent Graduates and Experienced Adults.

Casey - End Sophomore Year

Stories & Insights:
Casey's Soccer Endurance Casey's Long Term Friends Casey's No Math
MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Edward - End Junior Year

Stories & Insights:
Edward's Newspaper Story Edward's Newspaper Story Insights Edward's Hay Bailing Edward's Apprentice Electrician/Plumber
MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How to Measure Your Life and Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Edward's "Be Your Best" Insights Edward's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Edward's "Economic Engine" Insights Edward's "Right Career" Insights Edward's "Whole Person" Insights

Experienced Adults

Below are examples that can be of value to an Experienced Adult who wants to use the MyRightCareer System for their own life or just see examples more like themselves to improve their ability to be an Adviser. To get started using the MyRightCareer System for your own career click on the “Experienced Adult” heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right. College students may also find these examples useful because they show 1) how this technique can be used the rest of your life and 2) some interesting examples of how someone more your parent's age used the approach.
Bud created a unique document for each of his stories and then put his insights in a separate accompanying document. Bud's College Newspaper Story. Bud's College Newspaper Insights. He highlighted in red the key areas and then inserted his insight for that area in blue. At the end of the document he put his over insights in blue. Bud's MSI Turn-Around Story. Bud's MSI Turn-Around Insights.
Matt's Stories . Matt put all of his stories in one Word file. At the end of each story he included his insights for that story.

item.title: Examples-Begin at End
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Below are examples from this Exercise: Generic Whole Person, College Students, Recent Graduates and Experienced Adults. At the bottom of the page is a checklist to keep track of the status of the Steps in the Exercise.

Generic Whole Person Examples

End Result

Whole Person at Age 30

Work Backwards

Married at Age 30 Married & Buy a House at Age 30 Married & 1st Child at Age 30

College Students

Casey - End Sophomore Year

End Result If you click on Casey's End Result you will get a pdf file of Casey's End Result description. In this description she included an idea of what her career at age 30 might be. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
Work Backwards If you click on Casey's Work Backwards you will get a pdf file of how Casey worked backwards from her age 30 career idea to age 22, her graduation from college. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
Structural Tension If you click on Casey's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how Casey created a Structural Tension diagram between her Current Reality (summer between her Sophomore & Junior year) and her Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22 = graduation from college). It shows her objectives for those two years. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
MyRightCareer Insights There are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Career" and one for "Whole Person". This exercise has added a set of insights to each file. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.
These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How will you Measure Your Life and Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how she has added insights with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Madison- End Sophomore Year

End Result If you click on Madison's End Result you will get a pdf file of Madison's End Result description. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
Work Backwards If you click on Madison's Work Backwards you will get a pdf file of how Madison worked backwards from her age 30 career idea to her graduation from college. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
Structural Tension If you click on Madison's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how Madison created a Structural Tension diagram between her Current Reality (summer between her Sophomore & Junior year) and her Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22 = graduation from college). It shows her objectives for those two years. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Madison obtained from completing the first two exercises: Begin at the End and Autobiography. From these examples you can see how she has added insights with every exercise. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Madison's "Be Your Best" Insights Madison 's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Madison 's "Economic Engine" Insights Madison 's "Right Career" Insights Madison 's "Whole Person" Insights

Olivia- End Sophomore Year

End Result If you click on Olivia's End Result you will get a pdf file of Olivia End Result description. Besides a description of her Whole Person she also provides a vision of a couple of career alternatives. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
Work Backwards If you click on Olivia's Work Backwards you will get a pdf file of how Olivia worked backwards from her age 30 vision to her graduation from college on her two career ideas. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
Structural Tension If you click on Olivia's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how she created a Structural Tension diagram between her Current Reality (summer between her Sophomore & Junior year) and her Intermediate End Result #1 (age 22 = graduation from college). It shows her objectives for those two years. She included her Insights at the end of the document.

Edward - End Junior Year

End Result If you click on Edward's End Result you will get a pdf file of Edward's End Result description. In this document he included a description of three different possible careers. His description of each category is more extensive than Casey's, thus providing a different example. This is a multiple page document.
Vision Board If you click on Edward's Age 30 Vision Board you will get Edward's Vision Board, showing many of the major items in the End Result document.
Work Backwards If you click on Edward's Work Backwards you will get a pdf file of how Edward worked backwards for each of his three possible careers. On the second page you will also see how he worked backwards on his personal relationship. Because he was looking at 3 careers side by side he found it easier to use Excel to create a table than trying to create the same table in Word. If you need a multi-column table you can use Edward's Work Backwards Excel document as a template and you will find it on the Templates page.
Structural Tension If you click on Edward's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how Don created Structural Tension diagram between his Current Reality (start of his senior year) and his Intermediate End Result #1 (end of his senior year). Because of the nature of his 3 potential career paths he had to make his Intermediate End Result #1 be closer in than suggested.
MyRightCareer Insights TThese five documents are examples of the insights Edward obtained from completing all the exercises except Economic Engine: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories and Drivers. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Edward's "Be Your Best" Insights Edward's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Edward's "Economic Engine" Insights Edward's "Right Career" Insights Edward's "Whole Person" Insights

Paul - End Junior Year

End Result If you click on Paul's End Result you will get a pdf file of Paul's End Result description.
Work Backwards If you click on Paul's Work Backwards you will get a pdf file of how Paul worked backwards on his career idea.
Structural Tension If you click on Paul's Structural Tension you will get a pdf file of how he created Structural Tension diagram between his Current Reality (start of his senior year) and the end of his senior year.

Recent Graduates

Elizabeth (Age 25)

End Result If you click on Elizabeth's End Result you will get a pdf file of Elizabeth's End Result description. In this description she included an idea of what her career at age 35 might be and what she didn't want it to be. She included her Insights at the end of the document.
Work Backwards If you click on Elizabeth's Work Backwards you will get a pdf file of how Elizabeth worked backwards from age 35 to her current age (25). She address both her Personal Life and her Career. This is a very professional document and you may want to use her format. She included her Insights at the end of the document.

Experienced Adults

Below are examples that can be of value to an Experienced Adult who wants to use the MyRightCareer System for their own life or just see examples more like themselves to improve their ability to be an Adviser. To get started using the MyRightCareer System for your own career click on the “Experienced Adult” heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right. College students may also find these examples useful because they show 1) how this technique can be used the rest of your life and 2) some interesting examples of how someone more your parent's age used the approach.

Matt (Age 47)

End Result Matt's Time Line. He selected the year his youngest is out of college and has worked for one year. This is 8 years from his current situation (Age 47) and he will be 55 at that time. Matt's End Result He picked six key parameters, not as many as most students pick.
Work Backwards Matt's Work Backwards: Matt worked backwards from his Ultimate End Result (Age 55) to his Current Reality (Age 47).
Structural Tension Matt's Structural Tension: Matt created a document showing the relationship between his Current Reality and his Intermediate End Result #1. Matt's Structural Tension Objectives: Matt created five Objectives he feels he needs to achieve to move from his Current Reality to his Intermediate End Result #1.

Mary (Age 50)

End Result Mary's Time Line. She selected the year her twins leave for college. This is 5 years from her current situation. Mary's End Result She picked six key parameters, not as many as most students pick.
Work Backwards Mary's Work Backwards: Mary worked backwards from her Ultimate End Result (Age 56) to her Current Reality (Age 51).
Structural Tension Mary's Structural Tension: Mary created a document showing the relationship between her Current Reality and her Intermediate End Result #1. Mary's Structural Tension Objectives: Mary created five Objectives she feels she needs to achieve to move from her Current Reality to her Intermediate End Result #1.

Bud (Age 55)

End Result Bud's Time Line. He selected the year his son, his youngest child, graduated from high school. This was 7 years in the future and also the time his daughter was scheduled to graduate from college. Bud's End Result He picked eight key parameters, not as many as most students pick.
