You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page.

item.title: Short Instructions-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. The Full Instructions are listed in the Sub Navigation panel on the right. You can always open one of them up if you want more help. There are also additional examples on the Examples page.

0) Introduction

Personality type is such a critical ingredient in career satisfaction because it helps people identify four of the most important features that make us who we are: how we get energy, take in information, make decisions and organize our world. And while every individual is certainly unique – we all have different genes, parents, backgrounds, etc. – people of the same personality type have a tremendous amount in common, especially with regards to what makes them satisfied and successful in their work.
If you want to watch a 7 minute video explaining the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator or a video where Don explains your Exercise via some examples, click on Step 0 - Introduction in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

1) Take the Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory assessments

To understand how to access the appropriate Web site go to Step 1 - Take the Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory assessments. You will only be using the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report in this exercise. Casey's report is: Casey's Myers-Briggs Report

2) Create the "Do What You Are" report.

To understand how to access the appropriate Web site go to Step 2 - Create the "Do What You Are" report. Casey's example is: Casey's "Do What You Are" Report

3) Create your Personality Insights

Create a Personality Insights document using information from your “Do What You Are” report. The Insights document should mirror the sections in the Do What You Are document.
Casey's example is: Casey's Personality Insights.
Personality Insights Word template This is a Word file with the outline for the Personality Insights document.

4) Perform a Self Assessment of your Myers-Briggs Type.

To perform this self assessment use this MBTI Self Assessment template This is an Excel file with four pages - one for each of the four elements in the Meyers-Briggs Type (e.g. Extroversion vs. Introversion). There are nine characteristics for each element and you place an X next to the ones you feel represent you.
Casey's example is: Casey's Meyers-Briggs Self Assessment

5) Validate your Meyers-Briggs Type.

Look at the two types of insights you gained in the previous Step: Self-Assessment Worksheet and Outside Feedback. Now create a document where you provide your logic for what your “true” personality type should be.
Casey's example is: Casey's Validated MBTI
There is no template for this step.

6) Careers Insights.

You have now validated your Myers-Briggs Type, e.g. Casey decided she was an ENFJ, even though her self assessment said she was an ENFP. So the next step is to analyze what that means from a career viewpoint. To do that you will use your “Do What You Are” report. It has sections that provide you information about: What you need in a career for it to be satisfying; Some satisfying career fields and jobs for your Myers-Briggs type (examples of careers many people of your Type find satisfying) and How to use your personality type strengths to conduct a successful job search.
Casey's example is: Casey's Career Insights
Career Insights Word template

7) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples below.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

8) Discuss your Results with Your Adviser.

Discuss the output of Steps 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 & 7 above.

9) Provide your Feedback

Click on Feedback to access the SurveyMonkey survey.
10) Become an Example. Send Don your completed exercises.

11) Summary

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Personality Type Concept

Discover Your Personality Type Video

Click on the link above to watch a 7 minute video explaining the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. The video was created by PersonalityDesk, the people from whom you will take the Myers-Briggs assessment. If you feel you already know what the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator is you don't need to watch this video.
Personality type is such a critical ingredient in career satisfaction because it helps people identify four of the most important features that make us who we are: how we get energy, take in information, make decisions and organize our world. And while every individual is certainly unique – we all have different genes, parents, backgrounds, etc. – people of the same personality type have a tremendous amount in common, especially with regards to what makes them satisfied and successful in their work. Quite simply, when we using our natural, inborn personality type preferences – our gifts – (yes, you are born with a type!), people feel energized, motivated and satisfied. Conversely, when we are doing tasks that are not natural to us, it drains our energy and we are less successful. The only factor that remains constant over the entire course of a person’s lifetime is their Personality Type.

Exercise

Welcome to the Personality Exercise

Click on the link above to see a video where Don explains your Exercise via some examples. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.
In this exercise you need to: 1) Take the Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory assessments, 2) Create the "Do What You Are" report, 3) Create your Myers-Briggs Type Insights, 4) Perform a Self Assessment of your Myers-Briggs Type, 5) Validate your Meyers-Briggs Type, 6) "Do What You Are" Analysis & Insights, 7) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 8 Provide feedback, 9) Discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 10) Become an example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total the first seven steps will probably take you about 4 hours.

item.title: Templates-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

On this page are two types of templates you can use. At the top are templates for your analysis and insights. At the bottom of the page is the Autobiography Checklist which allows you to keep track of the status of the sub-exercises in the Exercise.

Analysis/Insights Templates

Personality Insights: Personality Insights Word template This is a Word file with the outline for the Personality Insights document. If you look at the Edward or Casey examples you will see they basically used this same outline.
MBTI Self Assessment: MBTI Self Assessment template This is an Excel file with four pages - one for each of the four elements in the Meyers-Briggs Type (e.g. Extroversion vs. Introversion). There are nine characteristics for each element and you place an X next to the ones you feel represent you.
Validate Meyers-Briggs Type: There is no template for this document.
Career Insights: Career Insights Word template This is a Word file with the outline for the Career Insights document. If you look at Edward or Casey's examples you will see they basically used this same outline.

Checklist Template

If you click on Personality Checklist Template you will be able to down the Excel file that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in this exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. Both of you can get the file from this Templates page.

File Naming

You should save any file you down load on your computer. Then create another copy with your name appended on the front of that file. You can then fill in your own information in that new file. If you someway screw up that file you can download the template again and not overwrite the one with your data. This way you may be able to copy some of your data from your partly damaged file to the new template.

item.title: Adviser Guidance-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You should watch the Welcome to Personality Exercise video at the minimum. It will give you the basic idea for this exercise and it is less than 5 minutes long.

Introduction

Here are some basic ideas you should keep in mind as they do this exercise:

Take the Assessments

They should be able to do this on their own. While they will get two reports, they will only use one (Myers-Briggs Type Indicate Career Report) for this exercise. Click on Casey's Myers-Briggs Report to see an example, she is an ENFJ. If you have not taken a Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Assessment you may want to watch this 7 minute video which explains it Discover Your Personality Type Video

"Do What You Are" Report

They should also be able to do this without any assistance and receive the report. Click on Casey's "Do What You Are" Report to see an example. The “Do What You Are” Report provides a better analysis of the career aspects of their Meyers-Briggs Type than the Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report they obtained in Step 1. But the “Do What You Are” Report requires them to enter Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator, e.g. ENFJ, they discovered in Step 1.

Personality Insights

They will be analyzing the personality description from the "Do What You Are" Report (which is based on their Meyers-Briggs Type, e.g. ENFJ). This will probably be the first time they have done any formal analysis of their personality. See if it matches your assessment of their personality. Click on Casey's Personality Insights to see an example.

Self Assessment

You should provide them with a reality-check on their personality, ENFJ. If you know them well enough to believe they are off base on one of the four preferences then have that discussion with them now. If you don't know them that well encourage them to seek input from peers, employers, coaches, relatives, etc. Click on Casey's Myers-Briggs Self Assessment to see an example. They may be projecting how they want to be, not how they really are. For example on the preference of "How you make decisions": Thinkers vs. Feelers they may have assessed themselves as a Feeler, while the Meyers-Briggs assessment tool categorized them as a Thinker. They may see themselves as a Feeler because they want to be in jobs that require diplomacy and they know they can take other people's feelings into account when making decisions. But you and others may know them well enough to see their most natural decision making approach is to make decisions objectively through rational arguments. It is not that they can't be diplomatic and won't take other people's feelings into account, it just isn't their first approach.

Validate Meyers-Briggs Type

So now they have to take the official Myers-Briggs Personality Type, their Self Assessment, your input, their peers/family input and come up with what they believe is their true personality type. This is an extremely important decision for them because their personality will not change and will have a huge impact on their success and happiness in their career. Make sure they have made a wise choice. This could be real easy because every assessment points to the same personality, e.g. ENFJ. Click on Casey's Validated Myers-Briggs Type to see an example.

Career Insights

See if the careers and jobs they picked from the lists provided make sense to you. Click on Casey's Career Insights to see an example. Remind them they will have a chance to revisit career insights in the next Exercise. Here they combine their Myers-Briggs Type Indicator, e.g. ENFJ, with the Interests they previously identified when they took the Strong Interest Inventory Assessment. These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. They will be accumulating their insights about that circle as they finish each exercise. This makes it easier for them to draw conclusions during the Capstone Project - which is probably quite a few weeks away. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached. Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights From the Personality exercise they should get some great insights for the "Be Your Best" file because they will have identified their natural personality. They will also be receiving their first direct recommendations that can be used in the "Right Careers" file.

Experienced Adult Examples

Below are two examples of that can help you understand this Exercise. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right.

Bud - INTJ

I (Introversion) - Clarity is Moderate: I focus on the inner world of ideas and impressions N (Intuition) - Clarity is Clear: I take in information from patterns and the big picture and focus on future possibilities T (Thinking) - Clarity is Moderate, almost Clear: I make decisions based on logic and on objective analysis of cause and effect J (Judging) - Clarity is Very Clear: I like a planned and organized approach, plus I want to have things settled Bud's Myers-Briggs Report Bud's "Do What You Are" Report Bud's Personality Insights Bud's Myers-Briggs Self Assessment Bud's Career Insights

Matt - ENTJ

E (Extraversion) - Clarity is Very Clear: I focus on the outer world of people and activity N (Intuition) - Clarity is Moderate: I take in information from patterns and the big picture and focus on future possibilities T (Thinking) - Clarity is Slight: I make decisions based on logic and on objective analysis of cause and effect J (Judging) - Clarity is Slight: I like a planned and organized approach, plus I want to have things settled Matt's Myers-Briggs Report Matt's "Do What You Are" Report Matt's Personality Insights

Optional Personal Usage

To get started using the MyRightCareer System for your own career click on the “Experienced Adult” heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:
  • Look at an example close to your students profile. That will give you a good idea of what your student's final output should resemble.
  • See if your student needs any help while they are completing the exercise. You may be able to help them.
  • Check to see their progress via the Exercise Checklist. If they don't already have it you should suggest it as a good tool for communicating their status.
  • Once they complete this exercise, review it and then have your dialogue
  • Provide me feedback on any insights you have on the student and the Program, as well as any insights on your Adviser role.
    Optionally you can:
  • Look at an Experienced Adult Example closer to your situation - they are on the Examples page.
  • Complete the exercise for your situation. click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right

Feedback

We would like your feed back on the Exercise. We would also like your feedback on the Adviser role, your interaction with your student and the support we are providing you. We would like you to take the SurveyMonkey survey in this section after you finish your work with your student. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. You can also provide feedback by sending Don an email (Don@My-Right-Career.com) or calling him at 650-400-8929.

item.title: Step 1 - Take Assessments-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You are going to take two assessments during this Step: - Myers-Briggs Type Indicator - Strong Interest Inventory We will only be using the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator assessment output during the Personality exercise. You are taking them at the same time because the assessment Web site we are using combines the results of the two assessments and we will see that combination in the Interests exercise.

Assessment Access - Your Career Center

Once the system reaches Beta Test the students will have to take all their Assessments (i.e. Myers-Briggs, Do What You Are, Strong Interest Inventory and StrengthsFinder 2.0) through their Career Center (sometimes called a Career Development Center or Career Services). During this Alpha Test we want to test how well this works by having you go to your Career Center for these Assessments. For this exercise we would like you to see if your Career Center offers the combined Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory Assessment. If so please take it through the Career Center and then use the output to finish this exercise (Personality) and the next exercise (Interests). If they don't offer the combined Assessment, but do offer each of them independently go ahead and take them in that format. Again use the output of each assessment to finish this exercise (Personality) and the next exercise (Interests).

Assessment Access - No Career Center Support

If your Career Center does not support either of the above asseessments (a very unlikely event since they are long time career planning tools) you will have to pay to take them via a 3rd party provider. The combined Myers-Brigss and Strong Interest Inventory Assessment is $99. In that case you need to tell Don you were not able to take the assessments through your Career Center and some of the reasons why not. We would like to understand the problems of taking these assessments via the student's Career Center. Don will then email you the $99. Below is a link to the Personalitydesk Web site where you can purchase the Myers-Briggs and Strong Interest Inventory assessments.

Personalitydesk Web site - Combined Assessment

You want to select the "Standard" version, not the "College" version. Personalitydesk will email you a Login and Password, plus the link to the SkillsOne Web site where you will take the combined assessments. When you login with your Login and Password you will notice there is also a User ID field. Leave it blank on your first login. A User ID will be generated and e-mailed to you after you begin your assessment. It can be used to access your reports later. Once logged in, you will see a list of several assessments. Please complete only the MBTI Step I (Form M) and the Strong Interest Inventory. Please enter a valid email on the testing site so that PersonalityDesk may contact you. If you have any difficulty accessing your assessment, please e-mail them at service@personalitydesk.com and reference the Order Number your received in the email that contained your Login and Password. Each assessment takes about 30 minutes so ensure you have an hour to complete them.

Web site Output

Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report

Your report will be emailed to you within 12 hours of completing the assessment during normal business hours in the U.S. After 9:00 p.m. Eastern Time your report will be emailed the next morning. Reports are emailed once a day on the weekends. The file comes with a long string of numbers as its name, we suggest you change the name to: YourName-Myers-Briggs_Report.pdf. You will use this report in this Personality exercise. Below is an example: Casey-Myers-Briggs_Report - The only part of this report you will be using in this Personality exercise is Summary of Your MBTI® Results, which is page 3 of the report. Print out this page because you will use it in the later steps. Below are two examples of page 3: Casey's Summary of Your Myers-Briggs Results (Page 3) Edward's Summary of Your Myers-Briggs Results (Page 3) Study the two sections of page 3 (Summary of Your Myers-Briggs Results):

Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Examples

For each of the four preferences read and understand which one of the Myers-Briggs assessment indicates your preference. Casey prefers to "Make Decisions" by Feeling, i.e. based primarily on values and subjective evaluations of people-centered concerns. Edward prefers to "Make Decisions by Thinking, i.e. based primarily on logic and on objective analysis of cause and effect.
  • Casey - ENFJ E (Extraversion) - Clarity is Moderate: I focus on the outer world of people and activity N (Intuition) - Clarity is Slight: I take in information from patterns and the big picture and focus on future possibilities F (Feeling) - Clarity is Moderate: I make decisions based on vales and subjective evaluation of people-centered concerns J (Judging) - Clarity is Clear: I like a planned and organized approach, plus I want to have things settled
  • Edward - INTJ I (Introversion) - Clarity is Moderate: I focus on the inner world of ideas and impressions N (Intuition) - Clarity is Clear: I take in information from patterns and the big picture and focus on future possibilities T (Thinking) - Clarity is Moderate, almost Clear: I make decisions based on logic and on objective analysis of cause and effect J (Judging) - Clarity is Very Clear: I like a planned and organized approach, plus I want to have things settled
    Clarity of Report Preferences: For each of the four preferences look at how clear you were in expressing your preference for a particular pole over its opposite (i.e. your Clarity). A longer bar suggests you are quite sure about your preference, while a shorter bar suggests you are less sure about your preference. Casey and Edward both prefer to "Take in Information" from patterns and the big picture and focus on future, thus they are both Intuitives (N's). But Casey only has a Slight Clarity with a score of 3 out of 30. In contrast Edward has a Clear Clarity with a score of 19 out of 30. As you can see Casey's line is very short and Edward's line is quite long. It is very clear that Edward is an Intuitive, while Casey is not so clear.
    Meaning of Preference: The Myers-Briggs Type doesn't mean Casey doesn't ever make decisions based on logic and an objective analysis of cause and effect. It just means she will normally make decisions based values and subjective evaluations of people-centered concerns. That is her natural approach to decision making. Edward is the same way. He of course can make decisions based on values and subjective evaluations of people-centered concerns. But when faced with a decision his normal approach will be based on logic and on objective analysis of cause and effect. We all use both poles of the preferences.

    Strong Interest Inventory® and Myers-Briggs Type Indicator® Career Report

    Your report will be emailed to you within 12 hours of completing the assessment during normal business hours in the U.S. After 9:00 p.m. Eastern Time your report will be emailed the next morning. Reports are emailed once a day on the weekends. Along with the report an optional one-hour consultation session by phone or email is available. Instructions for receiving that consultation will be included in the email containing the report. If you want to take advantage of the optional one-hour consultation session you should wait until you start the Interests exercise. The file comes with a long string of numbers as its name, we suggest you change the name to: YourName-StrongMBTI_Report.pdf. You will use this report in the next exercise. Make sure you store this somewhere you can find it when needed in the next exercise. Below is an example: Casey-StrongMBTI_Report

item.title: Step 2 - "Do What You Are" Report-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

The "Do What You Are" Report provides a better analysis of the career aspects of your Meyers-Briggs Type than the Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report you obtained in Step 1. But the “Do What You Are” Report requires you to enter Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator, e.g. INTJ, you discovered in Step 1.

"Do What You Are" Report - Your Career Center

As was described in Step 1 when the system reaches Beta Test the students will have to take all their Assessments (i.e. Myers-Briggs, Do What You Are, Strong Interest Inventory and StrengthsFinder 2.0) through their Career Center. During this Alpha Test we want to test how well this works by having you go to your Career Center for these Assessments. For this exercise we would like you to see if your Career Center offers the "Do What You Are" Report. If so please obtain it through the Career Center and then use the Do What You Are report to finish this exercise (Personality). This report is based on the best selling book "Do What You Are". It is a perfect complement to the Myers-Briggs assessment. Your Career Center may not realize this and you could suggest they pay for you to get the "Do What You Are" report as a way for them to experiment (for only $29).

"Do What You Are" Report - No Center Support

If your Career Center does not provide the "Do What You Are" Report or will not experiment you will have to pay for it from the PersonalityType.com. In that case you need to tell Don you were not able to take the assessments through your Career Center and some of the reasons why not. We would like to understand the problems of taking these assessments via the student's Career Center. Don will then email you the $29.
You already know your MBTI Type, e.g. INTJ, from your Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report so you can skip their simple personality assessment at the start of their Web site. Click on the link below and it will take you to their Web site:

Do What You Are

On the left side of the page you will find - The large heading "Know your type already?" - Under that heading will be "Select from the 16 Personality Types" - Next will be "Enter it here:" - Finally there is a pop up menu box with the 16 Personality Types. You need to find yours, e.g INTJ, and click on it. Then you will be taken to a page where - you will have to fill in your name and email address. - You will then be asked to pay for the report ($29). - You will have the chance to create a user name and password. - You will then be taken to a library where you can download the 15 page "Do What You Are" report like the ones shown for Casey and Edward below.

"Do What You Are" Report Explanation

Casey's "Do What You Are" Report - ENFJ
Edward's "Do What You Are" Report - Marketed - INTJ This report is highlighted to show the items Edward thought applied quite well to his life and career. You may want to do the same with your copy of your "Do What You Are" Report.
The "Do What You Are" report takes your Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator (e.g. INTJ) and uses it to receive a very insightful analysis of your potential career (s). The assessment is provided by an organization called PersonalityType.com. Their tag line is “Discover your perfect career”. The content comes from the very successful book “Do What You Are”, one of my favorite books that I just rediscovered. I am amazed at how insightful their assessment was for me. My feedback on what they provide comes from a 40 year career so I can judge whether their assessment is really accurate (at least for me). The assessment tool provides: General Description: I found it much better than the one provided by the Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report. It provides the description in a more conversational manner. I felt it was describing me. Strengths and Weaknesses: I was amazed how “right on” this assessment was (for me). For both the strengths and weaknesses they have you choose 5 from a list of 13. The lists were very relevant and the five strengths and weaknesses really were the ones I have experienced during my career. I could see how much my personality had driven my career. Career Satisfiers: In this case they also ask you to pick five from a list of 10. All ten were ones I found relevant and I could easily narrow it down to five very important items that I found made jobs satisfying to me (and ones that made jobs miserable). Satisfying Career Fields and Jobs: There were a large number that I could have gone into and several I did go into. Using your personality strengths to conduct a successful job search: These were insights that I had discovered the hard way, through trial and error over many years. The Secret to Success: It provided three insights that I wished I had known when I was starting my career. They were so true it was amazing.

item.title: Step 4 - Perform Personality Self Assessment
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Although the Myers-Briggs Type assessment is one of the most reliable self-report personality instruments available, no inventory is perfect. You may not feel entirely comfortable that your reported type, e.g. ENFJ, accurately describes you. The insights you gained in Step 3 from analyzing either of the two reports may have confirmed that for you.
  • Summary of your Myers-Briggs Type Results: Casey's Myers-Briggs Summary (page 3)
  • "Do What Your Are" General Description: Casey's "Do What You Are" Description
    In Step 3 you created your personality insights document, for example Casey's Personality Insights. In it you provided your insights of the personality the Myers-Briggs Type assessment tool had assigned to you and the "Do What You Are" document had described.

    Assignment

    Even if you are comfortable with the type, e.g. ENFJ, you received from your Myers-Briggs Type assessment you should perform a self assessment. You can do this in two steps.

    Self-Assessment Worksheet

    Here are two examples of using the Self-Assessment Worksheet:
  • Casey's Myers-Briggs Self Assessment
  • Edward's Myers-Briggs Self Assessment
    These have been created with an Excel file that has four pages - one for each of the four Preference pairs in the Myers-Briggs Type (e.g. Extroversion vs. Introversion). To perform this self assessment use this template. Self Assessment Excel template There are nine characteristics for each Preference pair and you place an X next to the characteristics you feel represent you. The Excel spreadsheet adds up the number of X's in each column. This makes it easy to see which of the two preferences you choose most often. For example in Casey's "What kind of environment makes you most comfortable?" section she has 3 X's for "Judgers often" and 6 X's for "Perceivers often" She then placed a red X in the box next to Perceiver as her personal assessment of that Preference pair. On the fourth page her self assessment was an ENFP. Her official Myers-Briggs Type is an ENFJ so they don't match on the fourth preference "What kind of environment makes you most comfortable?" Her self assessment is she is a Perceiver (P) and her official Myers-Briggs Type is she is a Judger (J).
    Make sure you create a "Do What You Are" report for your final Meyers-Briggs Type.

    Feedback from Others

    Pick a friend from your high school days, one from college and a member of your family. Send them your Myers-Briggs Type Results report Casey's Myers-Briggs Summary (page 3), but tell them they only need to look at page 3, the Summary page. Ask them if they agree with your preferences on the four areas. They may want to look at your clarity scores if the disagree on one of them because they may see you have Slight clarity and that is why they see you differently than you see yourself.
    Also send them a copy of your "Do What You Are" report Casey's "Do What You Are" Report"target="_blank">Casey's "Do What You Are" Description and ask them if they think the first three sections (General Description, Strengths and Weaknesses) are an accurate description of your personality. This report does a good job of putting your Myers-Briggs Type into everyday terms. Tell them they don't need to read the rest of the report.
    You have now performed a self-assessment and that leads you to the next step.

item.title: Step 5 - Validate Myers-Briggs Type-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You are being asked to spend so much time validating your Myers-Briggs Type because understanding your true personality is one of the most important predictors of a successful career. Doing things that fit with your natural personality will make you much more successful than trying to work against the grain. As was stated earlier your personality type is the only thing that stays constant through out your adult life. It is important to identify your true personality type right now. By completing Step 4 you now have a Self Assessment of your Myers-Briggs Type. Hopefully it matches the MBTI that came from the Web based assessment you received. But you could still be questioning your personality type. It may help to recall what you were thinking or experiencing when you took that Web based assessment. Your results reflect how you "voted" when asked to choose between opposites. What led you to respond as you did? Perhaps, instead of describing yourself as you really are, you were thinking about how someone else wants you to be, or about how you would ideally like to be. Or maybe you were thinking about a career that you wanted and so responded as you thought someone in that field might. Maybe you were getting ready for a major test and were in a hurry. As you go through the process of discovering your "true" personality type, remember everyone uses all of the eight preferences at different times. Also realize there are individual differences within each type, e.g. INTJ. No one description will fully capture your uniqueness. You are trying to discover which is more natural, which comes easier. That is going to be your true preference. In the end of the Do What You Are document there is a section called The Secret to Success. The first sentence says "Understand that using your strengths is easy". Here are two examples from Don to illustrate the concept of natural and easy.
1) It has always been easy for me to make decisions based on an objective analysis of the situation and logic. People are always impressed by this, but it is not really a skill, rather a part of my personality. My preference is Thinking (T).
2) Taking a planned and organized approach requires no work for me, unlike it does for others. It is second nature because I am obviously wired to take that approach. My preference is Judging (J)
Richard Branson, the founder/CEO, of Virgin preference is clearly Extroversion. For him to work a crowd is fun and natural. For me that would not be natural, my preference is Introversion. When I am thoroughly prepared and speaking about a subject I know well I feel comfortable in front of a group. So you can use both of your perspectives. But I am more like a Professor, nothing like Richard Branson.

Assignment

Examine your Insights

Look at the two types of insights you gained in the previous Step.
  • Self-Assessment Worksheet See Casey's Myers-Briggs Self Assessment as an example.
  • Outside Feedback Analyze what your friends and family told you about your personality. Do they basically agree with your "Do What You Are" report? If they know the Myers-Briggs Type terminology do they agree with your Type?

    Document your "true" Personality Type

    Now create a document where you provide your logic for what your "true" personality type should be. Here are two examples:
  • Casey's Validated Personality Type She had a conflict between her self assessment and her formal Myers-Briggs assessment. See how she resolved that conflict.
  • Edward's Validated Myers-Briggs Type His two assessment were aligned.

item.title: Look at Self
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This assignment has two exercises.

  • Personality

    To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. In this exercise you will take your Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator to produce a "Do What You Are" assessment. This will help you understand your personality and the occupations most suited to that personality.

  • Interests

    To see the detail for this exercise click on its name in the Sub Navigation section on the right. This exercise combines two assessments:
    Strong Interest Inventory: The Strong Interest Inventory has been around for over 70 years and helps you see what types of careers and occupations might interest you.
    Strong/Myers-Briggs Career Report: Your combined results on the Strong and MBTI tools are based on two simple assumptions— 1) that you are most likely to be satisfied and productive if you are working at something that interests you (the Strong Interest Inventory) and 2) if that something also fits your personality (your Myers-Briggs Type).

item.title: Step 7 - Add to MyRightCareer Insights-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: You have now learned a lot about your personality and the situations where you can thrive. Add insights you have gained to this file. You should be able to find a lot of insights, just like Casey did. - Meaning & Passion: Are there areas where you personality and your passion intersect? Casey found a lot of these. It is very normal for you to find meaning and have passion for things are a good fit with your personality. - Fuel your Economic Engine: Do you see how you can leverage your personality to fuel you economic engine. - Right Opportunities: What careers and jobs did you identify? You should have found some in the Do What You Are report. - Whole Person: What types of environments most interest you. Your personality will not fit well in every situation - work or outside of work.

item.title: Step 9 - Provide Feedback-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We making changes to the MyRightCareer Program and Web site in almost real time so your timely feedback is very important. Students coming after you will benefit from it.
Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. Once you are finished with the Survey please send Don an email at Don@My-Right-Career.com.
Click here to take survey

item.title: Step 8 - Discuss with your Adviser-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Now it is time to discuss your results with your Adviser. You may have been communicating with them along the way so they may already know some of what you have done, e.g. you might have shared your Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator report. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

A) Discuss Content Issues

Your Personality Type, e.g. Casey is ENFJ

E (Extraversion) - Clarity is Moderate: I focus on the outer world of people and activity N (Intuition) - Clarity is Slight: I take in information from patterns and the big picture and focus on future possibilities F (Feeling) - Clarity is Moderate: I make decisions based on vales and subjective evaluation of people-centered concerns J (Judging) - Clarity is Clear: I like a planned and organized approach, plus I want to have things settled Casey's Myers-Briggs Report Casey's "Do What You Are" Report

Your Insights

  • Casey's Personality Insights You may want to share some highlights from this document
  • Casey's Career Insights This is the bottom line document, i.e. what careers and jobs are a good fit for your personality. Make sure you discuss this.
  • MyRightCareer Insights documents: These are the most important documents you will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. These documents must be discussed. Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

    B) Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
  • Schedule: You have now done two exercises and you should have some feel for a realistic exercise schedule by now.
  • Adviser Review Process: Most likely you have now settled into a process that works for the two of you, e.g. how you communicate, how you review.
  • Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing these exercises.

item.title: Step 10 - Become an Example-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the same process we used in the previous exercise.

1) Send your completed exercises to Don

Send all of your completed material for this exercise to Don@My-Right-Career.com: Myers-Briggs Type Indicator® Career Report, "Do What You Are" Report, Personality Insights, Personality Self Assessment (Excel Spreadsheet) and your Insights. He will review it and remove anything he feels would disclose your personal identity, e.g. names of friends, high school name, college name. He will conform the file names, headings, etc to the standards used on all the other examples (if you used the templates this will not require much work). He will append your "stage name" to the front of all of the files.

2) Review and comment on Don's Exercise files

Don will send you the proposed exercise files. You should review them and suggest any changes you would like made, e.g. drop this information, reword this information.

3) Don will load your Example on Examples page

He will add these examples to your section on the Examples page. Individual pieces of your example may be integrated into the Full Instructions. As Don gets more examples he will use examples he feels do a good job explaining key ideas. Your example may be used on Exercise #2 and then not again until Exercise #4 and #5.

item.title: Step 6 - Career Insights-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have now validated your Myers-Briggs Type, e.g. Casey decided she was an ENFJ, even though her self assessment said she was an ENFP. So the next step is to analyze what that means from a career viewpoint. To do that you will use your "Do What You Are" report. It has sections that provide you information about:
  • What you need in a career for it to be satisfying
  • Some satisfying career fields and jobs for your Myers-Briggs type (examples of careers many people of your Type find satisfying)
  • How to use your personality type strengths to conduct a successful job search.

    Assignment

    Your assignment is to create a Career Insight document. Here are two examples:
  • Casey's Career Insights
  • Edward's Validated Myers-Briggs Type
    If you follow their format you will be able to directly use the information from the "Do What You Are" report.
    If you want to use their format then down load this template. Career Insights Word template This is a Word file with the outline for the Career Insights document.

item.title: Step 3 - Personality Insights
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You now have two descriptions of your personality:
  • Summary of your MBTI Results (page 3): Click on Casey's Myers-Briggs Summary to see an example. This provides you with your Type, for example Casey is an ENFJ. It also provides a Clarity score for each of the Preferences, e.g. Casey is Moderate on the Extraversion scale.
  • Do What You Are: Click on Casey's "Do What You Are" Description to see an example. This provides a more layman's description of your Personality and your Strengths/Weaknesses, still using your Myers-Briggs Type.

Assignment

Create a Personality Insights document using information from your "Do What You Are" report. The Insights document will have the following sections, which mirror the sections in the Do What You Are document. Take a look at Casey's Personality Insights. It follows the outline below.
  • General Description: She took several of the sentences, shown in quotes, from the general description and provided examples from her life to show this statement was accurate. For example:“Maintaining harmony relationships is a lifelong goal and a natural skill” a. I feel like this pertains to me because I have maintained relationships with my friends who I have known since I was five. I also tend to make sure that my friendships with them are going well because I truly value friends as part of my life. b. As I get older and become an adult, it has become apparent that my new friendships I have formed at college also need to remain harmonious, as well as my relationships with members of my family.
  • Work Related Strengths: She picked some of her top Strengths and did the same thing - provided examples from her life to show this strength was accurate. For example:"Enthusiasm and ability to enlist cooperation from others" a. I always have a lot of passion for things I care about and people like to feed off my energy. b. This will be helpful in the workplace because I will be able to get people motivated to be the best they can be. This will help the company do better overall and will improve the work environment positively. c. I am able to make people excited about doing things.
  • Work Related Weaknesses: She picked some of her top Weaknesses and did the same thing - provided examples from her life to show this weakness was accurate. For example:"Avoidance of conflict and tendency to ignore unpleasantness" a. I have a problem where I don’t like to confront people because I truly cherish harmonious relationships. b. In the work place, I need to make sure I confront people who do not respect me in order to be productive and respected at work. c. I also need to confront people who are not carrying their weight on projects or doing quality work
  • The Secret to Success: She took the two sub sections of this and addressed them. 1) Understand that using your strengths is easy. 2) The real secret to success for an ENFJ is learning to: Slow Down: Relinquish some control: Take things less personally Another Example: For another example take a look at Edward's Personality Insights

    Introvert Insights

    Click on The Power of Introversion to see Susan Cain's TED talk (20 minutes). It has over 5 million views. Below is a short description: In a culture where being social and outgoing are prized above all else, it can be difficult, even shameful, to be an introvert. But, as Susan Cain argues in this passionate talk, introverts bring extraordinary talents and abilities to the world, and should be encouraged and celebrated. Our world prizes extroverts -- but Susan Cain makes a case for the quiet and contemplative If you are an Introvert, or an Extrovert who would like to understand the 1/3 to 1/2 the people in the world who are Introverts, you need to watch this video.

item.title: Step 6 - 1st Career Advisory Board Meeting
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Now is time to discuss the results of your first three Assignments: Begin at the End, Look at Self (Personality and Interests) and Look at the Past (Autobiography and Accomplishments), with your Career Advisory Board.
You should proceed with the next exercise while you are having discussions with your Career Advisory Board members. Due to schedule conflicts it could take several weeks to complete this step and you can be working on the next exercise in parallel.

Your Key Exercise Output

For the Board Members you know would like to have supporting detail to the MyRightCareer Insights you can send them files from each of your five exercises: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography and Accomplishments. Below are Casey's examples.

Begin at the End Assignment

  • Casey's End Result This includes her insights as well. Casey identified a possible career at Age 30, your student may not have identified one and that is more normal.
  • Casey's Structural Tension This includes her insights as well.

    Look at Self Assignment

  • Personality Exercise
    Share with the Board members you Myers-Briggs Type Indicator and the insights you drew from your personality. Casey's Myers-Briggs Report Casey's "Do What You Are" Report Casey's Career Insights
  • Interests Exercise
    Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Report Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights
  • Strong & Myers-Briggs Exercise
    Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Report Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights

    Look at the Past Assignment

  • Autobiography Exercise
    Casey's Autobiography If your Board members are very familiar with your life you can skip giving them this file. Casey's Autobiography Insights You may have integrated your insights into your Top Accomplishments file.
  • Accomplishments Exercise
    Casey's All Accomplishments List - Top Highlighted Casey's Accomplishments Insights You may have integrated your insights into your Top Accomplishments file.

    Discuss Your MyRightCareer Insights

    At the minimum you need to send them your five MyRightCareer Insights files from your last exercise (Accomplishments): Be Your Best, Meaning & Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career and Whole Person. You only need to send them the files from your Accomplishments exercise because they are cumulative files and include your insights from the Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography and Accomplishments exercises.
    For each area, e.g. Be Your Best, you should have a dialogue about what you have discovered about yourself relative to that element in the Right Career Venn diagram. You should also have a discussion about what you have learned about yourself as a Whole Person, the fifth file.
    Here are Casey's as an example:
    Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

    Discuss What is Next for your Career Advisory Board

    Inform them you will be asking for their help again after you finish the next three Assignments: Strengths (Talents/Strengths and Skills), Meaning (Stories, Drivers, How you will Measure Your Life) and Economic Engine (Age 30 & Age 22). Remind them your last review will take place after the Capstone Project, where you will have identified your Right Career (s), developed your Sales Story for that Right Career (s) and created a Follow-on Plan.

item.title: Step 11 - Summary-Personality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Each of us has a distinct personality that stays with us for life. We may change our behavior in certain situations because we wouldn't be able to function successfully if we didn't. But we don't change our natural personality. In the Right Career Concepts Overview and then again in the Welcome to the Personality Exercise video we saw the difference between the lady who is an Extravert Feeler and the Director of Public Relations and the man who is an Intravert Thinker and the Director of Financial Planning and Analysis. They work for the same small company and are good friends. The Director of Public Relations is an Extravert who prefers being around people a lot, a public role and thinking out loud; who has high energy and is outgoing and enthusiastic. As a Feeler she is warm and friendly, diplomatic and tactful and quick to complement others. Her role requires her to be in front of people or on the phone with people all the time. The Director of Financial Planning & Analysis is an Intravert who feels comfortable being alone, working "behind-the-scenes" and thinking quietly inside his head; who has quiet energy and is self-contained and reserved. His role requires him to do sophisticated financial analysis and provide business advice to the CFO and CEO. By leveraging their natural personalities they are both very successful in their jobs and both are very happy in their jobs. The Director of Financial Planning and Analysis would like to be the CFO of a small company and take the company public. Most likely he will have to be the Investor Relations person for the company until it gets big enough to hire one. This is something he can do - it requires him to switch from Intravert to Extravert - but not something he prefers to do. He is most natural at working inside his head doing financial things. The Director of Public Relations would like to be the VP of Marketing at a small company. In that role she knows she will have to create budgets and do a lot more financial work. She can do this - switch from Feeling to Thinking - it is just not her preferred method of operating. Luckily for both of them, as they advance to their higher level roles, they don't have to operate outside of their natural personalities for very much of their time. By staying in roles that leverage their natural personalities they will continue to be successful and happy. As you saw there are a lot of different careers/jobs that people who share your personality type find satisfying. Casey, who is an ENFJ, was able to pick out 10 careers/jobs she liked and 5 she didn't like. Don, who is an INTJ, was also able to pick out 10 career/jobs he liked and 5 he didn't like. This exercise provides you with the first direct input on careers/jobs the could be your Right Career (s). It is a great starting point because you now have one piece of the Venn diagram - the Be Your Best circle - and one element of the circle - your natural personality. You should now know how your natural personality affects your choice of the Right Career. You still need to take into account some other factors:
  • Interest: Are you really interested in that Career/Job? The next Assignment (Interests) should provide some more insights on this subject.
  • Strengths/Skills: Do you have the natural strengths/skills to do well in that particular Career/Job? Maybe you are an INTJ, which is a good personality for a CFO, but you are not very good at financial analysis. The Strengths/Skills Assignment will help you understand this better.
  • Meaning/Passion: Does this Career/Job provide you with meaning and therefore evoke passion? You will explore that in the Meaning/Passion Assignment.
  • Economic Engine: Does this Career/Job provide you with enough income (fuel) to support the life style (engine) you feel you need.
    The bottom line is your personality is not going to change as you go through life so don't pick a career that doesn't leverage your personality. You can think of it as a way of eliminating careers as well as a way of picking careers. While you may have to take jobs from time to time that work against the grain of your personality in the long run you won't be happy or successful trying to be someone you aren't.

item.title: Examples-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Below are examples from this Exercise: College Students, Recent Graduates and Experienced Adults. At the bottom of the page is a checklist to keep track of the status of the Steps in the Exercise. At the bottom of the page is the Checklist which allows you to keep track of the status of the sub-exercises in the Exercise.

College Students

Casey - End Sophomore Year

Strong Interest Inventory: Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Report (pages 1 - 9) Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Insights Strong & Myers-Briggs: Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Report Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights MyRightCareer Insights There are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Career" and one for "Whole Person". This exercise has added a set of insights to each file. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story. These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises except Economic Engine: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories and Drivers. From these examples you can see how she has added insights with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents. Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Edward - End Junior Year

Strong Interest Inventory: Edward's Strong Interest Inventory Report Edward's Strong Interest Inventory Insights O*NET: Edward's O*NET Interest Scores (GOT Score x 50%) Edward's Career List Chief Executives Financial - Treasurers and Controllers Lawyers Strong and Myers-Briggs: Edward's Strong & Myers-Briggs Report Edward's Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights MyRightCareer Insights TThese five documents are examples of the insights Edward obtained from completing all the exercises except Economic Engine: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories and Drivers. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
