item.title: Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

In this exercise you need to: 1) Review your Strong Interest Inventory report & create an Insights document, 2) Review your Strong/Myers-Briggs report & create your Insights document, 3) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss the exercise with your Facilitator and 6) Become an example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total the first four steps will probably take you about 4 hours. Note: If you are an experienced adult, instead of a student, visit the "Experienced Adult" page before beginning this exercise. If you click on Interests Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page. There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically listening to a 5 minute video and using examples to do your work.

click on Full Instructions

If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the same 5 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

item.title: Short Instructions-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine.

0) Introduction

If you need an introduction to the Strong Interest Inventory and how it generates personalized career suggestions or a video where Don explains your Exercise via some examples, click on Step 0 - Introduction in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

1) Review your Strong Interest Inventory report & create an Insights document

Casey's example is: Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Report (pages 1 - 9) Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Insights For the template click on Strong Interest Inventory Insights Word template This is a Word file with the outline for the Insights document. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 1 - Strong Interest Inventory" in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

2) Review your Strong & Myers-Briggs report & create your Insights document

Casey's example is: Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Report Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights For the template click on Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights Word template This is a Word file with the outline for the Insights document. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 2 - Strong & Myers-Briggs" in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

3) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights

Document the insights you have gained from this exercise. These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises except Economic Engine: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories and Drivers. From these examples you can see how she has added insights with every exercise. You are only adding your insights for this exercise. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights
Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples above. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 3 - Add to your MyRightCareer Insights" in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

4) Discuss your Results with Your Facilitator.

Discuss the output of Steps 1, 2, 3 & 4 above. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 4 - Discuss your Results with Your Facilitator" in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

5) Provide your Feedback.

Click on Student Feedback to access the SurveyMonkey survey for a student.

6) Become an Example.

Send Don your completed exercises. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 6 - Become an Example" in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

Step 7 - Summary

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Strong Interests Inventory Concept

Strong Interests Inventory

Click on the link above to watch a brief (2 minute) PowerPoint introduction to the Strong Interest Inventory and to how it generates personalized career suggestions. There is no audio associated with this video. If you already understand the Strong Interests Inventory you can skip the video.
Used by more than 70 percent of U.S. colleges and universities, the Strong Interest Inventory® assessment is one of the world’s most widely respected and frequently used career planning tools. It helps high school and college students — as well as people in transition — make fulfilling career choices. By giving students insight into their interests, preferences, and personal styles, the Strong enables them to identify specific courses, jobs, internships, and activities they’re likely to enjoy.

Exercise

Welcome to the Interests Exercise

Click on the link above to see a video where Don explains your Exercise via some examples. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.
In this exercise you need to: 1) Review your Strong Interest Inventory report & create an Insights document, 2) Review your Strong/Myers-Briggs report & create your Insights document, 3) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 4) Provide feedback, 5) Discuss the exercise with your Adviser and 6) Become an example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total the first four steps will probably take you about 4 hours.

item.title: Templates-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

On this page are two types of templates you can use. At the top are templates for your analysis and insights. At the bottom of the page is the Interests Checklist which allows you to keep track of the status of the sub-exercises in the Exercise.

Analysis/Insights Templates

These are Word files with the outlines for the Insights documents. If you look at the Edward or Casey examples you will see they basically used these same outlines. Strong Interest Inventory Insights Word template Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights Word template

Checklist Template

If you click on Interests Checklist Template you will be able to down the Excel file that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in this exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. Both of you can get the file from this Templates page.

File Naming

You should save any file you down load on your computer. Then create another copy with your name appended on the front of that file. You can then fill in your own information in that new file. If you someway screw up that file you can download the template again and not overwrite the one with your data. This way you may be able to copy some of your data from your partly damaged file to the new template.

item.title: Adviser Guidance-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You should watch the Welcome to Interests Exercise video at the minimum. It will give you the basic idea for this exercise and it is less than 5 minutes long.

Introduction

Here are some basic ideas you should keep in mind as they do this exercise: Here are some basic ideas you should keep in mind as they do this exercise:

Strong Interest Inventory

Remind them that this report is just organizing and putting into categories what they told the assessment program interested them. A lot of what they will see may not necessarily really interest them when presented in that manner and that is OK. Get them to look for just a few good ideas. Encourage them to use O*NET. It currently includes 974 occupations which currently have, or are scheduled to have, data collected from job incumbents or occupation experts. Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Report (pages 1 - 9) Casey's Strong Interest Inventory Insights

Strong Interest Inventory & Myers-Briggs Type Indicator

Your combined results on the Strong and MBTI tools are based on the assumption that you are most likely to be satisfied and productive if you are working at something you enjoy in an environment that fits your personality. Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Report Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights

MyRightCareer Insights

These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. They will be accumulating their insights about that circle as they finish each exercise. This makes it easier for them to draw conclusions during the Capstone Project - which is probably quite a few weeks away. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached. From the Interests exercise they should get some great insights for the "Be Your Best" file because they will have identified their interests. They will also be receiving their 2nd direct recommendations that can be used in the "Right Careers" file. These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. They will be accumulating their insights about that circle as they finish each exercise. This makes it easier for them to draw conclusions during the Capstone Project - which is probably quite a few weeks away. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached. Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Experienced Adult Examples

Below are two examples that can help you understand the Exercise. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right. Strong Interest Inventory Some people don't find any of the output of this assessment match their Interests, yet the output comes from your answers to the Strong Interests Assessment so there must be a correlation. Matt's Strong Interest Inventory & Myers-Briggs Report Matt's Strong Interest Inventory Insights Bud's Strong Interest Inventory & Myers-Briggs Report Bud's Strong Interest Inventory Insights Strong Interest Inventory & Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Their combines your Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (e.g. ENFJ) with your interests from the Strong Interest Inventory. The combination provides some valuable career guidance. Matt's Strong Interest & Myers-Briggs Insights Bud's Strong Interest & Myers-Briggs Insights

Optional Usage by Adviser

To get started using the MyRightCareer System for your own career click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:
  • Look at an example close to your students profile. That will give you a good idea of what your student's final output should resemble.
  • See if your student needs any help while they are completing the exercise. You may be able to help them.
  • Check to see their progress via the Exercise Checklist. If they don't already have it you should suggest it as a good tool for communicating their status.
  • Once they complete this exercise, review it and then have your dialogue
  • Provide me feedback on any insights you have on the student and the Program, as well as any insights on your Adviser role.
Optionally you can:
  • Look at an Experienced Adult Example closer to your situation - they are on the Examples page.
  • Complete the exercise for your situation. click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right

Feedback

We would like your feed back on the Exercise. We would also like your feedback on the Adviser role, your interaction with your student and the support we are providing you. We would like you to take the SurveyMonkey survey in this section after you finish your work with your student. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. You can also provide feedback by sending Don an email (Don@My-Right-Career.com) or calling him at 650-400-8929.

item.title: Old College Profile
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have already taken this assessment and received the Strong Interest Inventory and Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report (with Strong Profile) Report. The middle part of this report is titled College Profile and it has 4 pages. Here is an example: Casey's College Profile Report.
This report will help you identify college courses and academic majors that allow you to express what is important to you.

Assignment

Take a look at the following areas:

  • Using your Themes

    • Your top three themes are listed in order of interest. For example Casey's top three themes are: - Enterprising (E): ACTIVE PERSUADERS - Enterprising students prefer to influence or lead others through selling the merits of ideas or products. - Social (S): EMPATHIC HELPERS - Social students prefer to take a helping or altruistic approach involving teaching, developing, or caring for others. - Artistic (A): CREATIVE COMMUNICATORS - Artistic students prefer to take a self-expressive or creative approach involving art/design, music, or writing. Each Theme describes an important aspect of your interests and personality. Use all three Themes to identify college courses and academic majors that allow you to express what is important to you. The majors listed within each Theme are examples of some of the many related academic areas worth exploring. For example Casey identified, under the Enterprising (E): ACTIVE PERSUADERS Theme, the following majors: Business Admin, Marketing and Public Relations.

  • Using your Basic Interest Scales

    • These scales indicate interests that are important to your overall lifestyle, both in school and out of school. Use your strongest basic interests to explore college courses, extracurricular activities, internships, and part-time jobs.
    The report shows you the five areas in which you showed the greatest interest (arranged in descending order of interest). Then for each area it provides examples of: Campus Organizations/Activities, Internships/Job settings and College Courses that match with those areas. For Casey her #1 Area was Marketing & Advertising (Marketing, researching and developing advertising campaigns for products and services). It then provided these examples: - Campus Organizations/Activities: Advertising Club, Business Student Organization - Internships/Job settings: Advertising company, Company Marketing Department - College Courses: Business Management, Communications and Marketing

  • Using your Occupational Scales

    • These scales identify jobs held by people with whom you share common interests, arranged in order of similarity of interests. Some occupations require specific training; however, many do not require a particular college major. Explore classes relevant to these occupations and consider related careers as well. For each occupation, e.g. Advertising Account Manager, the report provides: - Educational preparation, e.g. BA in liberal arts or business - College courses, e.g. Marketing, Advertising and Communications - Related Careers, e.g. Media Manager and Sales Manager

  • Using your Professional Styles Scales

    • Use your Personal Style Scales to identify the specific ways you prefer to approach whatever academic courses, majors, or jobs you undertake. The report takes each Personal Style and provides guidance for school related activities. As an example for Casey's Work Style which suggests "a preference for working closely or frequently with people rather than working alone" the report provides the following guidance: "You may prefer academic activities that focus on interpersonal interactions, such as study groups, group assignments and helping others, rather than studying and researching on your own."

  • Document any insights you have gained from this exercise

    • Casey documented her insights in a separate document, organized by the four areas above: Casey's College Profile Insights.

    Summary

    This should have given you some insights into which major to choose or if you have already chosen a major some validation of that choice. It should also provide additional guidance on related courses, campus organizations, internships, etc you can use to further your progress along your path to your Right Career.

    Take Your Next Step - Click Below

    Step 3 - Strong & Myers-Briggs

item.title: Step 2 - Strong & Myers-Briggs-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have already taken this assessment and received the Strong Interest Inventory and Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Career Report (with Strong Profile) Report. The last part of this report is titled Strong and MBTI Career Report. It has 13 pages. Here is an example: Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Report Your combined results on the Strong and MBTI tools are based on the same assumption—that you are most likely to be satisfied and productive if you are working at something you enjoy in an environment you find compatible.
  • The Strong Interest Inventory matches your interests with six types of work environments.
  • The Meyers-Briggs Type Indicator describes your personality type and matches it with types of work.

    Assignment

    Take a look at the following areas:

    Combined Strong Themes and MBTI Preference

    Review what happens when you take your strongest General Occupation Theme (e.g. Enterprising) and combine that with your MBTI.
  • Casey: ENTERPRISING + ENFJ = The Collaborative Persuaders
  • Edward: ENTERPRISING + INTJ = The Theoretical Persuaders

    Combined Personal Style & MBTI Preferences

    Review the results on the five Strong inventory scales that describe your personal style of working and learning, combined with the impact of your MBTI preferences.

    Career Fields suggested by your combined results

    Explore the career fields that reflect both General Occupational Theme (e.g. Enterprising) work environments suggested by your Strong results and O*NET™ job families that attract your MBTI type. One of the five Career Fields that Casey really liked was Public Relations. It is a O*NET job family that attracts ENFJ types (Casey's Myers-Briggs Type). She used the O*NET code (27-3031.00) for that Career Field at the O*NET Web site and this is what she found Casey's O*Net Public Relations Report Action Steps: Do you see a pattern in these occupations? Try highlighting any Knowledge, Skills or Abilities or words or phrases that particularly appeal to you. You will probably see some trends emerge.

    Occupations suggested by your combined results

    Review the occupations that were suggested by both your Strong and MBTI results, thus making it likely that you may find these occupations satisfying and enjoyable. Keep in mind that: 1) Your interests are similar to those of people working in these occupations who like their work 2) these occupations tend to attract people with your MBTI preferences who are satisfied with their job

    Additional Occupations to Explore

    The occupations in the previous step were suggested because they match both your Strong interests and your MBTI preferences. There are many other occupations that may also be a good fit for your combined results, or for just one of the instruments. Action Steps: Take a look at the Action Steps provided at the bottom of this section. They are customized to your Myers-Briggs Type.

    Good Match to Start Your Career

    The Strong Interest Inventory and Meyers-Briggs assessment can guide you to a career direction that is interesting and fulfilling. Be sure to consider entry positions that are a good fit for your Strong Theme and MBTI preferences. Look at the questions in the two boxes for some guidance on your first job.

    Document any insights you have gained from this exercise

    Casey documented her insights in a separate document, organized by the four areas above: Casey's Strong & Myers-Briggs Insights

    Summary

    When you are finished with this you will have insights that combine your interests and your personality with a focus on your personal style of working & learning and suggestions of career and occupations.These reports will help you understand how you can "Be Your Best" and give you some insights into what has "Meaning & Passion" for you.

item.title: Step 3 - Add to MyRightCareer Insights-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: You have now identified a lot of your interests, some of them are related to your natural personality and strengths. Add insights you have gained to this file. You should be able to find a lot of insights, just like Casey did. - Meaning & Passion: Are there areas where you interests and your passion intersect? Casey found a lot of these. It is very normal for you to find meaning and have passion for things that interest you. - Fuel your Economic Engine: Do you see how you can leverage your interests to fuel you economic engine. Do you see how your interests may cause you to require more fuel. - Right Opportunities: What careers and jobs did you identify? You should have found some in the Strong Interest Inventory report and some more in the Strong and Myers-Briggs report. - Whole Person: What types of environments most interest you. The Strong Theme & Myers-Briggs Type provides some good clues on your preferred work environment. The Strong Personal Style & Myers-Briggs Preferences provides insights on how you like to work.

item.title: Step 5- Provide Feedback-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We making changes to the MyRightCareer Program and Web site in almost real time so your timely feedback is very important. Students coming after you will benefit from it.
Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. Once you are finished with the Survey please send Don an email at Don@My-Right-Career.com.
Click here to take survey

item.title: Step 4 - Discuss with your Adviser-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Now it is time to discuss your results with your Adviser. You may have been communicating with them along the way so they may already know some of what you have done, e.g. you might have shared your Strong Interest Inventory report. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

Discuss Content Issues

  • Strong Interest Inventory Report & O*NET System: Share the key findings from the Strong Inventory Report and the key findings from the O*NET Interests exercise.
  • Strong Interest Inventory Insights: You should have a lot of ideas from both the Strong Interest Inventory report and the O*NET system.
  • Strong and Myers-Briggs Report: Share the key findings from the Strong and Myers-Briggs Report. You may want to highlight what you learned by combining Interests and Personality.
  • Strong and Myers-Briggs Insights: This should be a very useful discussion because it builds on what you learned about yourself in the Personality exercise.
  • MyRightCareer Insights documents:: These are the most important documents you will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. These documents must be discussed.

    Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
  • Schedule: You have now done three exercises and you should have a handle on the schedule by now.
  • Adviser Review Process: Most likely you have now settled into a process that works for the two of you, e.g. how you communicate, how you review.
  • Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing these exercises.

item.title: Step 6 - Become an Example-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the same process we used in the previous exercises.

A) Send your completed exercises to Don

Send all of your completed material for this exercise to Don: Strong Interest Inventory® and Myers-Briggs Type Indicator® Career Report, O*NET Career List, O*NET Interest Profiler: Score Report (you had to print this to a pdf when you took it), O*NET Interest Profiler: Career List, a career description that interests you (you can provide more than one) and your Insights document. He will review it and remove anything he feels would disclose your personal identity, e.g. names of friends, high school name, college name. He will conform the file names, headings, etc to the standards used on all the other examples (if you used the templates this will not require much work). He will append your "stage name" to the front of all of the files.

B) Review and comment on Don's Exercise files

Don will send you the proposed exercise files. You should review them and suggest any changes you would like made, e.g. drop this information, reword this information.

C) Don will load your Example on Examples page

He will add these examples to your section on the Examples page. Individual pieces of your example may be integrated into the Full Instructions. As Don gets more examples he will use examples he feels do a good job explaining key ideas. Your example may be used on Exercise #2 and then not again until Exercise #4 and #5.

item.title: Step 7 - Summary-Interests
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You looked at two different reports which each provided different insights into possible Right Careers.

Strong Interest Inventory

The Strong Interest Inventory® instrument is a powerful tool that can help you make satisfying decisions about your career and education. Understanding your Strong Interest Profile can help you identify a career focus and begin your career planning and exploration process. Keep in mind that the Strong measures interests, not skills or abilities, and that the results can help guide you toward rewarding careers, work activities, education programs, and leisure activities—all based on your interests.

Strong & Myers-Briggs

This report builds on what you have learned from prior interpretations of the Strong and MBTI tools. Your results on the Strong and MBTI tools are based on the same assumption—that you are most likely to be satisfied and productive if you are working at something you enjoy in an environment you find compatible.

item.title: Examples-Drivers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Below are examples from this Exercise: College Students, Recent Graduates and Experienced Adults.

Casey - End Sophomore Year

Top Drivers: Casey's Top Drivers List
Drivers Insights: Casey's Drivers Insights
MyRightCareer Insights There are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Career" and one for "Whole Person". This exercise has added a set of insights to each file. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.
MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. item.title: Step 1 - Right Career
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have two tasks to complete in this step. First you need to review the MyRightCareer Insights files you have created in all of the other Exercises: Be Your Best, Meaning & Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career and Whole Person. Second you need to identify your Right Career from those insights and any other sources of inspiration. Include some of the insights from the MyRightCareer Insights files to justify your Right Career (s) choice.

Review Your MyRightCareer Insights Files

You need to review the MyRightCareer Insights files you have been adding to with each exercise. For example here are Casey's MyRightCareer Insight's files:
Casey' "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Identify Your Right Career (s)

You need to Identify your Right Career (s) and then provide some of the Supporting Insights that led you to that conclusion.

Identify your Right Career (s)

Click on Casey's Right Career Elevator Statement:
  • Casey's Right Career - Elevator Statement (3/4 Page)
    You will see she has identified her Right Career as:
  • Function: Director of Marketing and Public Relations
  • Industry: Apparel, specifically consignment/vintage stores
  • Location: Major Cities, e.g. Boston, San Francisco, Chicago, Los Angeles, and New York City

    Supporting Insights

    Click on Casey's Right Career - Supporting Insights (10 Pages).
    You will notice she has taken insights from a lot of the Exercises to support her choice of her Right Career, e.g.
    Be My Best
    My official Myers-Briggs Type Indicator assessment is an ENFJ My Work Related Strengths related to my MBTI What I need to do in order for a career to be satisfying General Occupational Themes Insights: Top 3 - • Enterprising, Social & Artistic Natural Talents/Strengths: Includer, Empathy & Restorative Skills Insights: People Skills & Information Skills
    Meaning & Passion
    Helping Others: recognize and cultivate the potential in others. Working in Teams: Intrigued with the unique qualities of each person. I have a gift for figuring out how people who are different can work together productively Meaning at Work: I need to make sure that I have personal growth in my career and that I feel like I am making a contribution to my company and even to the world. I make a deep commitment to work in which I really believe. Friendships: These are very important to me, at work and outside work.
    Economic Engine
    So I will need to choose something that leverages my natural strengths & personality, but also has a high income potential. I do know from doing the budget exercises those career (s) should not be heavy on analysis and budget work.
    Whole Person
    Work Related: I have always been interested in fashion for very little money. Personal Related – These are my Age 30 Vision: Family: married, children, extended family. Other: NYC (or other large city), health, friends

    Create Marketing Summaries

    You should create a couple of summaries you can use in your marketing effort and when talking to people.
    Short Summary
    Click on Casey's Right Career - Summary (2 Pages). Casey's Insights document is over 10 pages long and includes all of her insights from all of the Exercises. In this short summary she got those insights down to only two pages, a more workable size.
    Elevator Statement
    Click on Casey's Right Career - Elevator Statement (3/4 Page). This document reduces it down to less than one page. It is called an Elevator Statement because you want something short enough to answer the question "Casey, what do you want to do when you get out of college?", in the time it takes to go a few floors in an elevator. You should pause after the first paragraph (where you tell them your choice of career) and ask "Would you like to know why I chose that as a career?" If they say Yes, you can continue with the insights you gained that led to that choice.

    Take Your Next Step - Click below

    Sales Story

    Return to Short Instructions - Click below

    Short Instructions

item.title: Step 3 - Sales Story
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have three tasks to complete in this step. First you need to review the Right Career files you created in Step 1: Right Career - Supporting Insights, Right Career - Summary and Right Career - Elevator Statement. Second you need to create your Sales Story from those files and any other sources of inspiration. Third you need to decide how you are going to use this Sales Story in your marketing efforts.

Review Your Right Career Choice Files

Below are the three files Casey created to describe her Right Career:
  • Casey's Right Career - Supporting Insights (10 Pages)
  • Casey's Right Career - Summary (2 Pages)
  • Casey's Right Career - Elevator Statement (3/4 Page)

    Create your Sales Story

    It is suggested you create two versions of your Sales Story - a full version (greater than one page) and an Elevator Version (less than one page)
    Full Sales Story (2 pages)
    Casey first created the two page version of her Sales Story, using the Right Career Summary (2 pages) as the starting point:
  • Casey's Sales Story (2 pages)
    You will notice the Sales Story (2 pages) file and the Right Career (2 pages) files are very similar. They both contain the basic same information because the career that is right for you is also the one in which you will most likely be successful. The Sales Story (2 pages) version is written in a more pro active voice.
    Elevator Sales Story (less than 1 page)
    Casey created her Sales Story - Elevator Statement (3/4 page), using the Right Career - Elevator Statement Summary (3/4) as the starting point:
  • Casey's Sales Story - Elevator Statement (3/4 Page)

    Use your Sales Story in your Marketing

    There are multiple uses for your Sales Story.
    Marketing Material
    You can take a subset of the Sales Story and use it on your resume and your LinkedIn Profile.
    In Person Marketing
    You can also start using it when talking to people about your career. You can use the Elevator version of the Sales Story as the starting point. I suggest you do it in multiple steps: Step 1: Explain your goal: "Director of Marketing and Public Relations who is in charge of managing different consignment/vintage stores in major cities".
    Step 2: Pause and see their reaction to that statement. I think it will be one of the two below, and maybe both.
  • Why is that right for you? You can use your Right Career - Elevator Statement, which explains why this is the right career for you.
  • Why are you right for that job? You can use the Sales Story - Elevator Statement to explain why you will be a success in that career.
  • Note: you will notice they both contain the basic same information because the career that is right for you means you will be successful in that career.
    Step 3: Ask for his help. You should stress you spent a lot of time to reach this conclusion and are convinced this is the correct answer. But you want to test it via an Internship and get experience. Does he know how you can get experience in one or both of the areas in your Right Career, e.g. for Casey:
  • Marketing and Public Relations (could be in another related industry)
  • Consignment/vintage stores (any fashion industry internship)

    Take Your Next Step - Click below

    Follow-on Plan

    Return to Short Instructions - Click below

    Short Instructions

item.title: Step 4 - Follow-on Plan
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have two tasks to complete in this step. First you need to review your Right Career (s) you identified in Step 1 and the Sales Story you created in Step 2. Second you need to create a Follow-on Plan, i.e. now that you have identified your Right Career what are you going to do next to leverage that into a job in that area.

Review Your Right Career and Your Sales Story

Below are Casey's examples:
  • Casey's Right Career - Elevator Statement (3/4 Page)
  • Casey's Sales Story - Elevator Statement (3/4 Page)

    Create Your Follow-on Plan

    Now that you know your Right Career (s) what are you going to do next. Casey's plan is almost 2 years long, while Edwards is only 1 year long. You can create a Follow-on Plan that fits your situation.
  • Casey's Follow-on Plan

    Take Your Next Step - Click below

    Feedback

    Return to Short Instructions - Click below

    Short Instructions

item.content:encoded:
Introduction

On this page are two types of templates you can use. At the top are templates for your analysis and insights. At the bottom of the page is the Checklist which allows you to keep track of the status of the sub-exercises in the Exercise.

Analysis/Insights Templates

Strengths Insights

This is a Word file with the brief Strengths Themes. You should delete the Strengths that are not yours and get the document down to the Five Strengths that are yours. You can then add your insights under each Strengths Theme description.
Strengths Insights Word template

Ideas for Action Insights

This is a Word file with the brief Strengths Themes. You should delete the Strengths that are not yours and get the document down to the Five Strengths that are yours. You can then add your top 3 "Ideas for Action" (the system produces 10/Strength) under each Strengths Theme description. You can also add any insights for each Strength.
Ideas for Action Insights Word template

Checklist Template

If you click on Strengths Checklist Template you will be able to down the Excel file that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in this exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. Both of you can get the file from this Templates page.

File Naming

You should save any file you down load on your computer. Then create another copy with your name appended on the front of that file. You can then fill in your own information in that new file. If you someway screw up that file you can download the template again and not overwrite the one with your data. This way you may be able to copy some of your data from your partly damaged file to the new template.

item.title: Short Instructions - Economics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine.

0) Introduction

Now you have the opportunity to put dollars to the words you have been creating.
If you want to see a video where Don describes the concept and the Exercise via some examples, as well as a description of the Resources available to do this exercise click on Step 0 - Introduction

1) Your Age 30 Budget

You should use your Age 30 Vision statement you developed in the first exercise as the starting point for this exercise. Click on Edward's Age 30 Vision to see his view of his life at Age 30. If you still have not settled on your Right Career (s) you have several options for estimating your Income: 1) You can assume you don't know the precise career, but you have some idea of the wage range (e.g. $80,000/year by Age 30) or 2) You can work backwards to determine how much income is required to support the life style you desire (e.g. what is the minimum income you need to have a decent life). Edward is assuming that his career will provide him with $100,000/year of income by Age 30. Estimate Your Age 30 Budget Example (pdf): Edward's Age 30 Budget. Template (Excel): Don's Age 30 Budget. You can use this as your starting point. Create Your Age 30 Budget Insights Example (pdf): Edward's Age 30 Budget - Insights Template (Word): Edward's Age 30 Budget - Insights You can use this as your starting point or just start with a blank Word document.

2) Your Age 22 Budget

Develop an Income and Expense budget for your first job out of college. As with the Age 30 Budget you have several options for estimating your Income: 1) You can assume you are starting at one of your Right Careers, i.e. you have gotten a professional job you wanted and you know the wage range, 2) You can assume you don't know the precise job you will end up getting, but you have some idea of the wage range (e.g. $40,000/year) or 3) You can work backwards to determine how much income is required to support the life style you desire (e.g. what is the minimum income you need to have a decent life). Edward is assuming that his first job out of college will provide him with $40,000/year of income. Estimate Your Age 22 Budget Example (pdf): Edward's Age 22 Budget Template (Excel): You can use the Age 30 Budget you just created in Step 1 as the starting point for your Age 22 Budget. Make a copy of the Age 30 Budget and change the name to Age 22. Then change your salary, taxes, expenses, etc. Create Your Age 22 Budget Insights Example (pdf): Edward's Age 22 Budget - Insights Template (Word): Edward's Age 22 Budget - Insights You can use this as your starting point or the one you did for Age 30 or just start with a blank Word document.

Complete the Optional Exercises (if you want to)

Step 3: Age 22 Budget Non-Professional Job:
  • Edward's Age 22 Budget - Non-Professional Job
  • Edward's Age 22 Budget - Non-Professional Job - Insights
    Step 4: Buying a House Financials:
  • Edward's House Affordability Calculator Results
  • Edward's Mortgage Calculator Results
  • Edward's Buying a House - Insights
    Step 5: Having a Family Financials:
  • Edward's Having a Family Financials
  • Edward's Having a Family Financials - Insights

    6) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights

    Document the insights you have gained from this exercise. These five documents are examples of the insights Eward obtained from completing all the exercises except Economic Engine: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories and Drivers. From these examples you can see how he has added insights with every exercise. You are only adding your insights for this exercise. Click on the links below to see the documents. Edward's "Be Your Best" Insights Edward's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Edward's "Economic Engine" Insights Edward's "Right Career" Insights Edward's "Whole Person" Insights Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise.

    7) Discuss your Results with Your Adviser.

    Discuss the output of Steps 1 and 2 above. If you completed any of the Optional Exercises (Step's 3,4 & 5) also discuss the with your Adviser. Click on "Step 7) Discuss your Results with Your Adviser" in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right for complete instructions.

    8) Hold your 2nd Career Advisory Board Meeting

    Click on "Step 8 - 2nd Career Advisory Board Meeting" in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right for complete instructions.

    9) Provide your Feedback

    Click on "Step 9 - Feedback" in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right to access the SurveyMonkey survey for a student.

    10) Become an Example

    Click on "Step 10 - Become an Example" in the Sub Navigation Panel on the upper right for complete instructions, or just send Don your output.

    11) Summary

    Click on "Step 11 - Summary" in the Sub Navigation Panel to read a Summary.

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-Economics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Economic Engine Approach

The third circle in the Right Career Venn diagram is Fuel Your Economic Engine. You will discover there is almost nothing in life that does't have a financial dimension to it, even deciding to get married or have children, two of the most personal decisions in life. You can find a career at which you can Be your Best because it leverages your Strengths, Skills and Personality. That same career may have enormous Meaning to you and you work with great Passion. But if society doesn't value that career enough to Fuel Your Economic Engine it probably is not your Right Career. If it doesn't pay you enough to support your family in a reasonable manner it is probably not your Right Career. You get to decide what is reasonable. This exercise will give you some tools to size the economic impact of your life style choices and your career choices.

Support Resources

You have multiple Support Resources to assist you in this Assignment. As with all the other Exercises you have an Examples page and a Templates page. With this Assignment you also have two unique resources: an Excel Budget Model Instructions and Web Sites.

Excel Model:

All of your financial analysis steps (Age 30, Age 22 and Age 22 Non Professional Job) use the same Excel model; just the numbers you enter are different. Click on Don's Age 30 Budget to see Don's Budget. Yours will look like this when you are done, but with numbers that reflect your situation. The detailed instructions for using each Worksheet are contained in the Excel Model Instructions page you will find in the Support section.

Web Sites:

There are a large number of Web sites to assist you in this assignment. Each step has links to the appropriate Web sites, instructions on how to use them and how you use the Web site output in your Excel model. The Web sites and instructions on how to use them are contained on the Web sites page.
