  • Edward's Having a Family Financials
  • Edward's Having a Family Financials - Insights
    MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
    Edward's "Be Your Best" Insights Edward's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Edward's "Economic Engine" Insights Edward's "Right Career" Insights Edward's "Whole Person" Insights

item.title: Templates - Economics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

On this page are three types of templates you can use. At the top are templates for your Budget and your Budget Insights. At the bottom of the page is the Checklist which allows you to keep track of the status of the sub-exercises in the Exercise.

Budget Templates

Clicking on the links below will produce an Excel file you can use for your Budget:
Age 30: Template Age 30 Budget. This is Edward's Age 30 Budget. You should change the file name to YourName-Budget-Age-30. Then either zero out Edward's numbers or replace them with your own.
Age 22: Use your Age 30 Budget as the Age 22 Template. Make a copy of your Age 30 Budget and change the name to Age 22.
Age 22 Non-Professional: Use your Age 22 Budget as the Age 22 Non-Professional Template. Make a copy of your Age 22 Budget and change the name to Age 22 Non-Professional.

Budget Insights Templates

Clicking on the links below will produce a Word file you can use for your Insights:
Age 30: Edward's Age 30 Budget - Insights
Age 22: Edward's Age 22 Budget - Insights
Age 22 Non-Professional: Edward's Age 22 Non-Professional Budget - Insights

Checklist Template

If you click on Economic Engine Checklist Template you will be able to down the Excel file that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in this exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. Both of you can get the file from this Templates page.

File Naming

You should save any file you down load on your computer. Then create another copy with your name appended on the front of that file. You can then fill in your own information in that new file. If you someway screw up that file you can download the template again and not overwrite the one with your data. This way you may be able to copy some of your data from your partly damaged file to the new template.

item.title: Step 1 - Age 30 Budget
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have two tasks to complete in this step. First you must make financial estimates, using the Excel Model, for your life at Age 30. Second you need to write your Insights for this Step. Click on the Excel Model Description in the Sub Navigation menu on the right, it contains most of the general instructions you will need to complete this exercise.

Age 30 Vision Statement

Age 30 Vision Pre-Requisite

To complete this step you should have your Age 30 Vision statement from the Begin at the End Exercise. If you did not complete the Begin at the End Exercise you have three choices:
  • Go back and complete the entire Begin at the End Exercise
  • Go back and complete "Step 1 - Age 30 Vision"
  • Make up your own Age 30 Vision as you develop your Age 30 Budget

    Age 30 Vision --> Budget

    You should use your Age 30 Vision statement you developed in the first exercise as the starting point for this exercise. Click on Edward's Age 30 Vision to see his view of his life at Age 30. Most likely you addressed Whole Person Parameters such as: location (e.g. LA or NYC), living situation (e.g. apartment vs. house), single vs. married, with or without kids, health, fun (e.g. vacations, eating out), family, commute, cars and financials (e.g. “Good Paying” job). You may have even visualized some possible careers. You are now adding dollars to the words you wrote in that document. For example Don wants to live in Manhattan Beach, one of the really nice beach towns in Los Angeles. Now he needs to estimate his lodging expenses. He is married and they both work hard and play hard. They eat out often and go to comedy clubs. He needs to estimate these entertainment expenses. Skiing has become a passion for both of them and besides driving to ski at Mammoth, the preferred LA ski area, they have started to fly to Colorado and Utah to ski. Hiking the Inca Trail was their first exotic vacations and they want to do more of that. He needs to estimate his Vacation budget. They would like to buy a home by the beach. There is an Optional exercise for this issue. In four years his wife will be at the age where they will have to decide about having a family. There is an Optional exercises for this exercise. These two are major financial decisions, besides emotional ones.

    Age 30 Budget - Examples & Instructions

    Click on Edward's Age 30 Budget to see the example used in this exercise. Click on Casey's Age 30 Budget to see another example.

    Income & Taxes Worksheet

    Sub items: Income, Before Tax Savings (e.g. 401K) and Income Taxes (Federal, State, Social Security and Medicare) and Spendable Income.
    Income: In the monthly column enter your Wages, Interest Income, Investment Income (e.g. Dividends, Capital Gains, Business Income) and Misc Income. Do the same for your Spouse. By now you may have an idea of your Right Career (s) and if so you can use that to estimate your income. If you still have not settled on your Right Career (s) you have several options for estimating your Income: 1) You can assume you don't know the precise career, but you have some idea of the wage range (e.g. $80,000/year by Age 30) or 2) You can work backwards to determine how much income is required to support the life style you desire (e.g. what is the minimum income you need to have a decent life). Edward believes he will have a job with a $100,000/year income by Age 30 and his Spouse will be making $40,000 that same year. Click on Edward's Salary Estimate to see a pdf showing the inputs and outputs for Don at Age 30. You will notice he chose Los Angeles and Financial Analyst. If you want to use the same Web site to estimate your salary click on Salary by Job Type. You can then enter your job type and your location. Excel will calculate the totals for each of you and the total for the family. It will also calculate what % each of you is contributing to the total family income, e.g. in Edward's example he contributes about 70% and his spouse contributes about 30%.
    Before Tax Savings: Enter the amount of dollars you plan to contribute to your 401K (or Keogh Plan if you are going to be self-employed). For example you can decide that by age 30 you want to contribute 10% of your income/year into your company’s 401K (some companies will match your contribution). Excel will calculate the totals for each of you and the total for the family.
    Federal, Social Security and Medicare: Click on Take Home Pay Calculator and it will assist you in estimating your taxes. Choose monthly Pay Frequency. Pick your filing status (either Single or Married filing jointly). Enter the # of Federal Tax Allowances (e.g. if you are married without children it is 2). Enter the 401K amount/month you chose in the Before Tax Savings section. Then enter the Gross Income you already estimated, if filing as Married you enter the total of your two incomes. If you are filing as single you only enter your income. Click on Edward's Take-Home_Pay to see a pdf of Edward's inputs and outputs using the Web site.
    State Income Tax: If your state has an income tax, e.g. California does, Click on Income Tax by State to access the Web site. You need to enter: Filing Status (e.g. single or married), Total Income (use the same yearly income you used in the Federal Tax calculation above), Deductions (select the “Use Federal and State Standard Deductions), Dependents (e.g. Single = 1 and Married = 2). Click on Edward's California Tax to see a pdf of Edward's inputs and outputs using the Web site.
    Data Entry: the Web sites provide your tax as an annual amount. You should enter it as $Tax/12 (e.g. $1,000 = $12,000/12 in the monthly field and you will see the $12,000 appear in the Yearly field).
    Spendable Income: Excel will calculate this for you by subtracting your “Before Tax Savings” (e.g. 401K contribution) and your Income Taxes from your Gross Income. This is the amount of money in your pay check each pay period. You have to learn to live on your Take Home Pay.

    Hourly Income Worksheet

    This Worksheet is mainly used for the Age 22-NonProfessional exercise. For example you may believe you can earn $20,000/year ($1,667/month) and will figure out later what job (s) would allow you to earn $1,667/month. What you want to find out is “how can I live on $20,000/year”. For the Age 30 model you are probably not getting paid hourly and can just input your monthly salary into the Income & Taxes Worksheet.

    Lodging Worksheet

    Sub items: Apartment rent or Mortgage payment, Homeowner Insurance or Renter Insurance and Homeowner Property Tax.
  • Owning a House: Edward visualizes himself owning a house by age 30.He has assumed it is $375,000 with a $75,000 (20%) Down Payment.
  • Down Payment: At an early age the most important parameter is how much Down Payment you can make.Most lending organizations require 20% down.
    In the Assumptions section of the Lodging Worksheet there are two sections: Own Your House/Condo or Rent an Apartment. You will use only one of those sections. In this example Edward has used the Own Your House/Condo section. By using the Web tools from the Web site page, Edward was able to calculate that he could afford to buy a $375,000 house, with a $75,000 downpayment. If you want to see how he did that click on

    Discretionary Expenses Worksheet

    Sub items: Vacation, Improvements, Food, Fun, Financial Expense, Self, Spouse, Post Tax Savings and Gifts. Edward estimated the Discretionary Expenses he expects to implement his Age 30 Vision. Of special note is his assumption for Post Tax Savings. Because owning a house is a key element of his Age 30 Vision he has been saving 10% of his salary for a down payment since he started working.

    Non-Discretionary Expenses Worksheet

    Sub items: Household, Medical, Personal Insurance, Pets, Transportation, Utilities, Debt Payments and Miscellaneous. Edward estimated the Discretionary Expenses he expects to implement his Age 30 Vision. He has assumed both he and his spouse will have cars because they will live in Manhattan Beach and Southern California is a car culture.

    Summary Worksheet

    Sub items: Income, Before Tax Savings (e.g. 401K), Income Taxes (Federal, State, Social Security and Medicare) and Spendable Income. Total Expenses (Discretionary Expenses, Non-Discretionary Expenses and Lodging). Surplus or Shortage The key focus item is at the bottom of this Worksheet – Surplus/Shortage. Edward's final pass produced a surplus (a positive number). But he had to make multiple changes in his Discretionary and Non-Discretionary Expense to get that line to not be negative.
    DO NOT input any data into the "Income and Expenses - Summary" Worksheet. Excel sources that data from all the other Worksheets, e.g. Income & Taxes, Lodging, Discretionary Expenses
    If you want to change any data, e.g. Wages or Vacation Expense you must go to the appropriate Worksheet and make those changes. The Summary worksheet line items are also summaries of several line items in the detail Worksheets, e.g. Vacation is not a single number, rather it is the following entries: Major Trips, Weekend Trips and Relative Visits. If you want to increase or decrease your Vacation expense you will have to make those changes in one or more of those three sub-categories. There are multiple uses for the Summary worksheet:
  • Surplus/Shortage: Validate you have created a budget that has a Surplus, rather than a shortage. Most likely your first pass at your budget will create a shortage, i.e. you will have spent more than your "Spendable Income". As you lower your expenses you will keep coming back to the Summary worksheet to see if you have gotten to a positive Surplus/Shortage number.
  • Spendable Income: Provide a high level summary of your Spendable Income. You can see, at a summary level, your Gross Income, Before Tax Savings, Taxes and Spendable Income. This may motivate you to increase or decrease your Before Tax Savings. You may be motivated to look for Professionals who could help you to lower your Taxes as a % of Income.
  • Expenses: Provide a high level summary of your Expenses. You can view them in their three major categories: Lodging, Non-Discretionary and Discretionary. You can view them as a % of your Spendable Income, another effective way to view the expenses. You can quickly identify the top 3 expenses in Non-Discretionary and Discretionary expenses. At the summary level you may see some of the expenses are too low or too high relative to other expenses.
  • What If: You can use the Summary worksheet to see the results of changing various aspects of your budget to see "What would happen if". You could test how much income you would need to support the expense level you want (just remember to revisit the Income Taxes Web sites as you increase your Income). At some Income level you will have enough to create a Surplus. You can then decide if that is a reasonable Income. You could do something similar with Expenses, e.g. what is the Income you would need to support the minimum Expenses you require. This is similar to the Age 22 Non-Professional exercise, e.g. what if you could only make $20,000 - can you come up with a reasonable set of expense assumptions to live at that Income level.

    Age 30 Insights - Examples & Instructions

    Click on Edward's Age 30 Budget - Insights to see an example. Edward's summary paragraph in his Insights document was: Getting the budget to have a surplus, i.e. spending less than we make, is a real challenge. It took several passes to get it to zero. I would like to spend more on Discretionary, e.g. Vacations, Fun and Personal (my wife and I). It is really hard to believe that a couple making $140,000 still has to be careful about what they spend. And it is only going to get worse as we have kids. It gives me a new appreciation for my parents.
    Click on Casey's Age 30 Budget - Insights for another Insights example.

    Your Age 30 Budget Model

    Click on Template Age 30 Budget. This is Edward's Age 30 Budget and you can then save it as YourName-Budget-Age 30. Click on Excel Model Description in the Sub-Navigation Menu on the right to get a pdf document with instructions for each element in the Excel Model, if you need more explanation. Once you learn the Excel Model for your Age 30 Budget you will be able to use it again for your Age 22 Budget. Now put your own Age 30 financial information in the Excel model, being careful to zero out Edward's in fields you are not using.

    Your Age 30 Budget Insights

    Click on Template Age 30 Budget - Insights. This is actually Edward's Age 30 Budget Insights but you can then save it as YourName-Budget-Age-30-Insights. It is a Word version that you can use it as your starting point or open a new Word document and create your Insights document from a blank page.

item.title: Step 4 - Optional: Financials of Buying a House
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

This is an exploration of Edward buying a house the year after he turns 30. It is based on his long-range plan and makes the same assumptions, i.e.
  • Personal – He starts living with his future wife at 28 & they get married when he is 30.
  • Financial – He makes $40,000/year in his 1st job and by age 30 he makes $100,000/year.
  • His wife, who is 3 years younger than him, is making $40,000/year when he turns 30.

    House Financials

    House Affordability

    The bank would probably not take into account his wife’s income because they are concerned she will quit working when they have kids. Thus he only used his $100,000/year salary for this analysis. Click on Edward's House Affordability Calculator Results to see his results from using the following parameters: (Annual Income: $100,000; Loan Term: 30 years; Interest Rate: 6%; Down Payment: 20%). Notice the model provides two possible scenarios: Acceptable – Debt to Income of 36% Mortgage: $396,000 House Price: $496,000 Down Payment: $100,000 Monthly Payment: $ 2,400 Safe – Debt to Income of 28% Mortgage: $310,000 House Price: $385,000 Down Payment: $ 75,000 Monthly Payment: $ 1,850
    It is clear they will have to save a lot of money for a down payment if they are going to buy a house after he turns 30. He has assumed they can not save more than $75,000 for a down payment. This means they can not afford more than a $375,000 house. To save that much down payment he will need to save 10% of his income every year from college on and his wife will need to save 10% of her income in the 2-year period they are living together. The down payment is driving the price of the house they can buy, not his income.
    He could buy the almost $500,000 house if they could:
  • Make the $100,000 downpayment (maybe parents provide part of downpayment)
  • Pay a higher monthly mortgage payment ($2,400 vs. $1,850)
  • Pay a higher yearly property tax payment ($7,450 vs. $5,800)
    Often this is referred to as house poor, i.e. the cost of buying and paying for your house has used up all of your financial resources. You may not even have enough left to decorate the house.

    Monthly Payments

    Click on Edward's Mortgage Calculator Results to see the monthly payments for the house he decided to buy. You will notice the Web site provides: mortgage payment, property tax and property insurance. Don then used these in his Age 30 Budget.

    Insights

    Click on Edward's Buying a House - Insights to see the Insights Edward got from this exercise. Two of the key Insights are: I never realized how much the Down Payment would influence the price of the house I could purchase. The House Affordability Calculator was a very useful resource to understand the relationship between my income, the down payment, the mortgage payments and the property tax. I decided to go for the Safe Debt to Income ratio of 28%, limiting the price of the house to $375,000. But I bet when we start looking for houses we will find we don’t like any of the $375,000 houses we find. I already know the typical house price in Manhattan Beach, where I initially wanted to live, is $1M.

    Your Buy a House Exercise

    House Affordability

    On the Web Sites - Economics page there is a section describing the Loan tools you can use. With the House Affordability Calculator figure out the two houses you can afford. Look at the analysis Edward did that is described above for guidance.

    Monthly Payments

    On the Web Sites - Economics page, in the Loan Tools, is the Mortgage Calculator. Use this to determine the monthly payments for the loan you selected. Look at the analysis Edward did that is described above for guidance.

    Buying a House_Insights

    Click on Edward's Buying a House - Insights and you can use this as a reference for creating your own insights document. Just create a new Word document and enter your own insights.

item.title: Old Step 5 - Age 26 Financials
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have two tasks to complete in this step. First you must make financial estimates, using the Excel Model, for your life at Age 26. Second you need to write your Insights for this Step.

Age 26 Status

In “Step 2 – Work Backwards” you determined your relationship status when you are 26, e.g. Don is single at that age. You decided on your Income at Age 26, e.g. Don’s is $70,000. If you want to own a house by Age 30 or soon after that you determined how much money you need to save each year, e.g. Don is saving 10% of his income, to have enough money to purchase a house in the future (Don needs $75,000 for his down payment).

Excel Model

Click on Don Budget Age 26 to see an example. Below are comments for all the Worksheets:

  • Income & Taxes Worksheet

    • o Sub items: Income, Before Tax Savings (e.g. 401K) and Income Taxes (Federal, State, Social Security and Medicare) and Spendable Income. o Your Income: From ‘Step 2 – Work Backwards’ Don believes he will have a job with a $70,000/year income by Age 26. o Spouse’s Income: From ‘Step 2 – Work Backwards’, for example Don believes he will still be single at Age 26, thus there is no Spouse Income.

  • Lodging Worksheet

    • o Sub items: • Renter: Apartment rent and Renter Insurance. • Home Owner: Mortgage payment, Homeowner Insurance and Homeowner Property Tax. o Don visualizes himself living in a nice apartment with two other people. So he only has to pay 1/3 of the rent.

  • Discretionary Expenses Worksheet

    • o Sub items: Vacation, Improvements, Food, Fun, Financial Expense, Self, Spouse, Post Tax Savings and Gifts. o Don estimated the Discretionary Expenses he expects he hopes to spend at Age 26. o Don is saving 10% of his income, to have enough money to purchase a house in the future (Don needs $75,000 for his down payment).

  • Non-Discretionary Expenses Worksheet

    • o Sub items: Household, Medical, Personal Insurance, Pets, Transportation, Utilities, Debt Payments, and Miscellaneous. o Don estimated the Non Discretionary Expenses he expects. He has assumed he will have a car because he will live in Manhattan Beach and Southern California is a car culture.

  • Summary Worksheet

    • o The key focus item is at the bottom of this Worksheet – Surplus/Shortage. o Don’s final pass produced a surplus (a positive number). o But he had to make multiple changes in his Discretionary and Non-Discretionary Expense to get that line to not be negative.

    Your Financial Model

    Make a copy of your Age 30 Budget, from Step 1, and save it as Your Name-Budget Age 26. Click on Excel Model Description to get a pdf document with instructions for each element in the Excel Model, or maybe you remember how to use the Excel Model from doing your Age 30 Financial Model. First enter your Income numbers, decide on Pre Tax Savings and calculate your Taxes. This will produce your Spendable Income. Second take a look at your Surplus/Shortage number, which will be negative because you have less Spendable Income. Third start through your three categories of expenses (Lodging, Discretionary and Non-Discretionary) looking for places to cut expense.

    Financial Model Insights

    Click on Don Budget Insights Age 26 to see an example. Click on Don Budget Insights Age 26 and save it as YourName- Budget Insights Age 30 It is a Word version that you can use or open a new Word document and create it from a blank page.

item.title: Step 2 - Age 22 Budget
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have two tasks to complete in this step. First you must create a budget, using the basic same Excel Model you used for your Age 30 budget, for your life at Age 22 (your first year out of college). Second you need to write your Insights for this Step. Click on the Excel Model Description in the Sub Navigation menu on the right, it contains most of the general instructions you will need to complete this exercise.

Age 22 Status

You need to determine your relationship status when you are 22, e.g. Don is single and having fun dating.
You need to determine your work status. In this exercise you have several options: 1) You can assume you are starting at one of your Right Careers, i.e. you have gotten a professional job you wanted and you know the wage range, 2) You can assume you don't know the precise job you will end up getting, but you have some idea of the wage range (e.g. $40,000/year) or 3) You can work backwards to determine how much income is required to support the life style you desire (e.g. what is the minimum income you need to have a decent life). Don is assuming that his first job out of college will provide him with $40,000/year of income.

Age 22 Budget - Example & Instructions

Click on Edward's Age 22 Budget to see the example used in this exercise. Click on Casey's Age 22 Budget to see another example.

Income & Taxes

Sub items: Income, Before Tax Savings (e.g. 401K) and Income Taxes (Federal, State, Social Security and Medicare) and Spendable Income.
  • Spouse #1 Income:Edward believes he will start out earning 40,000/year
  • Spouse #2 Income: Since Edward assumes he is single at Age 22 there is no Spouse #2 Income.

    Hourly Income

    Again this Worksheet is mainly used for the Age 22-NonProfessional exercise. For example you may believe you can earn $20,000/year ($1,667/month) and will figure out later what job (s) would allow you to earn $1,667/month. What you want to find out is “how can I live on $20,000/year”. For the Age 30 model you are probably not getting paid hourly and can just input your monthly salary into the Income & Taxes Worksheet.

    Lodging Worksheet

    Sub items: Apartment rent or Mortgage payment, Homeowner Insurance or Renter Insurance and Homeowner Property Tax. In the Assumptions section of the Lodging Worksheet there are two sections: Own Your House/Condo or Rent an Apartment. You will use only one of those sections. In this example Edward has used the "Rent an Apartment" option. He has assumed there will be 3 people living in this apartment and thus calculated the monthly rent and renter's insurance by dividing the total by 3.

    Discretionary Expenses Worksheet

    Sub items: Vacation, Improvements, Food, Fun, Financial Expense, Self, Spouse, Post Tax Savings and Gifts. Edward estimated the Discretionary Expenses he expects to spend. Of special note is his assumption for Post Tax Savings. Because owning a house is a key element of his Age 30 Vision he has been saving 10% of his salary for a down payment since he started working. You will notice he is spending a lot less at a $40,000 salary then he is able to spend at a combined $140,000 income when he is married and Age 30.

    Non-Discretionary Expenses Worksheet

    Sub items: Household, Medical, Personal Insurance, Pets, Transportation, Utilities, Debt Payments and Miscellaneous. Edward estimated the Discretionary Expenses he expects. He has assumed he will have a car because Southern California is a car culture.

    Summary Worksheet

    Warning

    DO NOT input any data into the "Income and Expenses - Summary" Worksheet. Excel sources that data from all the other Worksheets, e.g. Income & Taxes, Lodging, Discretionary Expenses
    If you want to change any data, e.g. Wages or Vacation Expense you must go to the appropriate Worksheet and make those changes. The Summary worksheet line items are also summaries of several line items in the detail Worksheets, e.g. Vacation is not a single number, rather it is the following entries: Major Trips, Weekend Trips and Relative Visits. If you want to increase or decrease your Vacation expense you will have to make those changes in one or more of those three sub-categories. The key focus item is at the bottom of this Worksheet – Surplus/Shortage. Edward"s final pass produced a surplus (a positive number). But he had to make multiple changes in his Discretionary and Non-Discretionary Expense to get that line to not be negative.

    Age 22 Budget Insights

    Click on Edward's Age 22 Budget - Insights to see an example. Edward's summary paragraph in his Insights document was: Getting the budget to have a surplus, i.e. spending less than I make, was a real challenge again. My income fell from $140,000 (Age 30 - 2 wage earners) to $40,000 (single & first job out of college). I had to cut out a significant amount of the expenses I had in my Age 30 Budget. While $40,000 is a lot more money than I have been making in college it is amazing how little it seems when doing this exercise.
    Click on Casey's Age 22 Budget - Insights to see another example of an Insights document.

    Your Age 22 Budget Model

    Make a copy of your own Budget Age 30 Excel file and change its name to YourName-Budget Age 22. You can then change the numbers in your Budget Age 30 file to reflect your life at Age 22, e.g. Income, Lodging, Expenses. Click on Excel Model Description in the Sub-Navigation Menu on the right to get a pdf document with instructions for each element in the Excel Model. You should have a good understanding of how the Excel model works from creating your Age 30 Budget.

    Your Age 22 Budget - Insights

    Click on Template Age 22 Budget - Insights. This is actually Edward's Age 22 Budget Insights but you can then save it as YourName-Budget-Age-22-Insights. It is a Word version that you can use it as your starting point or open a new Word document and create your Insights document from a blank page.

item.title: Step 3 - Optional: Age 22 Budget - Non-Prof Job
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

This exercise will help you understand your financial situation if you are not able to get a professional job right out of college. Even if you strongly believe you will get a professional job, this exercise will give you an idea of your financial reality if you don’t. Or you may get an internship in your profession, but it pays a lot less than a full position (e.g. maybe $20,000 versus $40,000).
You have two tasks to complete in this step. First you must create a Budget, using the Excel Model, for your life at Age 22, assuming you are not able to get a professional job right out of college. Second you need to write your Insights for this Step.
We will continue to use Edward as our example.

Age 22 Status

You need to determine your relationship status when you are 22, e.g. Edward is single and having fun dating.
You need to determine your work status. For example Edward was not able to get a job in his chosen financial analysis Career. He is working three jobs: a waiter, a bike shop salesman and a high school math tutor. He is still pursuing his target career.

Age 22 Non-Professional Job Budget

Click on Edward's Age 22 Budget - Non-Professional Job to see his Budget. Click on Casey's Age 22 Budget - Non-Professional Job to see another example.

  • Hourly Income

    This Worksheet is mainly used for the Age 22-NonProfessional exercise. For example you may believe you can earn $20,000/year ($1,667/month) and will figure out later what job (s) would allow you to earn $1,667/month. What you want to find out is “how can I live on $20,000/year”. Maybe your income comes from a full time Internship that doesn’t pay well. In that case just estimate your monthly income and put that in the Income & Taxes Worksheet. The columns of the Worksheet are the jobs you are planning on finding. There is space for four jobs; you should provide a name below each “Job 1” (e.g. Edward's Job #1 is waiter).
  • Hours/Day: for example Edward assumes he is going to work 4 hours/day in his Waiter job
  • Days/Week: for example Edward assumes he is going to work 4 days/week in that Waiter job
  • Hourly Rate: Edward assumes $10/hour, with no tips for his waiter job
    In the end you take the Total Income/month (in bold Red) and enter it into the Income + Taxes worksheet.

  • Income & Taxes

    Sub items: Income, Before Tax Savings (e.g. 401K) and Income Taxes (Federal, State, Social Security and Medicare) and Spendable Income.
    Income
  • Spouse #1 Income: It is likely your income will have been calculated using the Hourly Income Worksheet. Take the monthly income and put that in the Income & Taxes Worksheet.
  • Spouse #2 Income: Most likely you won't be married at Age 22, Don wasn't. If you are then enter your Spouse's income.
    Click on the Excel Budget Model Instructions in the Sub Navigation panel on the right and it will provide the instructions for this section.

  • Lodging Worksheet

    • Sub items: Apartment rent or Mortgage payment, Homeowner Insurance or Renter Insurance and Homeowner Property Tax. You might end up living at home until you find the professional job you want. Assuming your parents are not going to charge you rent you can put $0 in both of these fields. Many parents end up charging their child rent so you should probably use a real rental estimate. It will also make your financial projection more valuable, e.g. it will affect how much money you have to spend. Edward visualizes himself living in a less expensive apartment (than at Age 26) with three other people. So he only has to pay ¼ of the rent. It is not practical to live at home because home is a small town and he will never find a professional job living at home. In the Assumptions section of the Lodging Worksheet there are two sections: Own Your House/Condo or Rent an Apartment. You will use only one of those sections.

  • Discretionary Expenses Worksheet

    • Sub items: Vacation, Improvements, Food, Fun, Financial Expense, Self, Spouse, Post Tax Savings and Gifts. Edward estimated the Discretionary Expenses he plans to spend at Age 22, working in a 3 different Non Professional jobs.

  • Non-Discretionary Expenses Worksheet

    • Sub items: Household, Medical, Personal Insurance, Pets, Transportation, Utilities, Debt Payments and Miscellaneous. Edward estimated the Non Discretionary Expenses he expects. He has assumed he will live somewhere he can use public transportation.

  • Summary Worksheet

    The key focus item is at the bottom of this Worksheet – Surplus/Shortage. Edward'd final pass produced a surplus (a positive number). It was very hard to live on $20,000/year (his income estimate).

  • Your Age 22 Budget Non-Professional Budget

    • Make a copy of your own Budget Age 22 Excel file and change its name to YourName-Budget Age 22 Non-Professional. You can then change the numbers in your Budget Age 22 Excel file to reflect your life at Age 22 working in a Non Professional role, e.g. Income, Lodging, Expenses.

    Warning

    DO NOT input any data into the "Income and Expenses - Summary" Worksheet. Excel sources that data from all the other Worksheets, e.g. Income & Taxes, Lodging, Discretionary Expenses
    Click on Excel Model Description to get a pdf document with instructions for each element in the Excel Model, or maybe you remember how to use the Excel Model from doing your Age 30 and Age 22-Professional Job Budgets.
  • First enter your Income numbers, decide on Pre Tax Savings and calculate your Taxes. Use the Hourly Income Worksheet, which allows you to estimate jobs like waiters, laborers, etc. This will produce your Spendable Income.
  • Second, make a 1st estimate of your lodging expenses, e.g. Don assumed he would room with three other people in a $2,000/month apartment, so his monthly rent would be $500.
  • Third take a look at your Surplus/Shortage number, which will be negative because you have less Spendable Income.
  • Fourth start through your three categories of expenses (Lodging, Discretionary and Non-Discretionary) looking for places to cut expense.

    Age 22 Non-Profession Budget Model Insights

    Click on Template Age 22 Non-Professional Budget - Insights. This is actually Edward's Age 22 Non-Professional Budget Insights but you can then save it as YourName-Budget-Age-22-NonProfessional-Insights. It is a Word version that you can use it as your starting point or open a new Word document and create your Insights document from a blank page.

item.title: Excel Budget Model Instructions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

All of your financial analysis steps (Age 30, Age 22 and Age 22 Non-Professional Job) use the same Excel model; just the numbers you enter are different. They all have five Worksheets: Summary, Income/Taxes, Lodging (e.g. apartment rent or house payments), Detail-Discretionary Expenses and DetailNon-Discretionary Expenses. You do not enter any information into the Summary Worksheet; it gets its information from the other four Worksheets. When you enter data into the other Worksheets you use the Monthly column (the Yearly column is calculated by Excel). Click on Don Age 30 Budget to see a pdf of Don’s Budget.

Worksheets

Here is a description of each Worksheet and what you must do to complete it. You enter your information in the Monthly column, in the areas boxed in. If you are proficient in Excel you can make changes to the Worksheets, e.g. adding another sub category to Vacation. You must ensure the totals still calculate properly – Category (e.g. Vacation) and Worksheet (e.g. Income, Lodging, Discretionary and Non Discretionary.

  • Summary Worksheet:

    • Sub items: Income, Before Tax Savings (e.g. 401K), Income Taxes (Federal, State, Social Security and Medicare) and Spendable Income. Total Expenses (Discretionary Expenses, Non-Discretionary Expenses and Lodging). Surplus or Shortage
    DO NOT input any data into the "Income and Expenses - Summary" page (page #1). Excel sources that data from all the other Worksheets, e.g. Income & Taxes, Lodging, Discretionary Expenses
    If you want to change any data, e.g. Wages or Vacation Expense you must go to the appropriate Worksheet and make those changes. The Summary worksheet line items are also summaries of several line items in the detail Worksheets, e.g. Vacation is not a single number, rather it is the following entries: Major Trips, Weekend Trips and Relative Visits. If you want to increase or decrease your Vacation expense you will have to make those changes in one or more of those three sub-categories. There are multiple uses for the Summary worksheet:
  • Surplus/Shortage: Validate you have created a budget that has a Surplus, rather than a shortage. Most likely your first pass at your budget will create a shortage, i.e. you will have spent more than your "Spendable Income". As you lower your expenses you will keep coming back to the Summary worksheet to see if you have gotten to a positive Surplus/Shortage number.
  • Spendable Income: Provide a high level summary of your Spendable Income. You can see, at a summary level, your Gross Income, Before Tax Savings, Taxes and Spendable Income. This may motivate you to increase or decrease your Before Tax Savings. You may be motivated to look for Professionals who could help you to lower your Taxes as a % of Income.
  • Expenses: Provide a high level summary of your Expenses. You can view them in two major categories: Operating Expenses (Non-Discretionary and Discretionary) and Lodging. You can view them as a % of your Spendable Income, another effective way to analyze your expenses. You can quickly identify the top 3 Operating Expenses in Non-Discretionary and Discretionary expenses. At the summary level you may see some of the expenses are too low or too high relative to other expenses.
  • What If: You can use the Summary worksheet to see the results of changing various aspects of your budget to see "What would happen if". You could test how much income you would need to support the expense level you want (just remember to revisit the Income Taxes Web sites as you increase your Income). At some Income level you will have enough to create a Surplus. You can then decide if that is a reasonable Income. You could do something similar with Expenses, e.g. what is the Income you would need to support the minimum Expenses you require. This is similar to the Age 22 Non-Professional exercise, e.g. what if you could only make $20,000 - can you come up with a reasonable set of expense assumptions to live at that Income level.

  • Income & Taxes Worksheet:

    • Income: In the monthly column enter your Wages, Interest Income, Investment Income (e.g. Dividends, Capital Gains, Business Income) and Misc Income. Do the same for your Spouse. Don believes he will have a job with a $100,000/year income by Age 30. Click on Don's Salary Estimate to see a pdf showing the inputs and outputs for Don at Age 30. You will notice he chose Los Angeles and Financial Analyst. If you want to use the same Web site to estimate your salary click on Salary by Job Type. You can then enter your job type and your location. Excel will calculate the totals for each of you and the total for the family. It will also calculate what % each of you is contributing to the total family income, e.g. in Don's example he contributes about 70% and his spouse contributes about 30%. Before Tax Savings: Enter the amount of dollars you plan to contribute to your 401K (or Keogh Plan if you are going to be self-employed). For example you can decide that by age 30 you want to contribute 10% of your income/year into your company’s 401K (some companies will match your contribution). Excel will calculate the totals for each of you and the total for the family. Federal, Social Security and Medicare: Click on Take Home Pay Calculator and it will assist you in estimating your taxes. Choose monthly Pay Frequency. Pick your filing status (either Single or Married filing jointly). Enter the # of Federal Tax Allowances (e.g. if you are married without children it is 2). Enter the 401K amount/month you chose in the Before Tax Savings section. Then enter the Gross Income you already estimated, if filing as Married you enter the total of your two incomes. If you are filing as single you only enter your income. Click on Don Take-Home_Pay to see a pdf of Don’s inputs and outputs using the Web site. State Income Tax: If your state has an income tax, e.g. California does, Click on Income Tax by State to access the Web site. You need to enter: Filing Status (e.g. single or married), Total Income (use the same yearly income you used in the Federal Tax calculation above), Deductions (select the “Use Federal and State Standard Deductions), Dependents (e.g. Single = 1 and Married = 2). Click on Don's California Tax to see a pdf of Don’s inputs and outputs using the Web site. Data Entry: the Web sites provide your tax as an annual amount. You should enter it as $Tax/12 (e.g. $1,000 = $12,000/12 in the monthly field and you will see the $12,000 appear in the Yearly field). Spendable Income: Excel will calculate this for you by subtracting your “Before Tax Savings” (e.g. 401K contribution) and your Income Taxes from your Gross Income. This is the amount of money in your pay check each pay period. You have to learn to live on your Take Home Pay.

  • Income Worksheet:

    • Sub items: Job Description, Income/Week, Income/Month and Income/Year. This Worksheet is mainly used for the Age 22-NonProfessional exercise. For example you may believe you can earn $20,000/year ($1,667/month) and will figure out later what job (s) would allow you to earn $1,667/month. What you want to find out is “how can I live on $20,000/year”. Job Description: There are four columns, one for each of four jobs. For example Don assumed he had three jobs: Waiter, Bike shop salesman and high school math tutor.
    Income/Week: For each of the jobs you can enter the hours/day and days/week you will work and Excel will calculate the Hours/week you will be working on that job. You can input an hourly rate for each job and Excel will then calculate your weekly income for that job. It also allows you to add an estimate of Tips and produces a total Income/Week for each job.
    Income/Month: Using the Income/Week information from above Excel calculates your Income/Month (which is shown in Red). You take this number and enter it in the Income & Taxes Worksheet as your Monthly Income.

  • Lodging Worksheet Worksheet:

    • Sub items: Apartment rent or Mortgage payment, Homeowner Insurance or Renter Insurance and Homeowner Property Tax. Source of Information: Assuming you know the city you want to live in you can Click on City Cost of Living Comparison to access the Web site. Click on Don Cost of California Living to see a pdf of Don’s inputs and outputs using the Web site. Rent or Mortgage Payment (you choose one or the other, not both): Rent: Estimate the total rent/month for your apartment, along with the number of roommates. Excel will calculate “Your Rent” by dividing the Total by the # of Roommates. Enter that number in the monthly Mortgage or Rent field. House Affordability: Explore how much you can borrow: Click on House Affordability to access the Web site. Enter your annual income (you may want to only enter the income of the person who will be working if you have children – that is what Don did). Keep the following the same as in the model: “your planned loan term” at 30 years, “interest rate” at 6% and “percentage of down payment” at 20%. Hit “Submit” to receive the amount of money you can borrow, e.g. $300,000. There are two estimates, use the Safe one (debt to income rate of 28%). Round that off and use it as your loan payment below. Click on Don House Affordability to see a pdf of Don’s inputs and outputs using the Web site. Estimate your Mortgage Payment. Click on House Mortgage Calculator to access the Web site. Enter the Principal Balance from above, the Annual Interest Rate, the Amortization Length (e.g. 30 years). Leave the Starting month already entered. Pick “Monthly” as the payment method. Hit “Submit” to receive your Monthly Payment (e.g. $1,288). Enter that amount in the monthly Mortgage Payment field in the top of the page of your Excel model (Lodging worksheet).Click on Don's Mortgage Payments to see a pdf of Don’s inputs and outputs using the Web site. Homeowner or Renter Insurance (you choose one or the other; not both): Homeowner: The Excel model calculated this when you entered the price of your home. Renter: You enter the total Renters Insurance. It will divide that by the number of roommates to give you “Your Renter’s Insurance” amount. Enter that number in the area above. Property Tax: This only applies when you own a home. Excel has calculated that amount and you need to enter it.

  • Discretionary vs. Non Discretionary Concept

    • At the start, all of your expenses are discretionary, i.e. you get to decide how much you want to spend on that category. But soon there are sets of expenses for which you have little control, e.g. once you sign an apartment lease you are stuck with that monthly rent for another year. You also have little control over the Utilities’ expenses that come with that apartment Once you buy a car you will not be able to control most of those expense except gas (and that may be controlled by your work commute). There are sets of expenses, discretionary, that you have a lot more control over. You decide your vacation expenses (e.g. major trips, weekend trips, family visits), fun expenses (e.g. eating out, cable TV, health club) and personal expenses (e.g. clothes, personal care). Even food is discretionary. You can buy food and cook it or do Take Out.

  • Discretionary Expenses Worksheet:

    • Sub items: Vacation, Improvements, Food, Fun, Financial Expense, Self, Spouse, Post Tax Savings and Gifts. Enter a monthly $ figure for each subcategory, e.g. in Vacation you will enter Major Trips, Weekend Trips and Family Visits. In some cases the yearly amount is easier to understand, e.g. you plan one Major Trip that you estimate will cost $5,000. You will need to enter $5,000/12 in the monthly field and Excel will calculate the Yearly amount. In other cases the most natural entry is monthly, e.g. in Fun you plan on belonging to a Health Club and that is $75/month. Category/Subcategory Definitions (you enter the data at the subcategory level): Vacation: It has 3 self-explanatory subcategories – Major Trips, Weekend Trips and Family Visits. Improvements: Home/Apartment (e.g. a new couch), Yard (e.g. plants), Technology (e.g. a new TV set – if the technology is personal, e.g. a cell phone, it goes in your own Category – Self or Spouse) Food: Groceries (e.g. food you buy at Trader Joe’s), Take Home (e.g. getting a pizza rather than cooking), Lunches (e.g. what you spend each day at work on lunch) and Liquor (e.g. buying beer & wine for home). Fun: Eating out (e.g. restaurant or yogurt shop), Events (e.g. movies, concerts), Video Rental, Club Memberships (e.g. Health Club) Financial Expenses: Bank Charges (e.g. checking account fee, over draft fee, bill pay fee), Credit Card Charges (e.g. late payment, interest), Legal (e.g. Will creation), Tax Preparation (e.g. HR Block) Self/Spouse (same subcategories): Clothes (e.g. shirts, shoes), Personal Care (e.g. hair cut, toiletry supplies), Sports Stuff (e.g. soccer shoes, soccer balls), Personal Technology (e.g. iPhone, iPad, laptop), Books (e.g. paper or digital), Music (e.g. iTunes or CD’s), Services (e.g. shoe repair), Job Search (e.g. Web site fees, lunches/coffee), Education (e.g. night school). Post Tax Savings (not 401K because it is a Pre Tax Saving): Savings (e.g. 5% of your salary goes into a savings account and maybe then invested), House Down payment (e.g. setting aside 10% of your income to make a down payment on a house later), Emergency Fund (e.g. saving money for unexpected expenses like having to get new tires before you planned). Gifts: Family/Friends (e.g. birthday and Christmas), Other (e.g. gift to your doorman, political donations), Tax Deductible Donations (e.g. College Alumni Fund, Goodwill)  

  • Non-Discretionary Expenses Worksheet:

    • Sub items: Household, Medical, Personal Insurance, Pets, Transportation, Utilities, Debt Payments, Miscellaneous Enter a monthly $ figure for each subcategory and Excel will calculate the Yearly amount. Category/Subcategory Definitions (you enter the data at the subcategory level): Household: Housekeeper (e.g. entire amount or your share if you roommates), House (e.g. sheets, towels, hardware), Magazines/Papers, Postage/Shipping (e.g. US Post Office, FedEx), Other Medical: Counseling/Therapy (e.g. LCSW, Psychologist, Psychiatrist), Physical Therapy, Dentist, Doctors, Hospital, Vision, Medicine, Insurance Premiums (your portion if you work for a company, total amount if you work for yourself) Personal Insurance: Life Insurance (e.g. Term or Whole Life), Long Term Disability (provides income if you are too ill to work), Personal Liability (e.g. provides protection from law suits) Pets: Food (e.g. dog food), Vet (e.g. yearly checkup, keeping shots current), Grooming (e.g. monthly grooming), Boarding (e.g. while you are on a trip) Transportation Car (this applies to each car you own): Car Loan Payments, Gas, Insurance, Improvements (e.g. paint job), Maintenance (e.g. Major Service, Minor Service), Registration. Go to Auto Loan Calculator to get the amount of car loan payments you must make (assuming you have to buy a car). On the Web site you need to enter: auto price, loan term (months), interest rate, down payment, trade-in value and sales tax. Use a 36 month loan term, don't assume any trade-in-value and use 6% for the sales tax. Don then used the “monthly pay” from the "Auto Loan Calculator" in his auto loan payment cell. He assumed both he and his spouse had purchased $20,000 cars and were making the same car payments. Public Transportation: Train/Bus/Subway (e.g. using them to go to work instead of driving, using them for personal travel), Taxi, Car Rental (e.g. Zip Car because you don’t have your own car) Utilities: Cell (monthly cell phone bill), Land Line (e.g. monthly New York Bell phone bill), Cable/Internet (might be bundled in cable or part of AT&T), Standard Utilities (e.g. even if you are in an apartment you pay utilities): Electricity, Gas, Water and Sewer/Garbage Debt Payments: Student Loans (e.g. you have a loan from college), Credit Card (hopefully you are not borrowing money via your 20%/month credit card), Other Loans Miscellaneous: Personal (e.g. something personal that doesn’t fit into another category), Other (e.g. something that doesn’t fit into another category – you may want to enter a small number here

item.title: Web Sites - Economics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

There are a large number of Web sites to assist you in this assignment. Each step has links to the appropriate Web sites, instructions on how to use them and how you use the Web site output in your Excel model. Web sites are categorized as: Salary, Taxes, Locations, Housing and Eduation. Using Google you can find other Web sites for doing the same thing, e.g. Affordable Housing, Salary Guidelines and Auto Loans. If you find Web sites that you find valuable pass them along to Don@My-Right-Career.com and they may be added to this Resource list.

Salary

Salary by Job Type Measure your job compensation to the closest match in this database by searching on job title and location. Compare over a thousand job descriptions in over 300 U.S. cities. Know the base pay and the total cash compensation (bonuses) for the job you want, before you negotiate! See concise and informative data, quickly and easily. Be informed and maximize your earning potential.

Taxes

Federal Income Taxes In the United States, your gross income after tax and deductions is the "actual income" you will bring home. If you are an employee, your employer will withhold your tax and deductions from your paycheck. If you are self-employed, you are responsible for submitting your taxes either every quarter or every year, and paying for your own benefits. This Web site assists you in calculating your specific Federal Income tax, Social Security tax and the Medicare tax. It doesn’t provide state income taxes. State Income Taxes View relative tax rates across the U.S. based on the lowest, average, or highest tax brackets. The site will then help you calculate your specific state taxes.

Locations

Location Info You can use this Web site to research cities in which you have an interest. Examples of reports you can get are: Salary Calculator (What are you worth? Compare your salary in different cities.), Cost of Living (Is it really less expensive to live in the suburbs? What if you work in the city? Is LA more expensive than NYC or Boston?), City Profile (Gives you a snapshot of demographics, finances, economics and other quality-of-life factors so you can find a place where you'll feel at home.) Apartments Find apartments anywhere in the US via the Official Site of the National Association of REALTORS®. Homes Find homes anywhere in the US via the Official Site of the National Association of REALTORS®.
Craigslist Find almost anything via Craigslist. There is a unique Craigslist for most areas, e.g. San Francisco Bay area.

Housing Loans

House Affordability Explore how much you can borrow. Enter your annual income (you may want to only enter the income of the person who will be working if you have children – that is what Don did). Keep the following the same as in the model: “your planned loan term” at 30 years, “interest rate” at 6% and “percentage of down payment” at 20%. Hit “Submit” to receive the amount of money you can borrow, e.g. $300,000. There are two estimates, use the Safe one (debt to income rate of 28%). Round that off and use it as your loan payment below. Click on Don House Affordability to see a pdf of Don’s inputs and outputs using the Web site.
House Mortgage Calculator. Enter the Principal Balance from above, the Annual Interest Rate, the Amortization Length (e.g. 30 years). Leave the Starting month already entered. Pick “Monthly” as the payment method. Hit “Submit” to receive your Monthly Payment (e.g. $1,288). Enter that amount in the monthly Mortgage Payment field in the top of the page of your Lodging worksheet.Click on Don's Mortgage Payments to see a pdf of Don’s inputs and outputs using the Web site.

Car Loans

Go to Auto Loan Calculator to get the amount of car loan payments you must make (assuming you have to buy a car). On the Web site you need to enter: auto price, loan term (months), interest rate, down payment, trade-in value and sales tax. Use a 36 month loan term, don't assume any trade-in-value and use 6% for the sales tax. You can then enter the “monthly pay” from the "Auto Loan Calculator" in your auto loan payment cell.

College Cost & Trust Funds

Go to College Cost to estimate future college cost and the amount you will need to save to pay for college. When a child is born, it can be hard to imagine that he or she will be heading off to college in a few short years. The reality is, however, that starting early can reap significant benefits when it comes to saving for higher education. Use the BlackRock Cost of Waiting College Savings Calculator to estimate your child's future college costs and compare the lump-sum and monthly savings you will need to put aside if you begin investing for college now and at various intervals in the future. On the Web site you will need to enter: Average cost in today's dollars, e.g $40,000, Years until college (assume 18), Years in college (assume 4), College Cost Inflation (4% is a good assumption) and Return on your investment (6% is a good assumption). The model will tell you how much you will need to save/month. Don assumed he would send his kids to a college that cost $50,000/year in today's dollars. In 18 years that same college will cost $518,000 for four years (vs. $200,000 today). He will need to start saving $1,340/month once his first child is born to pay for that college. He plans on having two kids so that amount more than doubles.

Education – Dummies Series

Overview: You do not need to use these educational resources to complete the Economic Engine assignment. But they might help you out on the basics. Budgeting Does the word “budget” send chills up your spine? It shouldn’t. Budgets allow you to have some control over what you spend. A monthly budget can help you to decide how to spend your money, plan for your future, and pay off existing debt, and save a few pennies each month by reducing wasteful and impulsive purchases. Net Worth (Balance Sheet) A net worth statement is simply a listing of all that you own and all that you owe. The difference between what you own and what you owe is your net worth. Your net worth is like a financial report card because it reveals a lot about you. In fact, people tend to be more comfortable talking about their sex lives than their financial lives. No one can prove whether someone has been a fantastic lover. However, one glance at a net worth statement, and you have a pretty good idea whether a person has made a lot of financial mistakes, had terrible misfortune, has been a fantastic money manager, or is just darn lucky. Excel This online course covers the basics of creating Excel spreadsheets, creating and using formulas and functions, and formatting worksheets. You will move at your own pace through three interactive lessons, discovering how worksheets work, how to add and edit content, what formulas and functions do, and how to format your spreadsheet to best demonstrate your data. In each lesson, you'll find clear, expert instruction, interactive quizzes, hands-on activities, summaries, and a way to review topics so you can progress at your own pace.

item.title: Step 5 - Optional: Financials of Raising a Family
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Maybe you have started to think about having a family. Most likely you want to wait until you meet the right person, get married and live together for awhile before bringing someone else into your life. You may have thought about the timing, e.g. not until after age 30 and not until we are financially more stable. So what will it cost to raise a child? What if you want two or three children? The United States Department of Agriculture Department publishes an annual report on what families spend on their children from Age 0 to Age 17. There are also a couple of interesting articles, one in the Wall Street Journal and one in the New York Times, that use the USDA report as the basis for their analysis.

What are the USDA Findings?

The USDA report only address the expenses from Age 0 to Age 17. Click on USDA Expenditures on Children 2011 to see the USDA report. It provides the data using two variables:

Categories of Expenses

The USDA breaks down the expenses into the following categories: Housing, Food, Transportation, Clothing, Health Care, Child Care/Education and Miscellaneous.

Income Levels

Household income and child-raising expenses are positively correlated, i.e. the more you make, the more you spend on your children. The amount of money spent on a child in the highest income group (average income of $178,000) was more than twice that spent by a family in the lowest income group (average income of $38,000). The lowest income group spent $183,000, the middle income group spent $250,000 and the highest income group spent $415,000. But as a % of income the families in the highest income group spent only 12% of their income on their children compared to the 25% spent by families in the lowest income group. Families in the middle income group (average income of $79,000) spent 16%. Edward is projecting he will earn $100,000 by Age 30 and probably start a family by Age 32. He will be in the highest income group during the time he is raising his children so the USDA report projects him spending $415,000 per child from Age 0 to Age 17.

What about College Expenses?

Since you are just finishing or have finished college it is likely you will want your children to go to college as well. Maybe you will want them to go to a college as good as or better than the one you attended. Go to College Cost to estimate future college cost and the amount you will need to save to pay for college. When a child is born, it can be hard to imagine that he or she will be heading off to college in a few short years. The reality is, however, that starting early can reap significant benefits when it comes to saving for higher education. Use the BlackRock Cost of Waiting College Savings Calculator to estimate your child's future college costs and compare the lump-sum and monthly savings you will need to put aside if you begin investing for college now and at various intervals in the future. On the Web site you will need to enter: Average cost in today's dollars, e.g $40,000, Years until college (assume 18), Years in college (assume 4), College Cost Inflation (4% is a good assumption) and Return on your investment (6% is a good assumption). The model will tell you how much you will need to save/month. Edward assumed he would send his kids to a college that cost $50,000/year in today's dollars. In 18 years that same college will cost $518,000 for four years (vs. $200,000 today). He will need to start saving $1,340/month once his first child is born to pay for that college. He plans on having two kids so that amount more than doubles.

Maybe it is Even Higher

Two articles have been written that say, for higher income parents, the cost of rearing a child are significantly higher than the USDA estimates.

The Million Dollar Kid - Wall Street Journal

Go to Million Dollar Kid to see how the Wall Street Journal deconstructed the government's approach (note they were using the USDA 2007 report as their starting point, not 2011) and recalculated it using a different range of costs. Below are some quotes from the article: Escalating kid spending is more rampant among wealthier households, so we used the government's top-third income bracket as a starting point. We also added some costs that aren't included in that government calculation, such as college-savings plans, which a growing number of households are setting up for their kids. We placed all these expenses on a spectrum, from those that parents and experts say are the most common, up to more unusual -- and costly -- frills. At the lowest end, our estimates came in at about $800,000 (in 2007 dollars) through the age of 17. Add in extras like private school, a nanny and a flat-screen TV set in a kid's bedroom, and that figure climbs to $1.6 million. Some of the costs can add up quickly. For parents whose kids are passionate athletes, for instance, baseball equipment, including helmets, cleats and uniforms, costs in the realm of $3,000 from the age of 10 to 17 -- and taking it one step further by enrolling in an elite youth team can pile on a further $12,500 for annual travel expenses. Fully half of American teenagers now own MP3 players, according to research by the Pew Internet & American Life Project; a year of daily iTunes downloads for these kids -- their version of a daily latte fix -- comes to $361 and change. The biggest and most common driver is education. One in 10 children now goes to private or parochial school. Even at a relatively modest tuition at a parochial school of $6,000 a year, that would add $60,000 or more to the government's total figure of $36,000 for education and child care. Likewise, academic extras are becoming routine; the average income of a family seeking tutoring for a child is between $50,000 and $75,000, according to Eduventures, a Boston-based market-research firm.

It is even more expensive - New York Times

Go to Another View of Raising a Child Expenses to see how the author estimated her cost of raising a child. She concluded it would cost $1.8M. She also used the USDA report as her starting point and then tailored it to her geography (NYC) and situation. She stuck with the USDA's estimates for food, transportation, clothing and miscellaneous for a two-parent household in the Urban Northeast in the top earning group (over $103,000). The largest "cost" she added was her lost income for being a working Mom - lost wages while on Maternity Leave and earning only 73% of a male's income (vs. 90% if not a mother). This working Mom "cost" came to $700,000 over the 18 years.

Your Cost of Raising your Children

Don's Example

Click on Edward's Having a Family Financials to see how much Edward has estimated it would cost him to raise two kids. His total cost is almost $700,000 per child or a total of almost $1.4M for his two planned children. He assumed he would be in the highest Income group and used the USDA Age 0 to Age 17 cost data, showing he will spend $414,000 per child. This figure will probably be higher if he provides his kids the same benefits his parents provided him, e.g. playing on elite sports teams (including private coaches), private high school and tutors. He then assumed he would send his kids to a college that was as expensive as the one he attended ($50,000/year), which will cost him $238,000 per child. Last he assumed he would spend $40,000 in post college expenses on each child for items like them living at home after college, helping them buy their first home and money for grandchildren.

Your Estimate

Click on Template Raising Family Budget to download an Excel file you can use as a template. Change the name of the file to YourName-Raising_Family_Budget.xls. The top part of the Excel spreadsheet (Your Situation) is where you enter your information. Just enter your information in the cells with a box around them. This is Edward's example. Income Group: First decide on the Income group by entering the Income you feel you will have around the time you will have your first child. Age 0 to 17 Expenses: If it is over $102,000 you are then in the highest income bracket and would use those USDA expenses ($414,240) for the column titled Age 0 to 17. College: For the column titled College decide what college cost level (in today's dollars) you plan for your child. If you are going to a $40,000 college (total cost = Tuition, Room/Board, Other Expenses) you may want to plan on sending your child to a school in the same cost range. You can decide you will only pay for 50% of their college education and let them pay for the rest through scholarships and student loans. If so you would only have to save for a $20,000 college to send them to a $40,000 college. Post College: This would cover items like them living at home after college, helping them buy their first home and money for grandchildren. Total: To get your Total you need to decide on many children you will have. If your children are several years apart the costs will be higher because of inflation but this is a adequate estimate.

item.title: Step 11 - Summary-Economics
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

As we told you earlier, you will discover there is almost nothing in life that does’t have a financial dimension to it, even deciding to get married or have children, two of the most personal decisions in life. You can find a career at which you can Be your Best because it leverages your Strengths, Skills and Personality. That same career may have enormous Meaning to you and you work with great Passion. But if society doesn’t value that career enough to Fuel Your Economic Engine it probably is not your Right Career. If it doesn’t pay you enough to support your family in a reasonable manner it is probably not your Right Career. You get to decide what is reasonable.

Tracking your Expenses

In a video about managing your money one group said there are three things you must do: 1) Start with a goal (e.g. save for a car, pay down your college debt), 2) Create a Plan (a Budget) and 3) Track your Expenses (keep track of everything you spend and put them in categories). You can track your expenses by putting all your receipts and credit cards in a box. Then you can enter that data into an accounting system like Mint.

Living within Your Budget

It is a lot easier to come up with some numbers that solve to a balance budget, than it is to actually not spend more than you make each month. If you think you will have the problem of running out of money at the end of the month (or already do have that problem) here is an interesting simple solution;

Fool Proof Your Budget

Click on the link above to watch a brief (1 minute) video explaining the Envelope approach to staying within your budget each month.

item.title: Measure Your Life
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

You will answer three basic questions. How can I be sure I will be successful and happy in my career? How can I be sure that my relationships with my spouse, my children, my extended family and close friends become an enduring source of happiness? How can I live a life of integrity — and stay out of jail? Estimated time is 2 hours.
This exercise is simple enough we will only use the Short Instruction approach. You will be given a very minor amount of explanation and some examples.

Instructions

To begin click on Measure Your Life Instructions

item.title: Step 9 - Provide Feedback-Econ
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We making changes to the MyRightCareer Program and Web site in almost real time so your timely feedback is very important. Students coming after you will benefit from it.
Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree.
Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. When you finish please email Don@My-Right-Career.com
Click here to take survey

item.title: Step 7 - Discuss with Adviser-Econ
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Now it is time to discuss your results with your Adviser. You may have been communicating with them along the way so they may already know some of what you have done, e.g. you might have shared your Age 30 and Age 22 Budgets with them. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

Discuss Content Issues

    Age 30 Budget: Share your budget and your insights. Age 22 Budget: Share your budget and your insights. Optional Exercises: If you did any of these then consider sharing them with your Adviser. This is especially true if you feel you need some guidance or help.
  • - Age 22 Non-Professional Budget: If you think there is a chance you will not work in your chosen field for awhile then discuss the economic reality of that situation.  - Financials of Buying a House: If you are interested in purchasing a house before you are 30 discuss that with your Adviser. While they may not be able to give you good advice they probably know people who could. - Financials of Raising a Family: If you plan on having a family consider discussing the financial implications with your Adviser
    MyRightCareer Insights documents:: These are the most important documents you will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. These documents must be discussed.

    Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
    Schedule: You have now done a lot of exercises and you should have a handle on the schedule by now. Adviser Review Process: Most likely you have now settled into a process that works for the two of you, e.g. how you communicate, how you review. Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing these exercises.

item.title: Step 10 - Become Example-Econ
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the same process we used in the previous exercise.

A) Send your completed exercises to Don

Send all of your completed material for this exercise to Don: StrengthsFinder Report, Strengths/Talents Insights, Strengths Ideas for Action and Ideas for Action Insights. He will review it and remove anything he feels would disclose your personal identity, e.g. names of friends, high school name, college name. He will conform the file names, headings, etc to the standards used on all the other examples (if you used the templates this will not require much work). He will append your "stage name" to the front of all of the files.

B) Review and comment on Don's Exercise files

Don will send you the proposed exercise files. You should review them and suggest any changes you would like made, e.g. drop this information, reword this information.

C) Don will load your Example on Examples page

He will add these examples to your section on the Examples page. Individual pieces of your example may be integrated into the Full Instructions. As Don gets more examples he will use examples he feels do a good job explaining key ideas. Your example may be used on Exercise #2 and then not again until Exercise #4 and #5.

item.title: Step 6 - Add to MyRightCareer Insights-Econ
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey's examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: You have now identified a how you are going to balance your income and expense, some of them are related to your natural personality and strengths. Add insights you have gained to this file. You should be able to find a lot of insights, just like Don did. - Meaning & Passion: Are there areas where you economic interests and your passion intersect? It is very normal for you to find meaning and have passion for things that interest you. - Fuel your Economic Engine: Do you see how you can leverage your interests to fuel you economic engine. Do you see how your Whole Person may cause you to require more fuel. - Right Opportunities: What careers and jobs did you identify? - Whole Person: Your Whole Person parameters (e.g. where you want to live, your vacation desires, if you want to own a home) have a huge impact on your Budget.
