item.title: Meaning Insights
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Your assignment involves these steps: 1) Review your existing MyRC-MeaningPassion-Insights file, 2) Create a Meaning Insights Summary, 3) Provide feedback, 4) Discuss your completed exercise with your Adviser and 5) Become an Example. The Basic Assignment (Steps 1 & 2) will take you about 2 hours.

Meaning/Passion Approach

The 2nd circle in the Right Career Venn diagram is Meaning/Passion. By now you have completed a lot of exercises that don't address the subject directly (e.g. Begin at the End, Autobiography, Personality) but may have prompted some thoughts about what has meaning for you and for what you have a passion. In this Assignment you have completed some exercises (Stories, Drivers, Measure Your Life) that are designed to more directly address the Meaning/Passion subject. This exercise, Meaning Insights, provided you with an opportunity to reach a conclusion on what has meaning to you and for what you have passion.

Instructions

To begin click on Meaning Insights Instructions

item.title: Instructions-Measure
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

Your assignment involves these steps: 1) Read "How Will You Measure Your Life" article, 2) Answer the three questions, 3) Provide feedback, 4) Discuss your completed exercise with your Adviser and 5) Become an Example. The Basic Assignment (Steps 1 & 2) will take you about 2 hours.

1) Read "How Will You Measure Your Life" article

Click on "How Will You Measure Your Life" article. This is a short summary of the original text from Clayton Christensen's "How Will You Measure Your Life" book. Here are some quotes from the article. Every five years, Clayton Christensen and his peers gathered for a reunion at the Harvard Business School. As a group, they clearly had much to celebrate: They had wonderful jobs, they had made great achievements, and some were financially successful beyond their wildest dreams. But behind the facade of professional success, Christensen observed something was not right. Many of his peers were clearly not happy. At graduation, they had plans and visions for what they would accomplish, not just in their careers, but in their personal lives as well. Yet, at reunions, he realized that something had gone wrong for some of them along the way. Their personal relationships had begun to deteriorate, even as their professional prospects blossomed. For others, careers that began with great promise and reached the pinnacle of success had come crashing down. No one graduates from business school with a deliberate strategy to get divorced, lose touch with their children, or make choices that land you in jail. Yet this is the exact strategy that too many people end up implementing.

2) Answer the three questions

Christen's three questions are:
  • 1) How can I be sure I will be successful and happy in my career?
  • 2) How can I be sure that my relationships with my spouse, my children, my extended family and close friends become an enduring source of happiness?
  • 3) How can I live a life of integrity — and stay out of jail?
    Below are two examples of answering those three questions:
    Casey's Measure Your Life
    Edward's Measure Your Life
    You can use Casey's example as your Template or just use a blank Word document:
    Measure Your Life Template

    3) Provide feedback

    You will provide feedback for all the Meaning Exercises at the end of the Meaning Insights Exercise.

    4) Discuss your exercise with your Adviser

    You should wait until you have finished all of your Meaning Exercises before you discuss them with your Adviser.

    5) Become an Example

    You can can wait until you have finished all of the Meaning Exercises and then send them all to Don to turn into Examples.

item.title: Talents/Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

In this exercise you need to: 1) Take StrengthsFinder 2.0 assessment, 2) Create your Talents/Strenghts Insights, 3) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights document the insights you have gained from this exercise, 4) Discuss the exercise with your Facilitator, 5) Provide Feedback and 6) Become an example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. In total the first four steps will probably take you about 3 hours.
If you click on Strengths Checklist you will get the pdf document that is the Checklist for the sub-exercises in the exercise. You can use this to keep track of your progress and to communicate your progress to your Facilitator. They will have a copy of the same Checklist. There is the native Excel version of this file on the Templates page.
There are two approaches you can take to complete exercises: Short Instructions or Full Instructions. You can also use a hybrid approach in at least two different ways: 1) Use the Short Instructions for one Step and then switch to the Full Instructions on another Step if you need more help or 2) Use the Short Instructions on a Step until you need more help on that Step and then go directly to the Full Instructions on that Step for more instructions.

click on Short Instructions Approach

If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples the Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine. It is basically listening to a 5 minute video and using examples to do your work.

click on Step 0 - Introduction

If you would like a full set of instructions, which includes the same 5 minute video and instructions with multiple examples integrated into the text, then the Full Instructions Approach will work better.

item.title: Instructions-Stories
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

Write stories about at least two of your Major Accomplishments you enjoyed doing. Write a story about an accomplishment you did not enjoy doing, but still are proud of completing.
To complete this step you should have your list of Top Accomplishments from the Accomplishments Exercise. If you did not complete the Accomplishments Exercise you have several choices:
  • Go back to the Autobiography Assignment and complete "Step 1 - Write Your Autobiography". Then go to the Accomplishments Assignment and using your Autobiography, complete "Step 1 - List of Accomplishments" and "Step 2 - List of Top Accomplishments". This is probably the easiest way and certainly the most complete way to arrive at your Top Accomplishments
  • Go back the Accomplishments Assignment and complete "Step 1 - List of All Accomplishments" and "Step 2 - List of Top Accomplishments". This assumes you can identify your "List of All Accomplishments" without creating your Autobiography.
  • Go back the Accomplishments Assignment and complete "Step 2 - List of Top Accomplishments". This assumes you can identify your Top Accomplishments without your "List of All Accomplishments".
  • Create your Stories without referencing your Accomplishments, e.g. the two stories I want to write are X & Y.

    1) Write a 1 page Story for each Accomplishment

    When I say a “one” page story don’t take that literally. Most people write stories (including insights) that range from 3/4 of a page to 2 pages. Just don’t get carried away and write a 5 page short story.
    Click on Edward's Newspaper Story for Edward's story about “Founding & running the college newspaper” when he was a junior in college. It is an example of a one page story.

    2) Document your Insights

    Click on Edward's Newspaper Story Insights for his insights of “Founding & running the College newspaper”. Edward incorporated his insights within the story by highlighting portions of the text in bold red and then providing an INSIGHT statement in bold blue after the highlighted section.
    Click on Casey's Soccer Endurance for her story about building up her soccer endurance. Casey combined her story and her story insights into one file. Her Insights are at the end of the file.

    3) Provide feedback

    You will provide feedback for all the Meaning Exercises at the end of the Meaning Insights Exercise.

    4) Discuss your exercise with your Adviser

    You should wait until you have finished all of your Meaning Exercises before you discuss them with your Adviser.

    5) Become an Example

    You can can wait until you have finished all of the Meaning Exercises and then send them all to Don to turn into Examples.

item.title: Instructions-Drivers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

To help you complete the exercise here are Casey's Examples and a Word template:
Casey's Examples: Casey's Top Drivers List Casey's Drivers Insights
Template: Click on Drivers Template and you will download a Word file that will be your template for this exercise.

1) Identify your Top 10 Drivers, besides money

Highlight those Drivers you believe are your top 10. You may have to make multiple passes to arrive at the true Top 10 Drivers. When you are done your document should look like Casey's Top Drivers List.

2) Document the insights you gained

Use the file you just created as the template for this step. Make a copy of the file and rename it YourName-Drivers_Insights. Now remove all the Drivers that are not on your Top 10 list (i.e. the ones that are not highlighted).
Spend some time thinking about how your life, so far, has been affected by the Drivers you have identified. Have your past roles and organizations met those Drivers? Have you left roles because they did not meet those Drivers? Do you find yourself attracted to new roles, organizations or industries because they fulfill certain of those Drivers? The insights you identify may help you identify your Right Career. You should add insights for each drive and then some general insights. When you are done it should look like Casey's Drivers Insights

3) Provide feedback

You will provide feedback for all the Meaning Exercises at the end of the Meaning Insights Exercise.

item.title: Short Instructions-Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine.

0) Introduction

Strengths Concept in 2 minutes Video

Click on the link above to see a video where Marcus Buckingham provides a quick overview of the Strengths concept via a simple example. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.
To see a longer video where Marcus Buckingham describes the Strengths concept in more detail and more importantly the two myths that hold 80% of people back from leveraging their natural strengths click on Step 0 - Introduction-Strengths in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

1) StrengthsFinder 2.0 Assessment

You need to do an assessment before you can do the actual exercises (which use the outputs of the assessment).
To see an example of the output click on Casey's StrengthsFinder2 Report To find out how to access the assessment click on Step 1 - StrengthsFinder 2.0 Assessment in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

2) Strengths Awareness

In the StrengthsFinder 2.0 Report, study Section I (Awareness), which describe what makes you stand out from others with the same theme in their top five.
For an example click on Casey's StrengthsFinder2 Report
Create a one page summary of what you have learned by looking at all five Top Talents. You most likely have common themes running through your Top Talents.
For an example click on Casey's Strengths Insights.
If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 2 - Strengths Awareness in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

3) Ideas for Action

In the StrengthsFinder2 Report (Section II - Action Planning Guide) there are 10 Recommended Actions you can take for each of your Five Top Talents.
For an example click on Casey's Action Planning Guide
Pick at least three of the 10 Ideas for Action for each of your top five themes that you would like to implement during the next year. Create a one page summary of what you have learned by looking at all your Ideas for Action. If you picked three for each of your Top 5 Talents you will have 30 Ideas for Action. You most likely have common themes running through those 30 Ideas for Action.
For an example click on Casey's Ideas for Action Insights. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 3 - Structural Tension in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

4) Document your MyRightCareer Insights

These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights
If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 4 - Create your MyRightCareer Insights Document in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

5) Discuss your Results with Your Adviser

Click on Step 5 - Discuss your Results with Your Adviser in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

6) Provide Feedback

Discuss the output of Steps 1, 2, 3 & 4 above. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on Step 6 - Provide Feedback in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

7) Become an Example

Send your completed exercises to Don. Click on Step 7 - Become an Example in the Sub Navigation panel on the right to find out more.

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Strengths Concept

Strengths Concept in 2 minutes Video

Click on the link above to see a video where Marcus Buckingham provides a quick overview of the Strengths concept via a simple example. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.

Strengths Concept & Two Myths Holding You Back Video

Click on the link above to see a video where Marcus Buckingham describes the Strengths concept in more detail and more importantly the two myths that hold 80% of people back from leveraging their natural strengths.
  • Myth #1 - As you grow you will change Truth - As you grow you will become more and more of who you already are (in regards to your personality)
  • Myth #2 - You will grow the most in your areas of weakness. Truth - You will grow the most in your areas of strengths. While you can grow in an area of weakness it will be minimal and it will be painful (you do have to figure out how to compensate or work around areas of weakness).
    For those of you who like to read, the StrengthsFinder 2.0 book Part I (Finding Your Strengths - An Introduction) provides an explanation of the strengths concept. Marcus Buckingham co-authored, with Donald Clifton (the father of the Strengths Movement), "Now, Discover Your Strengths". While it was written in 2000 it is still a very good description of the strengths concept and how to apply it in your life. Click on Gallup Strengths Center to access a wide range of Strengths material. In the next Step (StrengthsFinder 2.0 Assessment) you will go to a different section of this Web site to purchase a code to take the StrengthsFinder 2.0 Assessment.

item.title: Adviser Guidance-Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If the Strengths concept is new to you click on Step 0 - Introduction and watch the two videos by Marcus Buckingham: "Strengths Concept in 2 Minutes" and "Strengths Concept and Two Myths Holding You Back" (7 minutes). You should also watch the Welcome to Strengths video. It will give you the basic idea for this exercise and it is less than 5 minutes long.

Introduction

Here are some basic ideas you should keep in mind as they do this exercise:

StrengthsFinder Report

Casey's StrengthsFinder2 Report

Strengths/Talents Insights

Casey's Strengths Insights

Strengths Ideas for Action

Casey's Action Planning Guide

Ideas for Action Insights

Casey's Ideas for Action Insights

MyRightCareer Insights

These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. They will be accumulating their insights about that circle as they finish each exercise. This makes it easier for them to draw conclusions during the Capstone Project - which is probably quite a few weeks away. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached.
From the Interests exercise they should get some great insights for the "Be Your Best" file because they will have identified their interests. They will also be receiving their 2nd direct recommendations that can be used in the "Right Careers" file.
These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. They will be accumulating their insights about that circle as they finish each exercise. This makes it easier for them to draw conclusions during the Capstone Project - which is probably quite a few weeks away. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Optional Personal Usage

Below are two examples that can be of value to an Adviser or Career Advisory Board Member if you want to use the MyRightCareer System for your own life. If you want to complete this use the same templates the students use. You will notice Matt and Bud's formats are slightly different than the students.
StrengthsFinder Report
Strengths/Talents Insights
Strengths Ideas for Action
Ideas for Action Insights

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:
  • Look at an example close to your students profile. That will give you a good idea of what your student's final output should resemble.
  • See if your student needs any help while they are completing the exercise.
  • Check to see their progress via the Exercise Checklist. If they don't already have it you should suggest it as a good tool for communicating their status.
  • Once they complete this exercise, review it and then have your dialogue
  • Provide me feedback on any insights you have on the student and the Program, as well as any insights on your Adviser role.

    Feedback

    We would like your feed back on the Exercise. We would also like your feedback on the Adviser role, your interaction with your student and the support we are providing you. We would like you to take the SurveyMonkey survey in this section after you finish your work with your student. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. You can also provide feedback by sending Don an email (Don@My-Right-Career.com) or calling him at 650-400-8929.

item.title: Short Instructions-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are the type of person who only needs a very minor amount of explanation and some examples this Short Instructions Approach will probably work just fine.

0) Introduction

One of the more important elements in identifying your Right Career is recognizing the skills you have that you really enjoy using. If you enjoy doing something you will usually do it really well, allowing you to Be Your Best. Those skills will most likely be ones for which you have a Passion. They may also be ones which have Meaning for you.
O*NET Skills Search is designed to help you use your skill set to identify occupations for exploration. You select a set of skills from six broad groups of skills to create your customized skill list. If you want more instructions on the O*NET Skills System click on "0 - Introduction" in the Sub Navigation Menu on the right.

1) Select Your Skills

All Your Skills: Click on O*NET Skills Search to start your Skills evaluation. Once you have identified your skills print that file to a pdf so you can save it. We suggest you name it YourName-Skills-All. Click on Edward's Skills to see the pdf file Edward created from his Skills Search.
Skills You Enjoy Using: Click on Edward's Skills he Enjoys. Once you have identified the skills you enjoy using, print that file to a pdf so you can save it. We suggest you name it YourName-Skills-Enjoy.
If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 1 - Select Your Skills" in the Sub Navigation Menu on the right.

2) Identify the Occupations that use your Skills

When you have finished entering the "Skills You Enjoy" click on the Go button at the bottom of the Skills section. Your selected skills are compared to skill ratings for each occupation. If a selected skill is rated "Important" for a particular occupation, it is considered a match.
Click on Edward's Occupations Suggested and see which Occupations the system suggests for Edward's Skills he enjoys using (he did the yellow highlighting, not O*NET).
Now create a report for each Occupation of interest showing the skills required. Below are reports showing which of Edward's skills are used for each of those Occupations: - Chief Executives - Treasurers and Controllers - Lawyers
If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "2 - Occupation/Skills Match" in the Sub Navigation Menu on the right.

3) Review Specific Occupations

Now you are going to take a deeper look at Occupations that interest you. As mentioned earlier Edward is trying to decide what he does after graduation from engineering school - work as an engineer, go get an MBA (to work in business) or go to Law School. To help him understand the business and law areas he looked at the following in more depth: - Chief Executives - Treasurers and Controllers - Lawyers
If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 3 - Review Specific Occupations" in the Sub Navigation Menu on the right.

4) Create Insights

It is time to document what you have learned from examining your skills and potential Occupations. Edward is trying to decide if he should go out and work as an engineer, go get an MBA or go get a Law degree. Click on Edward's Skills Insights to see his conclusions.
If you want to see the Full Instructions click "Step 4 - Creating Insights" in the Sub Navigation Menu on the right.

5) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights

These five documents are examples of the insights obtained from completing all the exercises except Economic Engine: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories and Drivers. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Edward's "Be Your Best" Insights Edward's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Edward's "Economic Engine" Insights Edward's "Right Career" Insights Edward's "Whole Person" Insights
Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 6 - MyRightCareer Insights" in the Sub Navigation Menu on the right.

6) Provide your Feedback

Click on Feedback to access the SurveyMonkey survey for a student.

7) Discuss your Results with Your Adviser.

Discuss the output of Steps 1 through 5 above. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 7 - Discuss your Results with Your Adviser" in the Sub Navigation Menu on the right.

8) Become an Example

Send Don your completed exercises. If you want to see the Full Instructions click on "Step 8 - Become an Example" in the Sub Navigation Menu on the right.
9) Summary

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

One of the more important elements in identifying your Right Career is recognizing the skills you have that you really enjoy using. If you enjoy doing something you will usually do it really well, allowing you to Be Your Best. Those skills will most likely be ones for which you have a Passion. They may also be ones which have Meaning for you.
Click On-Line Skills Help The Skills Search function is designed to help you use your skill set to identify occupations for exploration. You select a set of skills from six broad groups of skills to create your customized skill list. Begin by selecting skills from one or more of the six skill groups identified: Basic Skills, Complex Problem Solving Skills, Resource Management Skills, Social Skills, Systems Skills, and Technical Skills. item.title: Adviser Guidance-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You should watch the Welcome to Skills video at the minimum. It will give you the basic idea for this exercise and it is less than 5 minutes long.

Introduction

Here are some basic ideas you should keep in mind as you do this exercise:

Autobiography

Make sure they don't get carried away and write a true Autobiography. It should just be an outline. Casey's Autobiography

Transitions

At their age they should have made a lot of transitions because every thing they do is new, e.g. going from one elementary school to middle school, going from for fun soccer to serious soccer. There are a lot of insights that can come from these transitions. Casey's Autobiography Insights

MyRightCareer Insights documents

These are the most important documents they will be creating during the program. They should have taken all of their findings in this exercise and placed them in the appropriate document - Be Your Best, Meaning/Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career and Whole Person. They will be accumulating their insights about each circle as they finish each exercise. This makes it easier for them to draw conclusions during the Capstone Project - which is probably quite a few weeks away. Make sure they are documenting any insights, more is better, they have reached. A lot of time all they have to do is copy the insights from documents they have already created during the exercise, e.g. there is an insights document for their Age 30 Vision. Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Experienced Adult Example

Below is an example that can help you understand the Exercise. There are more Experienced Adult examples at the end of the Examples page, which you can access from the Sub Navigation Panel on the right. Skills List Bud used the same O*NET system the college students use to identify his skills, i.e. he picked them from the list provided by the O*NET system. Occupations List The O*NET system then produced a list of Occupations that use those skills. The list starts with the occupations that use the most of his skills and then goes down. Bud highlighted in yellow the occupations of most interest to him. CEO Skills Required vs. Bud's Skills The O*NET System produces a report showing the skills required for the CEO role and then shows which of those Bud has. There is a similar report for the Treasurer-Controller role. One of the skills Bud lacks for both roles is Active Listening. CEO Summary Report The O*NET System has a comprehensive report for each Occupation. It has links at the end to other information about that Occupation. Insights Bud created his insights from this exercise Optional Usage by Adviser To get started using the MyRightCareer System for your own career click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right.

Next Steps

Your Next Steps should be:
  • Look at an example close to your students profile. That will give you a good idea of what your student's final output should resemble.
  • See if your student needs any help while they are completing the exercise. You may be able to help them.
  • Check to see their progress via the Exercise Checklist. If they don't already have it you should suggest it as a good tool for communicating their status.
  • Once they complete this exercise, review it and then have your dialogue
  • Provide me feedback on any insights you have on the student and the Program, as well as any insights on your Adviser role.
Optionally you can:
  • Look at an Experienced Adult Example closer to your situation - they are on the Examples page.
  • Complete the exercise for your situation. click on the "Experienced Adult" heading in the Sub Navigation panel on the right

Feedback

We would like your feed back on the Exercise. We would also like your feedback on the Adviser role, your interaction with your student and the support we are providing you. We would like you to take the SurveyMonkey survey in this section after you finish your work with your student. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. You can also provide feedback by sending Don an email (Don@My-Right-Career.com) or calling him at 650-400-8929.

item.title: Step 1- Select Your Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You have two tasks to complete in this step. First you must use the O*NET Skills Search system to identify your skills. Second you need to decide which of those skills are the ones you really enjoy using.

O*NET Skills

Click on O*NET Skills Search

Skills Search is designed to help you use your skill set to identify occupations for exploration. You select a set of skills from six broad groups of skills to create your customized skill list.
Click on O*NET Skills List to see the Groups and skills within each group.
Once you have identified your skills print that file to a pdf so you can save it. We suggest you name it YourName-Skills-All.
Click on Edward's Skills to see the pdf file Edward created from his Skills Search.

Identify Skills You Enjoy

Click on Edward highlighting the skills he enjoys.
He has highlighted the skills from the list above he feels he really enjoys using. You will notice he did not highlight all of the skills he feels he has. You may find you enjoy using all of the skills you have, Casey does so she didn't create a Skills she enjoys list. You don't have to actually highlight your skills. Instead you can just remove the checkmarks on the skills you have, but don't really enjoy using, and create a new Skills List.
Click on Edward's Skills he Enjoys.
Once you have identified the skills you enjoy using, print that file to a pdf so you can save it. We suggest you name it YourName-Skills-Enjoy.
The rest of the Skills Exercise is based on the Skills you enjoy using. You are more likely to do well when you are using Skills you enjoy. You are more likely to have passion for Skills you enjoy using.

item.title: Step 2 - Occupation/Skills Match
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

In this Step you are going to 1) Have the system identify some Occupations that use your skills and 2) Examine which skills are used in those Occupations. At the end of this Step you should have a couple of Occupations you want to explore some more.

Occupations/Skills Match

When you have finished identifying the "Skills You Enjoy" you click on the Go button at the bottom of the Skills section. Your selected skills are compared to skill ratings for each occupation. If a selected skill is rated "Important" for a particular occupation, it is considered a match. "Important" includes skills rated 50 or above on the standardized scale (3.0 or above on the original importance scale). Occupations matching all your selected skills are shown first, followed by those matching all but one of your selected skills, and so on. Occupations are presented that match at least 75% of your selected skills. Click on Edward's Occupations Suggested and see which Occupations the system suggests for Edward's Skills he enjoys using. He is trying to decide if he should go work as an engineer, go get an MBA or go to Law School. His top two Occupations use 12 of the 12 skills he enjoys using: - Chief Executives (e.g., CEO, President, CFO, COO, General Manager, Exec VP, Vice President) - Treasurers and Controllers (e.g., Chief Financial Officer (CFO), Comptroller, Controller, Director of Finance, Finance Vice President, Treasurer) Edward is also interested in two other Occupations: IT and Law. They both use 11 of the 12 skills he enjoys using. - Computer and Information Systems Managers (e.g., IT Director, IS Director, IT Manager) - Lawyers (e.g., Attorney, Assistant Attorney General, Deputy Attorney General, City Attorney, County Attorney, Partner, Assistant Counsel) But both of these occupations are rated as Job Zone 4 instead of Job Zone 5 like Chief Executives and Treasurers/Controllers. The Job Zone tells you how much education, experience and training is required to hold a job with that Zone Level (5 is the highest).
Edward experimented and used his full Skills list to see if it changed the Occupations suggested. Changing from Skills-All to Skills-Enjoy only made a difference where those four occupations showed up on the Occupations list. - Chief Executives (still #1 on both lists) - Treasurers and Controllers (#9 to #2) - Information Systems Managers (#23 to #10) - Lawyers (Page 4 to Page 3). In each case the occupations of interest move up on the scale by using Skills he enjoys. So in Edward's case limiting his skills to the ones he enjoys using validates that business (Chief Executives & Treasurers and Controllers) is a good area for him. It shows that working in an IT area (Information Systems Managers) is a good fit as well. It says being a Lawyer gets better, but is still way out on page 3.

Skills Used in Occupations

Below are reports showing which of Edward's skills are used for each of those Occupations: - Chief Executives - Treasurers and Controllers - Lawyers For example, the Treasurers and Controllers occupation shows that Edward has the majority of the skills that are rated as important for that Occupation. As he looks at the Occupation he likes that it uses a lot of the skills he enjoys.

item.title: Step 3 - Review Specific Occupations-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Now you are going to take a deeper look at some Occupations of interest to you.

Occupation Summary Reports

As mentioned earlier Edward is trying to decide what he does after graduation from engineering school - work as an engineer, go get an MBA (to work in business) or go to Law School. To help him understand the business and law areas he looked at the following in more depth: - Chief Executives - Treasurers and Controllers - Lawyers

Report Sections

There are many different sections in the Summary Report. Below are some important ones.
Tasks
Here you can compare the tasks you will be performing in each occupation.
Knowledge
Here you can see what types of knowledge you will need to acquire. There is a big difference between the knowledge for Lawyers and Treasurers/Controllers, although there is more overlap than you would think.
Skills
This is a repeat of the skills that are important to this Occupation. You should find most of them are ones you enjoy using, which is why this Occupation is on your list.
Job Zone
A Job Zone is a group of occupations that are similar in: how much education people need to do the work, how much related experience people need to do the work, and how much on-the-job training people need to do the work. Job Zone 1 needs little preparation and Job Zone 5 needs extensive. Both Chief Executives and Treasurers/Controllers are Zone 5.
Interests
This uses the Strong Interest Inventory codes. For example Treasurers/Controllers Interest Code is CE (Conventional and Enterprising). Edward's Code is ECS (Enterprising, Conventional and Social). Thus this Occupation is a good match for his Interests.
Income/Employment
You can find out the Median Wages and projected employment growth.
Related Occupations
There are often other Occupations that will use similar skills.
Sources of Additional Information
Click on Occupational Outlook Handbook - Top Executives to see the Bureau of Labor Statistics valuable report.

item.title: Step 4 - Create Insights-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

It is time to document what you have learned from examining your skills and potential Occupations.

Insights

You can examine multiple areas.
Skills (All vs. Enjoy) Insights
Were you surprised at your skills list? Were you able to define them easily? How many skills did you drop to get to your Skills Enjoyed list?
Skill/Occupation Insights
Do the Occupations the Skills System recommends seem to make sense to you? If you look at a particular Occupation do the Skills required make sense?
Occupations Themselves
What did you learn by examining the Summary Report for any particular occupation?

Edward Insights Example

Edward is trying to decide if he should go out and work as an engineer, go get an MBA or go get a Law degree. Click on Edward's Skills Insights "A lot of the Skills I enjoy using are analytical, which coincides with my INTJ personality. It is also the reason I went to engineering school in the first place. But as I found out those same skills lend themselves to other Occupations than engineering." His skills pointed to business Occupations as the best fit - his top two Occupations use 12 of the 12 skills he enjoys using. Those two Occupations are listed #1 and #2 on his list. - Chief Executives (e.g., CEO, President, CFO, COO, General Manager, Exec VP, Vice President) - Treasurers and Controllers (e.g., Chief Financial Officer (CFO), Comptroller, Controller, Director of Finance, Finance Vice President, Treasurer) The Lawyers Occupation ends up on Page 3. The Skills exercise says getting an MBA to prepare for a business career is probably a better use of Edward's skills than going to Law School to prepare for a legal career.

item.title: Old MyRightCareer Insights
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: "Be Your Best", "Meaning & Passion", "Fuel Your Economic Engine", "Right Opportunity" and "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Casey Examples

These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Strengths, Skills, Meaning (Stories, Drivers, How will you Measure your Life) and Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how she has added insights with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Edward Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights he obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Personality, Interests, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Strengths, Skills, Meaning (Stories, Drivers, How will you Measure your Life) and Economic Engine. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Edward's "Be Your Best" Insights Edward's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Edward's "Economic Engine" Insights Edward's "Right Career" Insights Edward's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy.

Take Your Next Step - Provide Feedback

item.title: Step 5 - Add to MyRightCareer Insights-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights obtained from completing all the exercises except Economic Engine: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories and Drivers. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Edward's "Be Your Best" Insights Edward's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Edward's "Economic Engine" Insights Edward's "Right Career" Insights Edward's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: You have now identified your Skills, some of them are related to your natural personality and strengths. You should be able to find a lot of insights. - Meaning & Passion: Are there areas where you interests and your passion intersect? It is very normal for you to find meaning and have passion when you are using Skills you enjoy using. - Fuel your Economic Engine: Do you see how you can leverage your Skills to fuel you economic engine. - Right Opportunities: What Occupations did you identify? - Whole Person: What types of environments most interest you.

item.title: Step 6 - Discuss with Adviser-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Now it is time to discuss your results with your Adviser. You may have been communicating with them along the way so they may already know some of what you have done, e.g. you might have shared your O*NET Skills report. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

Discuss Content Issues

  • Skills Share your Skills - the entire list and the ones you enjoy using.
  • Occupations: Discuss the Occupations O*NET suggest for those skills.
  • Specific Occupations: Choose a couple of occupations and talk about them.
  • Skills Insights: Explain the insights you have gained about which Skills you have and which you enjoy. Also explain the relationship between these skills and potential Occupations.
  • MyRightCareer Insights documents:: These are the most important documents you will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. These documents must be discussed.

    Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
  • Schedule: You have now done seven exercises and you should have a handle on the schedule by now.
  • Adviser Review Process: Most likely you have now settled into a process that works for the two of you, e.g. how you communicate, how you review.
  • Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing these exercises.

item.title: Step 7 - Provide Feedback-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We making changes to the MyRightCareer Program and Web site in almost real time so your timely feedback is very important. Students coming after you will benefit from it.
When you get to the end of a section, hit Next to go to the next Section, at the end of a Section you can hit previous to go back one page and change your answers. Once you are comfortable with your answers hit Done and it will take you to the next Section. When you reach the last Section the system will say the Survey is completed. Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input. Once you are finished with the Survey please send Don an email at Don@My-Right-Career.com.
Click here to take survey

item.title: Step 8 - Become an Example-Skills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the same process we used in the previous exercises.

A) Send your completed exercises to Don

Send all of your completed material for this exercise to Don: Skills You Enjoyed, Occupations and your Insights document. He will review it and remove anything he feels would disclose your personal identity, e.g. names of friends, high school name, college name. He will conform the file names, headings, etc to the standards used on all the other examples (if you used the templates this will not require much work). He will append your "stage name" to the front of all of the files.

B) Review and comment on Don's Exercise files

Don will send you the proposed exercise files. You should review them and suggest any changes you would like made, e.g. drop this information, reword this information.

C) Don will load your Example on Examples page

He will add these examples to your section on the Examples page. Individual pieces of your example may be integrated into the Full Instructions. As Don gets more examples he will use examples he feels do a good job explaining key ideas.

item.title: Step 1 - StrengthsFinder 2.0 Assessment
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

You need to do an assessment before you can do the actual exercises (which use the outputs of the assessment).

Assessment Access - Your Career Center

Once the system reaches Beta Test the students will have to take all their Assessments (i.e. Myers-Briggs, Do What You Are, Strong Interest Inventory and StrengthsFinder 2.0) through their Career Center. During this Alpha Test we want to test how well this works by having you go to your Career Center for these Assessments. For this exercise we would like you to see if your Career Center offers the StrengthsFinder 2.0 Assessment. If so please take it through the Career Center and then use the output to finish this exercise. If you watched either (or both) of the Marcus Buckingham videos you know focusing on leveraging your Strengths is one of secrets of success. You may not realize it has been embraced by a large number of very successful companies. Your Career Center may not realize this and you could suggest they pay for you to take the Assessment as a way for them to experiment (for only $10) with the Strengths movement.

Assessment Access - No Career Center Support

If your Career Center does not or will not support the StrengthsFinder 2.0 assessment you need to purchase the access code via the Gallup Strengths Center. The cost of this assessment is $9.
In that case you need to tell Don you were not able to take the assessments through your Career Center and some of the reasons why not. We would like to understand the problems of taking these assessments via the student's Career Center. Don will then email you the $10.

StrengthsFinder 2.0 Assessment

Click on link below to the Gallup Strengths Center. You are going to take the "Strengths Discovery Package".

  • Gallup Strengths Center

    What you are purchasing is a unique access code to the StrengthsFinder 2.0 Assessment. You will use that Access Code to register and set up an ID (your email) and Password. Then you will take the assessment and you will be able to download a pdf file containing your personal StrengthsFinder 2.0 Report. The assessment takes about 45 minutes and you need to finish it in one sitting. You can come back to the Web site as often as you wish to retrieve that report again or look at other Strength related resources.

item.title: Step 2 - Strengths Awareness
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Section I (Awareness)

In the StrengthsFinder 2.0 Report, study Section I (Awareness), which describe what makes you stand out from others with the same theme in their top five, for each of your top five themes.
For an example click on Casey's StrengthsFinder2 Report

Personalize Awareness

Personalize your Section I (Awareness) report by completing the following steps:
  • On each of your five Top Talents pages take a highlighter and mark the sentences that you think best describe you. Pick the ones that stand out to you. If you have Adobe Acrobat you can annotate the electronic file like Casey did Annotated Strengths Insights
  • Answer the questions they pose to increase your awareness of your talent.
  • Create a one page summary of what you have learned by looking at all five Top Talents. You most likely have common themes running through your Top Talents.
    For an example click on Casey's Strengths Insights.

item.title: Step 3 - Ideas for Action-Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Section II - Ideas for Action

In the StrengthsFinder2 Report (Section II - Action Planning Guide) there are 10 Recommended Actions you can take for each of your Five Top Talents.
For an example click on Casey's Action Planning Guide

Personalize your Ideas for Action

  • Pick two or three of the 10 Ideas for Action for each of your top five themes that you would like to implement during the next year. Take a highlighter and mark those Ideas for Action. If you have Adobe Acrobat you can annotate the electronic file like Casey did Annotated Ideas for Actions
  • Create a one page summary of what you have learned by looking at all your Ideas for Action. If you picked three for each of your Top 5 Talents you will have 30 Ideas for Action. You most likely have common themes running through those 30 Ideas for Action. For an example click on Casey's Ideas for Action Insights.

item.title: Step 4 - Add to MyRightCareer Insights-Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: You have now identified a lot of your interests, some of them are related to your natural personality and strengths. Add insights you have gained to this file. You should be able to find a lot of insights, just like Casey did. - Meaning & Passion: Are there areas where you interests and your passion intersect? Casey found a lot of these. It is very normal for you to find meaning and have passion for things that interest you. - Fuel your Economic Engine: Do you see how you can leverage your interests to fuel you economic engine. Do you see how your interests may cause you to require more fuel. - Right Opportunities: What careers and jobs did you identify? You should have found some in the Strong Interest Inventory report and some more in the Strong and Myers-Briggs report. - Whole Person: What types of environments most interest you. The Strong Theme & Myers-Briggs Type provides some good clues on your preferred work environment. The Strong Personal Style & Myers-Briggs Preferences provides insights on how you like to work.

item.title: Step 5 - Discuss with Adviser-Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Now it is time to discuss your results with your Adviser. You may have been communicating with them along the way so they may already know some of what you have done, e.g. you might have shared your StrenghtsFinder report. But assuming you have not shared anything here are the suggested items to share and discuss:

Discuss Content Issues

  • StrengthsFinder Report Share your Top Five Talents and some of the key findings from the StrengthsFinder Report.
  • Strengths/Talents Insights: Help them understand, from your viewpoint, the insights you have gained into your Talents/Strengths and their influence on your Career.
  • Strengths Ideas for Action: Explain some of the main Ideas for Action you have chosen and why you chose them.
  • Ideas for Action Insights: Explain what the Ideas for Action has helped you understand about your Talents/Strengths.
  • MyRightCareer Insights documents:: These are the most important documents you will be creating during the program. There is one document for each of the circles in the Right Career Venn diagram. These documents must be discussed.

    Discuss Process Issues

    These last items are process oriented issues:
  • Schedule: You have now done seven exercises and you should have a handle on the schedule by now.
  • Adviser Review Process: Most likely you have now settled into a process that works for the two of you, e.g. how you communicate, how you review.
  • Anything else you want to discuss: Who knows what has come up in doing these exercises.

item.title: Step 6 - Provide Feedback-Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We making changes to the MyRightCareer Program and Web site in almost real time so your timely feedback is very important. Students coming after you will benefit from it.
Most of the feedback in this survey asks you to agree or disagree with a statement. You have five levels of agreement: Strongly Disagree, Disagree, Neutral, Agree, Strongly Agree. Besides that you will have a chance to provide free form textual input.
Please send an email to Don@My-Right-Career.com when you finish the survey.
Click here to take survey

item.title: Step 7 - Become an Example-Strengths
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is the same process we used in the previous exercise.

A) Send your completed exercises to Don

Send all of your completed material for this exercise to Don: StrengthsFinder Report, Strengths/Talents Insights, Strengths Ideas for Action and Ideas for Action Insights. He will review it and remove anything he feels would disclose your personal identity, e.g. names of friends, high school name, college name. He will conform the file names, headings, etc to the standards used on all the other examples (if you used the templates this will not require much work). He will append your "stage name" to the front of all of the files.

B) Review and comment on Don's Exercise files

Don will send you the proposed exercise files. You should review them and suggest any changes you would like made, e.g. drop this information, reword this information.

C) Don will load your Example on Examples page

He will add these examples to your section on the Examples page. Individual pieces of your example may be integrated into the Full Instructions. As Don gets more examples he will use examples he feels do a good job explaining key ideas. Your example may be used on Exercise #2 and then not again until Exercise #4 and #5.

item.title: Step 0 - Introduction-Accomp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Accomplishments Approach

You are looking at your accomplishments for three reasons. First so you can pull together a comprehensive list of your accomplishments. Second so you can identify the accomplishments you really enjoyed doing because it would be great if your career had more of these types of experiences. Third so you identify accomplishments you did not really enjoy doing because it would be great if your career was not made up of a lot of these types of accomplishments.

Overview

Welcome to the Accomplishments Exercise

Click on the link above to see a video where Don explains your Exercise via some examples. At the conclusion of the video close the Windows Media Player, then close the page it was running in and you will return to this page.

Instructions

You need to: 1) Create a list of all of your accomplishments, 2) Create a list of 3 to 10 accomplishments you really enjoyed doing and 2 to 3 accomplishments you did not enjoy doing, 3) Document the insights you gained from the exercise, 4) Add to your MyRightCareer Insights, 5) Provide feedback, 6) Discuss your completed exercise with your Facilitator and 7) Become an Example. None of the steps take longer than one hour. Steps 1 through 4 will probably take you about 2 hours.

item.title: Step 8 - 2nd Career Advisory Board Meeting
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Now is time to share the results of your final three Assignments: Strengths (Skills & Talents/Strengths), Meaning/Passion (Stories, Drivers, How to Measure Your Life & Meaning Insights) and Economic Engine with your Career Advisory Board. At this point you will have completed all six Insights Assignments so it is important to get as much guidance and insight from the Board as you can.
You should proceed with the next Capstone Assignment while you are having discussions with your Career Advisory Board members. Due to schedule conflicts it could take several weeks to complete this step and you can be working on Capstone Assignment in parallel.

Discuss Your MyRightCareer Insights

At the minimum you need to send them your five MyRightCareer Insights files from your last exercise (Economic Engine): Be Your Best, Meaning & Passion, Economic Engine, Right Career and Whole Person.
For each area, e.g. Be Your Best, you should have a dialogue about what you have discovered about yourself relative to that element in the Right Career Venn diagram. You should also have a discussion about what you have learned about yourself as a Whole Person, the fifth file.
Here are Casey's as an example, except they have insights for all of the exercises:
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Discuss Your Key Exercise Output

For the Board Members you know would like to have supporting detail to the MyRightCareer Insights you can send them files from each of your three Assignments: Strengths (Skills & Talents/Strengths), Meaning/Passion (Stories, Drivers, How to Measure Your Life & Meaning Insights) and Economic Engine Below are Casey's examples.

Strengths Assignment

  • Skills Exercise
    Casey's Top Skills Casey's Top Skills Insights
  • Talents/Strengths Exercise
    Casey's StrengthsFinder2 Report Casey's Strengths Insights

    • Meaning/Passion Assignment

  • Stories Exercise
    Casey's Soccer Endurance Casey's Long Term Friends Casey's No Math
  • Drivers Exercise
    Casey's Top Drivers List Casey's Drivers Insights
  • How Will You Measure Your Life Exercise
    Casey's Measure Your Life
  • Meaning Insights Exercise
    Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Summary

    Economic Engine Assignment

  • Age 30 Budget
    Casey's Age 30 Budget Casey's Age 30 Budget - Insights
  • Age 22 Budget
    Casey's Age 22 Budget Casey's Age 22 Budget - Insights

    B) Discuss What is Next

    Remind them your last review will take place after the Capstone Project, where you will have identified your Right Career (s), developed your Sales Story for that Right Career (s) and created a Follow-on Plan.

item.title: Step 6 - 3rd Career Advisory Board Meeting
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Now is time to share your Right Career (s), your Sales Story for that Right Career (s) and your Follow-on Plan with your Career Advisory Board.

Your Right Career

Share with them the Right Career (s) you identified and why. For example Casey identified her Right Career as:
  • Function: Director of Marketing and Public Relations
  • Industry: Apparel, specifically consignment/vintage stores
  • Location: Major Cities, e.g. Boston, San Francisco, Chicago, Los Angeles, and New York City
    She had created the following two files to support that choice and shared them with the Board:
  • Casey's Right Career - Summary (2 Pages)
  • Casey's Right Career - Elevator Statement (3/4 Page)
    You want to engage each of them in a discussion about your logic for your choice.

    Your Sales Story

    Share with them your two versions of your Sales Story - a full version (greater than one page) and an Elevator Version (less than one page)
  • Casey's Sales Story (2 pages)
  • Casey's Sales Story - Elevator Statement (3/4 Page)
    Point out to them that the Sales Story (2 pages) file and the Right Career (2 pages) files are very similar. They both contain the basic same information because the career that is right for you is also the one in which you will most likely be successful. The Sales Story (2 pages) version is written in a more pro active voice. You want to engage each of them in a discussion about your Sales Story - what is missing, what should be dropped, what should be strengthened.

    Your Follow-on Plan

    Now share with them your Follow-on Plan. Think about incorporating one or two Career Advisory Board Meetings in that Follow-on Plan. It is a great way to ensure you will carry out the plan. It will also keep your Board members engaged with you and your success.
  • Casey's Follow-on Plan

    Discuss What is Next

    You should ask them if they will help you stay on track as you implement your Follow-on Plan. Ideally you will have built-in some checkpoints where it would make sense to get their input.

item.title: Success Built to Last
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

This is a short course on the Success Built to Last research. It provides the research findings that support the Meaning & Passion circle in the Right Career Venn diagram. • Create meaning and passion in your life • Be your best • Fuel the “economic engine” that leads to financial security . . . . .

Intsructions

Click on

Success Built to Last Instructions

item.title: 1 - Intern Guidance
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Test Bilbo   As an Intern you will be using the MyRightCareer system differently depending on the type of Internship you are completing. Find your Internships below and read the Guidance before proceeding.

Program Usage and Content Internships

The Program Usage & Content category has three Internships (Total Program, Assignment and Content Development), as well as the opportunity to design your own Custom Internship. There are several things in common to all of these Program Usage & Content Internships:
  • You are actually using the MyRightCareer system, not filling a role in Marketing, Development or Company Management.
  • You are providing feedback on each exercise through a SurveyMonkey survey
  • You are allowing Don to use your exercise output as a potential example
Total Program Internship
The Total Program Internship requires you to complete the entire MyRightCareer Program: the Pre-Requisite Assignment, all 6 Insight Assignments and the Capstone Assignment. While the MyRightCareer Program is totally self-paced, so you can determine your own schedule, it is recommended you plan on a 12 week schedule. Thus you are making a major time commitment by signing up for the Total Program Internship, i.e. 50 hours over 12 weeks. You must also recruit a Team to help you (an Adviser/Facilitator and Career Advisory Board). Thus you are not only committing your time, you are asking others to commit their time and coordinate schedules with you for reviews.
Assignment Internship
The Assignment Internship requires you to complete a set of three related Insights Assignments, out of the 6 Insights Assignments in the MyRightCareer Program and will probably take 18 to 24 hours to complete. You will be completing the Pre-Requisite, Begin at the End and two Assignments chosen by Don & you together. You do not have to recruit a team (Adviser/Facilitator and Career Advisory Board) so you are not committing anyone’s time, nor do you have to coordinate schedules with them. This means you do not have to complete those exercises in the Pre-Requisites Assignment.
Content Strategy Internship
The Content Strategy Internship requires you to improve the overall content strategy for the entire program or the improvement of at least one Assignment (which usually contains two Exercises). The Strategy improvement may take forms very similar to those of an individual exercise, but be designed to apply to all the exercises, e.g. instructions, examples, templates, exercise flow, Short vs. Full Instructions, general feedback, SurveyMonkey questions & feedback, other feedback, use of YouTube/video’s, use of Facebook,and many others. This area can include recommendations to add Exercises or drop Exercises. Alternately you can contribute to the improvement of at least one Assignment (which usually contains two Exercises). The improvement can take many forms of improvements, e.g. instructions, examples, templates, exercise flow, Short vs. Full Instructions, general feedback, SurveyMonkey questions & feedback, other feedback, use of YouTube/video’s, use of Facebook,and many others. You do not have to recruit a team (Adviser/Facilitator and Career Advisory Board) so you are not committing anyone’s time, nor do you have to coordinate schedules with them. This means you do not have to complete those exercises in the Pre-Requisites Assignment, unless you have chosen to focus on the Adviser and/or Career Advisory Board as the area you hope to improve.

Marketing and Sales Internships

There are a wide range of Internships in this category, e.g. Marketing Strategy, Web-based Marketing, Social media, Product Management, Competition, Sales and Recruitment.
Common Tasks for All Marketing Internships
There are several things in common to all of the Marketing Internships:
  • You are only using the MyRightCareer system to gain an appreciation of it so you can be effective in your Internship. You will be completing the Pre-Requisite, Begin at the End and two Assignments chosen by Don & you together.
  • You do not have to recruit a team (Adviser/Facilitator and Career Advisory Board) so you are not committing anyone’s time, nor do you have to coordinate schedules with them. This means you do not have to complete those exercises in the Pre-Requisites Assignment.
  • You are providing feedback on each exercise you complete, through a SurveyMonkey survey
  • You are allowing Don to use your exercise output as a potential example
Missing Pre-Requisite Exercises
While you can complete the Insights Assignment in any order you want it is recommended you complete them in the order they are shown across the top of the page: Future --> Self --> Past --> Strengths --> Meaning --> Economics. If you do them out of order or the two Assignments from Don are later in the sequence, there is a simple solution. In the instructions for the following Exercises, where this problem occurs, there will be guidance for fulfilling the pre-requisite: Strengths Assignment (Skills Exercise), Meaning Assignment (Stories Exercise), Economic Engine Assignment (Age 30 Budget Exercise). For example, to complete the Age 30 Budget Exercise you only have to complete, from the Begin at the End Assignment, "Step 1 - Visualize your self at Age 30", not all four steps in the Begin at the End exercise.

Development Internships

There are a wide range of Internships in this category, e.g.
  • Marketing site: Technology and Marketing site-Ease of Use & Other
  • Content site: Technology, Content site-eLearning Platform, Content site-Ease of Use and Content site-Commerce.
Common Tasks for All Development Internships
There are several things in common to all of the Development Internships:
  • You are only using the MyRightCareer system to gain an appreciation of it so you can be effective in your Internship. You will be completing the Pre-Requisite, Begin at the End and two Assignments chosen by Don & you together.
  • You do not have to recruit a team (Adviser/Facilitator and Career Advisory Board) so you are not committing anyone’s time, nor do you have to coordinate schedules with them. This means you do not have to complete those exercises in the Pre-Requisites Assignment.
  • You are providing feedback on each exercise you complete, through a SurveyMonkey survey
  • You are allowing Don to use your exercise output as a potential example
Missing Pre-Requisite Exercises
While you can complete the Insights Assignment in any order you want it is recommended you complete them in the order they are shown across the top of the page: Future --> Self --> Past --> Strengths --> Meaning --> Economics. If you do them out of order or the two Assignments from Don are later in the sequence, there is a simple solution. In the instructions for the following Exercises, where this problem occurs, there will be guidance for fulfilling the pre-requisite: Strengths Assignment (Skills Exercise), Meaning Assignment (Stories Exercise), Economic Engine Assignment (Age 30 Budget Exercise). For example, to complete the Age 30 Budget Exercise you only have to complete, from the Begin at the End Assignment, "Step 1 - Visualize your self at Age 30", not all four steps in the Begin at the End exercise.

item.title: MyRightCareer Insights-Stories
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: Do any of your stories show when you are at your Best? Add insights you have gained to this file. - Meaning & Passion: You were asked to write stories about accomplishments you really enjoyed doing. Are there areas where your accomplishments and your passion intersect? - Fuel your Economic Engine: Do you see how you can leverage your meaning/passion to fuel you economic engine. Do you see how it may cause you to pursue a career (s) that don't pay very well. - Right Opportunities: Did you identify any careers and jobs? Maybe a story reminded you how much you enjoyed something that you have since dropped. - Whole Person: Your stories probably give you some good insights into Whole Person issues.

item.title: MyRightCareer Insights-Drivers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents

Take your existing MyRightCareer Insights documents and add the insights you have gained from this exercise. Remember you only have one file for each of the four circles in the Venn diagram and then a fifth file for the Whole Person. You do not create new MyRightCareer Insights files for each exercise. Instead you are adding insights on top of the insights from the previous exercise. Within each file are the headings for the Exercises to make this easy. You can see this by looking at Casey’s examples above. Be sure to add insights to each of the documents: - Be Your Best: Are any of your Drivers the base for your achievements? Add insights you have gained to this file. - Meaning & Passion: Are the things that are your Drivers also things that have meaning to you and for which you have passion? - Fuel your Economic Engine: Do you see how you can leverage your Drivers to fuel you economic engine. Do you see how it may cause you to pursue a career (s) that don't pay very well. - Right Opportunities: Did you identify any careers and jobs? Your Drivers may point you toward certain type of roles or types of industries. - Whole Person: Your Drivers are not just about work.

item.title: MyRightCareer Insights-Measure
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Overview

If you remember from the previous exercises, there are five MyRightCareer Insights files: one for "Be Your Best", one for "Meaning & Passion", one for "Fuel Your Economic Engine", one for "Right Opportunity" and one for "Whole Person". Each file has a section for you to record your insights after you complete each exercise. By the end of the MyRightCareer Program you will have accumulated a lot of insights that will assist you in identifying your Right Career and preparing your Sales Story.

Examples

MyRightCareer Insights These five documents are examples of the insights Casey obtained from completing all the exercises: Begin at the End, Autobiography, Accomplishments, Personality, Interests, Strengths, Skills, Stories, Drivers, How Will You Measure Your Life and Fuel Your Economic Engine. From these examples you can see how insights were added with every exercise. Some of the insights might be the same, just stated in a slightly different way. Or you can have the exact same insights used in multiple circles. In fact that is what you want to see. Then you start to pick up some themes. Click on the links below to see the documents.
Casey's "Be Your Best" Insights Casey's "Meaning & Passion" Insights Casey's "Economic Engine" Insights Casey's "Right Career" Insights Casey's "Whole Person" Insights

Update your MyRightCareer Insights Documents
